TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. In the light of obstacles that seem to be growing within the Labor caucus and cabinet, I ask the minister: what will be the implications for the Australian health system if his changes are rejected?

—I would have thought that that would be a matter of opinion. The effects on the health system of the proposals that I have put up being rejected would obviously be in the eye of the beholder, and there are plenty of beholders around. During the morning both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have rung me to tell me that they have been grievously misrepresented this morning.
—How sad!

—Why? All I can do is report what they say. That is what they both said, and I would choose to believe them. That being the case, as far as I am concerned, I will proceed to run the gauntlet of my party colleagues over the next few days—
—That is not unusual for you.

—I have been doing it all my life. We shall see what the end result of that is. Obviously, I would not have put up these proposals if I did not believe that they were necessary and if I did not believe that, over time, unless something is done, there are going to be some serious consequences for the public health system. I have stressed, of course, that they are not for now, that I was looking at the medium term—the 10- to 20-year term—where I believe we will get some problems down the track if we do not act now. It is my hope that the proposals that I have put forward will be adopted, and I shall continue to press them until we find to the contrary.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That answer does not provide us with a lot of information. Therefore, we will try again. Presumably, if the minister is arguing for change, he recognises shortcomings currently exist in the system. I note that he has been referring to strains that exist in the system. We therefore ask him as health minister what shortcomings he recognises currently exist which will further deteriorate if the changes he is advocating are not in fact implemented?

—I am not sure that I have much to add to the first answer that I gave. I have said that there are strains in the system. I have identified them as being waiting lists in public hospitals around the country. As Senator Hill and other honourable senators would be aware, in the last fortnight we have announced a $100 million package which we hope will address that. Certainly in the course of the next few years it will show us the way that that ought to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: I have said that there needs to be extra because, if I cannot be sure that over a 10- to 20-year term there will not be added pressures over and above those, the strain will become serious. At the moment, the system copes. With the extra $100 million that we have talked about and with the demonstration projects that it will show, I am sure that the system will continue to cope well. It just depends what volume it faces over that one to two decades.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I will not misrepresent the Prime Minister. Yesterday in the other place he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Medicare is working so well that people are leaving the private health system and joining the public health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand by what I said. I agree with what Paul Keating said yesterday. I have made the same statement repeatedly. If Senator Herron had been paying attention over the last few months, he would know that.

PARA.TAB: I have repeatedly said that people have voted with their feet as far as private health insurance is concerned. They have left it in droves. They go into the public health system because we have one of the best public health systems in the world. That is an absolute fact, and I stand by it. Not only has the Prime Minister said it; I have said it time and time again.

That having been said, what I have pointed out continually, as I did in my answer to Senator Hill, is that I am therefore not looking at the situation as of this afternoon. I am not concerned that there is any crisis in our system now. I want to make sure that over the next 10 to 20 years some extra strains will be avoided. That is why I have said that we should try to put a floor on the numbers that are in private health insurance now.

I do not find any difficulty in the Prime Minister saying that because I have said it many times myself publicly. I agree with him. His comments do not change by one iota my view about the future. I see a problem that is not here today. Perhaps sometimes we have to look ahead and address problems before they exist. That is what I am seeking to do.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of a series of newspaper articles which refer to legal action being taken against CSL Ltd by the relatives of those who received human pituitary hormones, pertussis vaccine and a range of blood products? I can think of one article written by Jennifer Cooke in the Sydney Morning Herald which referred to 31 actions—I think that is the figure; I do not have the article with me—that have been taken. —The Minister for Resources has advised me in answer to Senator Coulter's scurrilous question that he has no direct knowledge of the arrest of certain people in Japan for bribing politicians. In terms of Senator Coulter's second question, yes to the first part and yes to the second part.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Honourable senators will no doubt be aware of the announcement by the Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Hosokawa, that Japan has agreed to open its rice markets. I ask the minister whether he can inform the Senate of the implications of this decision will have for the Uruguay Round negotiations and the Australian rice industry.

—The announcement by Japanese Prime Minister Hosokawa earlier today that Japan will open its market to rice imports is a very welcome and courageous one, and it does remove the final major obstacle to concluding the Uruguay Round agriculture negotiations by tomorrow's deadline. The announcement by Japan has been a very long awaited one and will certainly generate significant commercial benefits for Australia's rice industry.

PARA.TAB: Japan will be opening its very lucrative market in 1995 to around 400,000 tonnes of imported rice, which is equivalent to four per cent of domestic production. Over the six years from 1995 to 2000 the access will expand to 800,000 tonnes, equivalent to eight per cent of domestic consumption. The Japanese market for imported rice in the year 2000 will be almost double Australia's current level of total rice exports, which are valued at around $230 million.

The Australian industry has been actively gearing up for the eventual opening of the Japanese market for some time and has already been successful in securing sales under the emergency import arrangements that Japan has just put in place for next year as a result of its current poor harvest. The movement by Japan on rice, coupled with the announcement of the South Korean President, Kim Young-Sam, on 9 December that South Korea would also allow rice imports as part of the Uruguay Round settlement, have vindicated the very strong stand that has been taken by Australia and the other members of the Cairns Group in pressing strongly and consistently for liberalisation of access for all agricultural products without exceptions.

This will be a major and enduring benefit of the Uruguay Round agreement on agriculture for efficient agricultural producers. It will open markets formerly closed, as in Japan and Korea, and improve the transparency, predictability and security of access to other agricultural markets for the full range of agricultural products.

As I indicated in answer to a question yesterday, there have been modifications agreed to the Blair House accord by the United States and the European Union which affect rice. However, the end point of reductions has not been affected by these adjustments and the US will have to reduce its current levels of subsidies by almost 90 per cent. Nonetheless, as I did say yesterday, we are still concerned that the US will have substantial capacity in the early years of the implementation period to subsidise its exports heavily, including possibly to the Japan and Korean markets.

Senator Cook, who is in Geneva now, has raised with the United States our concerns about the additional flexibility provided to export subsidies on rice and has put some proposals to the United States which would minimise the potential adverse impact on Australian rice exports. We will be hoping very much that those proposals can be accepted and that we can benefit accordingly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of the Arts and Administrative Services

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. In the 1992-93 budget the government announced a review of the commercialisation program in the minister's department. What is the current status of that review and what are the key issues being addressed by the review?

—An important review of commercialisation has been initiated and it is intended to report to the government in the 1994-95 budget context. It would be of interest to at least some members of parliament that that review overlaps with some reviews undertaken by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into commercialisation and will also be impacted upon by the important Hilmer report on national competition policy. It is important from time to time to look at where these reviews are going and look at what the current situation is with regard to the matters under review.

PARA.TAB: With the good work of my colleagues and predecessors since 1987, the department of administrative services has changed from one which has provided a range of prominent services to one which competes on the basis of user choice and users having to pay. It has been transformed so that there are now some 14 commercially focused business units within the administrative services portfolio, which turned a 1987 loss of $68 million into a net operating return in 1993 of some $17 million. There have been cost reductions of about 30 per cent, increased productivity in terms of sales for employees of around five per cent per year and improved returns on the Commonwealth's equity up to 6.4 per cent in 1992-93. The Auditor-General has also commented favourably on the results of the DAAS commercialisation experience.

These changes have not been easy. They have only been achieved with a lot of commitment from staff and have required a transformation of the culture and ethos of the department into one which competes with private sector providers. I welcome the opportunity to say something about this today because I want to say something about the particular personal efforts of one individual in achieving this outcome. I refer to Noel Tanzer, currently the secretary to the department, who has been at the centre of the reform process throughout that time.

As honourable senators would know, Noel will be retiring shortly from that position. He will be leaving secure in the knowledge that he has done an outstanding job and has had one of those rare opportunities to initiate and secure fundamental administrative reform. He has provided inspired leadership and has done it with courage and sensitivity. I would like to place on the record the government's great appreciation of Noel's achievements in this regard. He leaves for his successor a very strong organisation and I think he should be regarded by all Australians as someone who has given outstanding service to the Public Service and the nation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Has the minister seen the West Australian article of 13 December 1993, in which it is reported that Dr Wayne Bradshaw, wanted for alleged corruption charges in Western Australia, has been located living in the Maldives? Will Australia seek the extradition of Dr Bradshaw from the Maldives to face charges in Western Australia?

—It is important to note that in Australia extradition proceedings are conducted under standing arrangements between state and federal governments. In accordance with our procedures, the Australian government only considers making a formal extradition request to another country when asked to do so by the prosecuting authorities of a state, territory or, of course, the Commonwealth. Normally, responsibility for making such a request to the Commonwealth rests with the relevant state attorney-general or director of public prosecutions.

PARA.TAB: In the particular case that Senator Chris Evans refers to, the corruption offences that Dr Bradshaw is alleged to have committed are offences against the laws of Western Australia. Responsibility therefore for their investigation and prosecution rests with the Western Australian authorities. It is important to note that, given the public interest in Western Australia about the relationship between the Attorney-General of WA and Dr Bradshaw, my advice is that no request for Dr Bradshaw's extradition has been received from the Western Australian Attorney-General, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, or her DPP. In terms of the next step, should Western Australia seek Dr Bradshaw's extradition, the Attorney-General will consider making a formal request to the Maldives. If such request is made, then it would be a matter for the Maldives to consider that request in accordance with its laws.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Vandalism of War Cemeteries and Memorials

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to a recent spate of vandalism in war cemeteries and war memorials in Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane. Will the minister inform the Senate what action has been taken to preserve those monuments and burial places for the benefit of all Australians and in the memory of those who made their final contribution to this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there have been some recent acts of vandalism in war cemeteries and memorials in Adelaide, Brisbane and Perth. These events are a continuation of a problem that, regrettably, has become more prevalent over recent years.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that, as Senator McKiernan has said in asking his question, all in this chamber would agree that acts of vandalism against a war cemetery or a memorial are particularly mindless and cowardly. Previous episodes of vandalism have occurred in one form or another in most major war cemeteries and plots over the past five years, but in 1989, over the Christmas break, vandals completely destroyed the Goulburn War Cemetery, resulting in the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs announcing a $3,000 reward would be paid on the conviction of those who vandalised war cemeteries and war memorials. The result of that was the arrest of those responsible for the desecration of war memorials in Brisbane's Balmoral Cemetery in 1992.

I ought also say to the Senate that the cost to the Office of Australian War Graves, and ultimately to the taxpayer, has been increasing not only for the repairs to and replacement of memorials but also on prevention in the form of security alarms, patrols and the like in war cemeteries. There have been some five acts of major vandalism and numerous minor instances during the past five years, resulting in in excess of $25,000 in direct costs and much more in indirect costs.

The Office of Australian War Graves has in place new security systems in the major locations, including the gardens of remembrance in most states and Papua New Guinea, and has programmed additions in other areas. Approaches to the editors of local press outlining the nature of these senseless and uncivilised acts have to some extent drawn the public's attention to this problem.

The other aspect that I think is worth mentioning to honourable senators is the fact that this does have a serious effect on the morale of the staff of the Office of Australian War Graves. I think all honourable senators, and certainly those Australians who visit these places of commemoration, will appreciate that these acts of vandalism are devastating to the war graves' employees, who take a real pride in the presentation and maintenance of our cemeteries and war memorials.

Continued efforts are being made to improve security in our gardens and war cemeteries as well as to put more reliance on the public who, I think, are equally outraged at the nature of these mindless activities. I am very hopeful that the continuing offer of a $3,000 reward for information leading to a conviction will result in the apprehension of those responsible for these latest acts of vandalism in the three cities that have been mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer him to an answer he gave earlier in question time to Senator Chris Evans. I ask him no more than whether he will table the document from which he read.
—No, Mr President.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Dr Mahathir and other ministers are quoted as saying that the Malaysian cabinet had decided to call off the row with Australia because of the `reaction of Australians in general to the remarks of their Prime Minister'. Last week Senator Gareth Evans accused the opposition of fuelling this unnecessary dispute by expressing the Australian public's outrage on this issue. Why was he prepared to mouth a defence for the Prime Minister when he knew it was inappropriate? The unseemly spectacle of repeated expressions of regret being dragged out of the Prime Minister will not be easily forgotten. Will the government consider allocating advertising funds promoting Australian produce and manufactured goods to offset the loss of sales caused by the Prime Minister's intemperate remarks?
—Last week Dr Mahathir said that he and the Malaysian government regarded this matter as closed. So do we.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. The minister will be aware of reports claiming that some sunscreens lose their effectiveness over relatively short periods of time. What action is the government taking to address this problem?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am shocked that honourable senators opposite want to mock this. Summer is coming on and Senator Boswell, particularly, coming from Queensland where skin cancer has the highest incidence in Australia, and probably holds the world title, should be very concerned about this article and the point that is raised by it. What is at question is whether or not sunscreens actually lose their effectiveness if they are exposed to heat—for example, if they are left in the glove box of a car or left lying in the sun for any length of time. This matter has just been brought to the notice of the pharmaceutical industries and also the TGA.

PARA.TAB: There is no advice, no warning and no expiry date information on sunscreens. It is a very serious matter that people buying sunscreens—particularly those marketed as 8+ or 15+—expecting to have a full sunscreen protection may then discover that they do not. So this matter is properly raised and brought to my attention.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration has obtained a sample of the product that was the subject of the newspaper article. It is examining that sample to test for stability, content and the appropriate broad spectrum claims ascribed to that sunscreen. If the TGA's review demonstrates any concern about those claims—particularly as to effectiveness and its loss over time or due to exposure to heat—then it will be advising me and we will be making that information public and making the necessary changes.

The other matter under consideration by the Therapeutic Goods Administration is whether or not there is a need for an expiry date on sunscreen products. This is again a matter of considerable importance because there is some evidence that these products lose their potency simply by a long shelf life—maybe over a year, maybe not.

It is important to know that Australia is regarded as being at the forefront of control of sunscreens, which have been regulated as a therapeutic good since the commencement of the Therapeutic Goods Act in February 1991. Overseas, these products are generally regarded as cosmetics. Perhaps it is a measure of how important skin cancer is for Australians that we can take comfort in knowing how seriously we address it in this country.

The TGA only accepts applications for sunscreen products which are certified by applicants as complying with the test requirements of the Australian standards for sunscreens. So far, no significant evidence that sunscreens do not meet the required standard has emerged from the testing program, but in the light of this information it is a matter of great concern that we do very quickly get that examination by the TGA concluded and provide timely and current information and advice to consumers.

I think the most important advice that I can give to consumers while we are awaiting that scientific evidence from the TGA is that they check the date on which the sunscreen was actually issued. Even though consumers are buying new products, they should see whether they can measure their shelf life and buy only currently issued ones while this is still a matter for concern.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the minister not ruling out the possibility of his appointment to the High Court, I ask him whether he supports the judicial activism approach of most of the judges of the High Court in recent decisions, most notably the Mabo No. 2 decision, and whether he stands by his press release of July 1981, in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: There is much to be said for the US constitutional system of Supreme Court appointees being subject to congressional confirmation —
. . . no potential appointee of genuine competence and integrity has anything to fear from such a process.
I ask the minister whether he still stands by those statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —In previous incarnations I have written and said all sorts of things about the High Court, but I have not given a moment's thought to those issues since that time. Most of us in public life are subject from time to time to media speculation about our futures. I have been no exception. At last count, I think I had had something like five separate careers mapped out for me by the media, in each case without my having done anything at all to promote or encourage the speculation in question. I am simply not going to respond to speculative rumour of this kind, whether it is about going onto a court, or becoming president of the world, or anything else. I do not think I or anyone else should have to.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the minister: even if he is not going to the High Court, does he still stand by those two principles that I mentioned?

—My position is stated on the public record, going all the way back to my academic days, about my beliefs as to an appropriate role for the High Court, recognising the kind of institution that it is. I do not think it is a matter of the slightest degree of interest to the Senate or anybody else at this stage. I am not at all sure why Senator Ellison should be interested in finding out.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. It relates to the minister's attendance at the signing of a joint venture agreement between Ice Creameries of Australia and the Beijing Salt Corporation earlier today. Can the minister inform the Senate of what opportunities will be provided through this agreement? Are there any indications that there may be an increasing potential for Australian businesses to forge partnerships in the Chinese economy?

—Today I had the privilege to participate in a ceremony for a joint venture involving an outstanding Australian success story in small business, Ice Creameries of Australia, which 17 years ago started with one shop selling ice-cream, developed 80 shops throughout the eastern states of Australia, and has now gone international, selling the franchise for that network into China in a joint venture with a Chinese corporation. This is the sort of culture change that is now going on in Australia in small business. As small businesses respond to the fact that our economy is world competitive, they are adopting practices that make them internationally competitive and able to go and compete in the world.

PARA.TAB: The company itself, starting with an approach from the Australian government only two years ago, was able to introduce the chairman of the Australian company, Mr Atchison, who was at that time the Chairman of the Franchisors Association of Australia and New Zealand, to the Minister for Commerce in the People's Republic of China. From that discussion he was able to sign a contract today to establish this franchising arrangement whereby a number of these Australian-named stores will be operating in China from early 1994. It is a recognition by the Chinese that we have management skills in small and medium sized enterprises that are equal to the best in the world. Of course, it gives us an opportunity to get into one of the fastest expanding markets in the world.

This is a success story in small and medium sized businesses. We should celebrate that success in Australia. We should give due recognition to an outstanding achievement by a small business, by the people who own the business and by the staff and the Australian franchisees who have got together to make this venture in China work well. We look forward to the fact that, with the success of this one, other Australian franchisees and franchisors will be able to develop similar markets in Australia to improve the export potential of the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer the minister to the withdrawal of charges in the most recent war crimes trial in Adelaide, which is now the third trial in South Australia to have been abandoned or dismissed. Can the minister confirm that the total cost to the taxpayers of these three war crimes trials was $27.5 million? Is that amount consistent with the amount budgeted for these trials? What further expenditure is expected to be incurred? Can the minister indicate whether there will be any further prosecutions of South Australians for European war crimes?

—I do have some information in respect of the costs of the investigations and prosecutions. I am informed that a special investigations unit was established in May 1987 to investigate alleged war criminals. It ceased to operate on 30 June 1992. The funding of its operations over that almost five-year period totalled some $11,497,575. After its closure, some of its key personnel formed the war crimes prosecution support unit. That unit's costs from its establishment on 1 July 1992 to 30 June 1993 were $2,223,275.60. The costs of this financial year's operations are not yet known.

PARA.TAB: A team of investigators, including the director of the unit, was in the Ukraine collecting evidence when the Director of Public Prosecutions entered a nolle prosequi in the Wagner prosecution. The involvement of the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions commenced in the 1989-90 financial year and the costs of that office to the present time are $6,749,860. The best available figure for legal aid costs for the same period is some $4 1/2 million. The total costs at present, I am informed, are approximately $29 million.

I should add that, because of the mode of operation of the special investigations unit and the defence, where the same legal team represented all three defendants, it has not been possible to provide separate costings for each defendant in the prosecution under the War Crimes Act. But it can be said that the total expenditure on each defendant by the office of the DPP has been: Polyukhovich, $3.6 million; Berezowski, $1.16 million; and Wagner, close to $2 million. If there is any further information that Senator Minchin has asked for that I have not given, I will undertake to present it to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that Senator Bolkus table the document from which he just read—or is he hiding behind the cowardice of not having the courage?
—Whether or not the minister tables the document is a matter for him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recently published MLC superannuation index, and in particular to its finding that the confidence of Australians in their superannuation schemes is steadily declining. What is the minister's view of this finding?

—The MLC superannuation index is based on a periodic survey conducted for the MLC Life Office. It started in mid-1992 and it broadly measures consumer confidence in superannuation arrangements. So it is very new. The latest index level, released on 1 December, indicated a downward trend in the confidence of Australians in their superannuation arrangements. What this survey does not show is the reasons underlying this trend. MLC has indicated that it will conduct a further survey early next year to explore the reasons.

PARA.TAB: The index reported that older Australians are less confident than young people about generating sufficient savings to meet their retirement needs. The lack of time remaining to accumulate a benefit and the long-term nature of superannuation would seem to explain this result. We need to be concerned about what underlies this decline and if it measures a real change rather than just being something thrown up by the nature of this index. It is so new that we cannot be extremely confident about it at this stage.

There is another important factor to take into account. It may well be that the apparent decline in confidence in superannuation should be interpreted having regard to the fact that people are generally becoming much more aware about how much saving is necessary to generate adequate living standards in retirement. Therefore, as a consequence, more people are questioning whether their existing retirement provision will be sufficient.

There has been, particularly with the initiation of the superannuation guarantee charge but also broadly, increased debate about superannuation in the community. It is quite plausible that this has led to a change in consumer confidence in superannuation arrangements which cuts across the real change. The community has better arrangements but people are less confident of them because they are more aware of what is required in terms of savings to generate adequate living standards in retirement. So there are some pluses as well as some interesting questions in this survey. The government will be very interested in the outcome of the MLC's further inquiry.

The index reported that 55 per cent of Australians now believe that their retirement planning is inadequate. This is a positive development because it is likely to lead to an encouragement for greater self-provision for retirement income. So although on the face of it this measurement of consumer confidence is a cause for concern, it is probably more positive than negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Has the government received representations from the Norfolk Island government that it strongly protests against the extension of the Native Title Bill to Norfolk Island? Do these representations include the fact that absolutely no consultation has taken place with the Norfolk Island government over the bill? Does this failure by the federal government to consult with Norfolk Island contravene cabinet handbook guidelines? Is the government's failure to consult with Norfolk Island also at odds with the commitments given by the territory minister in March 1992 and the Attorney-General in April 1992? Given that the Native Title Bill is based on the notion of terra nullius, which has no relevance to Norfolk Island, will the government amend the bill to delete its extension to Norfolk Island?
—A good question.

—I agree that it is a very good question. I recall that when I was minister for territories I had a little to do with the administration of Norfolk Island. I was particularly careful to consult with its government all the time.
—Did you holler for a Marshall?
—No. Norfolk Island is a very long way from the Marshall Islands.
—Senator Kemp laughed at that joke. He is the only one who did.

—Senator Kemp probably would; I think that would be right. I was anxious at all times to consult with the Norfolk Island government, as I am sure the government now is. I do not want to shock Senator Calvert, but I really do not know whether the Norfolk Island government has expressed these concerns. I am deeply concerned at the ignorance that I am displaying here, but I will endeavour to find out the answer to this and the 107 other parts of the question and try to give it to Senator Calvert tomorrow.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I raise as a matter of concern your unprecedented attempt to embarrass a senator by reference to private correspondence. TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, an extraordinary slur has been mounted by Senator Hill on your entirely appropriate responses at question time. You have had nothing but assaults by Senator Ian Macdonald on your capacity to handle this place properly. You have had occasion on innumerable instances to call him to order, to bring him to heel and to get him to behave in a civilised fashion, which he seems manifestly incapable of doing.

It is entirely appropriate under those circumstances that you should have made it perfectly clear that in drawing Senator Ian Macdonald's attention to the standards required of behaviour in this chamber you should have made it particularly plain that you were talking about Senator Ian Macdonald and not Senator Sandy Macdonald.

For there to be some suggestion that in doing this you were behaving in some way that is inappropriate to the role and the dignity of the Chair in this place is an outrageous slur, one that I, and I imagine all honourable senators on this side and I hope the cross benches as well, would entirely reject. I suggest to you that there is no need whatsoever for you to respond to this extraordinary suggestion that has been put to you by Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I think there is a genuine point to be made with respect to this matter. It is the case that you receive correspondence from senators on both sides of the chamber expressing views on a variety of matters. Those senators are entitled to believe that you will treat that correspondence as in confidence. It is perfectly within your intellectual capacity to comply with any such request that is made to differentiate between Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Sandy Macdonald without revealing the contents of any letter and without revealing that you have been requested to do so by any other senator.

PARA.TAB: While I concur with what Senator Evans says about it being proper for you when calling—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans.

—I do not disagree at all with what Senator Gareth Evans says about it being proper for you to make a distinction between two senators with the same surname. The claim that is being made is that it is improper for you to say that you are doing so because you have been requested to do so by one of those senators. What that means is that if there is any embarrassing matter, any difficult matter or anything that might require some diplomacy—which heavens above you might have a chance of understanding—
—Thank you for the compliment.
—Just a slim chance. A senator will be reluctant to raise that matter with you lest next time you lose your cool in the chair and you dob that senator in.

—I will reply to the points made today. Over recent weeks there have been persistent interjections from Senator Ian Macdonald, who I believe has been ignoring the Chair when asked to cease interjecting. I have been calling `Senator Macdonald'. If that was a mistake, it is a mistake that has been pointed out to me in correspondence.

PARA.TAB: I made this statement today as a result of two things that occurred recently. The other day unparliamentary remarks were being made by Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator Collins across the chamber. I ignored them until it got to the stage where I could ignore them no longer. I called on Senator Ian Macdonald to withdraw. He then started questioning my right to rule on the things Senator Collins said. When Senator Ian Macdonald sat down I asked Senator Collins to withdraw. I did not need Senator Ian Macdonald's assistance when I was in the process of asking Senator Collins to withdraw.

The same situation occurred today. Senator Faulkner was asked to withdraw. At that time Senator Ian Macdonald then said to me, `What are going to do about Senator Ray?' It is the role of the Chair to ask Senator Ray to withdraw, which I did. What I pointed out was that I did not need Senator Ian Macdonald's assistance.

I believe I have acted completely fairly. Today on two occasions opposition members did not stand during question time and I adjusted the number of questions to try to make both sides equal. That is something that I do not have to do. I believe that I have acted properly and in accordance with the way the President of the Senate should act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Christopher Evans this day, relating to extradition procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus was asked what I consider to be a very unsavoury question with unsavoury implications by Senator Chris Evans—

TALK.START.PARA: —One gets disappointed when matters of this seriousness create mirth in members of the government. Senator Bolkus had a prepared written answer, which in my view was most unsavoury and improper and which cast most unpleasant insinuations upon the chief law enforcement officer of Western Australia. That is something that a federal minister of the Crown should not do lightly. It is certainly not something that would normally invite laughter or mirth from members of the government.

PARA.TAB: I asked Senator Bolkus, at the price of a question, to do no more than table the very words which he read in his prepared brief. I asked for no other documents. But given that Senator Bolkus was aware of the sensitivity of what he said, he declined under privilege to table the documents. Invariably, when ministers decline to table documents from which they are quoting or referring, it is on the basis of some sort of confidentiality. All I asked Senator Bolkus to do was to provide the written words. That would have allowed me and members of the opposition an opportunity to carefully read the words which Senator Bolkus used. But he chose, for sleazy political reasons—if I might use those words—not to so do. From memory, Senator Bolkus used words to this effect: `given the interest in the association between the Western Australian Attorney-General and Mr Wayne Bradshaw'. The interpretation any reasonable person would make and the impression meant to be left in the minds and the mouths of those listening was that there was some improper relationship between Dr Bradshaw and the Western Australian Attorney-General and that there was something improper about the Western Australian Attorney-General's conduct. If that is the implication, best Senator Chris Evans and Senator Bolkus stand up and say so. If they are not implying that, then let them say that as well. But to make snide, improper insinuations in such grave circumstances does nothing but reflect upon the author of the words, rather than the person to whom they are referring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne. I am not blaming Senator Chris Evans, who asked the question. But I would like to reserve my judgment until I have a good listen to the tape. My office normally runs a tape of question time. Unfortunately, my staff forgot to put it on today. But I understood—and my interpretation may be a bit different from that of Senator Crichton-Browne—Senator Bolkus to say that there would be no extradition application because of Wayne Bradshaw's friendship with Cheryl Edwardes—and Senator Bolkus could not pronounce `Edwardes'—and her husband. That is my interpretation, but I reserve my opinion until I listen to the tape. But if the interpretations made by Senator Crichton-Browne and me are correct, I think it is highly improper and I will be back in this chamber demanding a withdrawal and an apology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson this day, relating to emergency relief funding for charitable organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: In the newspapers in the past few weeks there have been repeated stories of increases in demand from charitable organisations for people in need. For example, an article in the Australian on 3 December, headed `New poor blow out the Salvos' Christmas list', reported:
The number of people seeking food and shelter provided by the Salvation Army is expected to rise by up to 70 per cent this Christmas as the recession continues to bite.
I quote from an article in the Canberra Times on 14 November headed `More folk in need than ever: charity':
A Sydney charity has recorded a 30 per cent increase in food demand this year from people in need.

PARA.TAB: The Anglican Home Mission Society launched its Christmas appeal yesterday and said in a statement that food was in greater demand than ever from the needy.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Australian in May there was another article saying that the Salvation Army needed more money. On 1 November this year the Sydney Morning Herald said:
The Smith Family is receiving more calls for help from people in the bush than ever before.

PARA.TAB: In the past 18 months, the numbers have gone up by 40 per cent . . .

SPEECH.PARA: These are not just people in the city but people in the bush. In the Age of 30 November there is an article which says that the soup kitchen in the Sacred Heart Mission in Grey Street, St Kilda is empty. When the kitchen opens, 400 people pour through the doors for meals.

PARA.TAB: We also have figures to show that those on the young homeless allowance have increased significantly, the total unemployment rate has gone up and the unemployment rate is about the same as it was this time last year—11.3 per cent last year and 11.1 per cent this year. In families with children aged nought to 14 in which neither parent is working, there has been almost no change. The number of families with children aged nought to 14, in which neither parent is working but at least one parent is looking for work, has gone up and the number of long term unemployed has gone up.

If the minister thinks that there is no increase in need between this Christmas and last Christmas, she is just joking and trying to fool the Australian public. In answer to my question she said that the emergency relief program this year had increased on its base funding from last year. Mr President, there is no intention to increase or have a special Christmas appeal at this stage. Let me tell you, Mr President, that the base funding for 1992-93 was $18.35 million.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced his scam scheme of matching dollar for dollar raised, but when the government went to sign, we saw in the fine print that it was dollar for dollar raised and spent. That amounted to about $9.9 million last year. Then he added another $2 million on to that base funding. The base funding for this year is estimated to be $17.63 million. I cannot see where it has gone up. In the previous year—1991-92—the figure was $16.3 million. So in 1991-92 it was $16.3 million. The next year the base amount was $18.35 million, with another $12 million handed out gratuitously before Christmas. This year we have an estimate of $17.6 million.

The amount of emergency relief last year came to $30.2 million, much of it given before Christmas—$12 million in Christmas appeals, including $10 million to the Christmas appeal and $2 million as a gratuitous amount given out by Mr Keating. We see a 42 per cent decrease in the emergency relief funding from last year to this year. What was the emergency last year? There is no difference between the needs of the people in the community. I have demonstrated that the need is greater. The emergency was that the Labor Party was facing an election in February or March. Santa Claus Keating—Prime Minister Keating—came out with his Christmas sack on his back on 11 December on the Sunday program and announced his scam scheme, tricking the organisation into thinking it was going to get all the money that it raised, but it had only the money that it spent during the Christmas appeal. It had to keep some money until winter to deal with people who were in great need.

What has happened? We get no funding before this Christmas because there is no election. I hope the Democrats are listening to this. This is the sort of government that we have in power. It comes in before an election and gives out $12 million in emergency relief. This year, when the need is as great, there is no money. The Australian people were duped last year before Christmas and they have been duped this year before Christmas—two Christmases in a row. The Christmas before last there was no money either.

We have not seen an increase. In fact, we have seen a 42 per cent decrease in emergency relief funding. It is an appalling situation for Australians in need. Every Australian who is struggling this Christmas will look at Mr Keating and say how two-faced he is that last Christmas he gave out money and that this Christmas there is no money for people in need in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson has got it very wrong and it is not the first time. I am afraid I did not hear all of Senator Patterson's contribution but I can understand what she was saying. It was a diatribe about how this government was concerned to make sure that families were assisted through emergency relief. She has run the argument in this place before, so one would think that she was actually opposed to providing people with emergency relief.

PARA.TAB: This year, the government has increased its funding. Senator Patterson's claim that there is no increase in funding is not right; the increase is there. What is more, Senator Patterson might be very pleased to discover that in the budget an extra $2 million was allocated to emergency relief this year and that will be provided in the December allocation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the other $10 million they got last year?

—Before Senator Patterson starts saying, `What about everything else?', why does she not just accept what I said, which completely refutes what she was saying. `There is no money; there is no increase'—Senator Patterson is wrong. A $2 million increase this year is to be provided in the December allocation.

PARA.TAB: The government has made it quite clear that its main emphasis through its budget policies is to target assistance to people in a long-term and permanent way, which is a point I was making during the answer I gave Senator Patterson. That is the main thrust of the announcements in the budget, and takes account of the fact that, despite the best intentions in the world, some people will get into an emergency—a financial or economic crisis. Such crisis is best dealt with by assistance—sometimes by payment of bills; other times by direct cash assistance to people under that emergency relief handout.

That emergency relief funding will be increased this year by $2 million and will be allocated to people at Christmas time. The government recognises that, despite the best intentions of government to make sure that people are assisted with housing and pension benefits and payments, for some reason things go wrong for some families. So there is that continuing backup of emergency relief—not the main game but a backup.

The increase of $2 million this year is over and above the increase in last year's allocation, and is allocated for payment in December. That recognises that sometimes crises occur as families try to cope with providing something for themselves at Christmas time.

If one listened to Senator Patterson, one would think that this was not a compassionate government; this was not a government that was concerned about people; this was not a government that was interested in helping people in the long term—and it is. If we allocated all assistance to people as emergency relief, Senator Patterson would be the first in here saying, `Why don't we do the more long-term thing; the more permanent thing?'. Well, we are, and the emergency relief program has been increased with a special extra budget allocation over and above the indexed arrangement for emergency relief.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been rolled.
—No, it is not wrong; it is a fact.
—Where is the $10 million you gave last year?
—Senator Patterson needs to calm down. She is asking for information and she is making claims—
—I am not calm; I am angry.

—I agree that Senator Patterson is angry and that does not help her case at all. What is more, she is making claims that are not accurate. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to make those claims accurate. I walked in here halfway through her contribution, when she was loudly insisting that this government had not increased funding for emergency relief this year. That is just not the case. It has been increased by indexation over and above the amount allocated last year. It has also had an extra allocation of $2 million in this budget, which will go to people during the December allocation for emergency relief and no doubt will be of assistance to them, both at Christmas and over the longer haul, if that is needed by those assisting people with emergency relief.

PARA.TAB: It is more important that we assist people in ongoing management of their lives and manage a targeted focus on emergency relief to back up those people. The important point, which I do not believe can be overstressed, is that this government's budget and previous budgets target families in need in general. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator MacGibbon this day, relating to the resignation of Royal Australian Air Force pilots.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner expressed injured innocence that I should ask a question about the state of resignations and the resignations that may be pending in the F111 and FA18 squadrons in the air force. I maintain that he should know that because he is the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. We are not talking about knowing what every person in the Defence Force is doing but a very small, critical group to the RAAF. There are only three fighter squadrons—Nos 3, 75 and 77—and we are talking about a pool of between 50 and 60 pilots. If we put in the two F111 squadrons—Nos 1 and 6—there maybe another 20 pilots.

PARA.TAB: It is common knowledge that the airlines have started recruiting again, particularly Cathay Pacific. I would have thought that it is quite wrong for Senator Faulkner to maintain that he has no knowledge of what is going on in the marketplace in relation to a group of pilots who are absolutely critical to the operational efficiency of the RAAF. In the latter part of the 1980s, the airlines recruited very aggressively and we lost a lot of pilots in whom the Commonwealth had invested a great deal of money in training. A pilot who has about 1,000 hours experience in an F111 or an FA18 probably represents an investment of well over $5 million for the Commonwealth. That experience cannot be replicated in a crash program.

At present, the RAAF has many pilots—it probably has its full complement of pilots—but it has a great number of very low time pilots who were recruited and trained after the mass exodus in the late 1980s. Since that time we have had budget restraints. At best these pilots in the fighter and strike squadrons are flying only 170 to 172 hours a year. With those hours they simply cannot build up the professional expertise that they need to take positions of authority in the squadron. Therefore, the few pilots that we have—who are precisely the pilots who are attractive to the airlines—have got to be retained. As I see it, the government is doing nothing to retain those pilots.

We had a very stupid scheme introduced by Mrs Kelly when she was the equivalent of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel a few years ago at the height of the pilot resignations. All that did was to place great piles of money in the hands of pilots who are never going to resign; they were the helicopter pilots who were not attractive to the airlines at all. So at the expense of public funds we retained people who were at no risk of going.

I do not ask for a repeat of that scheme. But I am alarmed that the government is not aware of the way in which the few experienced pilots we have left in those squadrons are under option and being courted by the airlines, principally Cathay Pacific. If the government does nothing to counter the blandishments of the airlines, we will lose those pilots. The air force would then be very severely restricted in its capabilities, not for five or six years but probably 15 years before that expertise is rebuilt.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to reiterate to the Senate that Senator Gareth Evans was asked twice, and perhaps a third time in a question asked by my colleague, whether he would rule out any future prospect of an appointment to the High Court. This is a very serious question which goes to the heart of the way in which this government operates. Senator Gareth Evans is in charge of the foreign affairs of this nation, certainly one of the most senior portfolios in the cabinet. In the last month or so he has been subject to speculation about two possible jobs. First, it has been alleged that he would be seeking the secretary-generalship of the United Nations; and today, we read in the press that he is holding out for himself the prospect of a job in the High Court.

PARA.TAB: I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that these are two serious issues. In relation to the first issue, I believe that there is a serious conflict of interest. Like many Australians, I happen to be very concerned about certain activities of the United Nations, particularly this government's capacity to constantly sign UN conventions and covenants which enmesh our legal system in the UN. I am quite opposed to that, but I understand that Senator Evans has a different view—and that is an intellectual argument.

But I would be exceedingly worried if Senator Evans, on a future occasion, were to seek a very senior job or the most senior job at the United Nations. There is a potential serious conflict of interest. I do not allege that Senator Evans is doing that, but it is important that that prospect be ruled out. Equally, I put that it is unsatisfactory for Senator Evans to be encouraging—and that is what he did today—speculation about a move to the High Court. Senator Evans had the chance, as I said, three times to rule out any prospect of a move to the High Court and each time he ducked the issue.

Senator Evans laid out the principles very clearly on this sort of issue some 13 years ago when he launched a vicious attack against Mr Ellicott, who at that stage was rumoured to be seeking a move towards the High Court. Senator Evans conducted a very unpleasant, vicious campaign against Mr Ellicott. He put out a press release which, among other things, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the appointment of Mr Ellicott to any position on the Court would be a deeply divisive and unhappy one for the nation. PARA.TAB: Certainly we on this side of the chamber would be very much opposed to that. I put Senator Evans on notice that he can do this chamber a favour by now ruling out—and we will give him a fourth chance to rule out—any prospect of his moving to the High Court. I urge Senator Evans to reflect heavily on the Ellicott principle, which he did so much to establish in this chamber.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned of this public petition strongly support the campaign initiated by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) subcommittee of Central America along with more than 12 representative institutions. The central objective of this campaign is: that the Australian nation play a more relevant role in the process to consolidate peace and democracy in El Salvador.

The UN Secretary General has noted that El Salvador is a model of particular importance for the peaceful resolution of internal conflicts in other parts of the world. If Civil/Democratic values are to prevail over military objectives in El Salvador then the international community, including the Australian Government, must contribute to the strengthening of Salvadoran society.

We, as individuals and as part of the Australian community in general, feel that for the first time in the history of El Salvador a real possibility exists for civil society to be the principal force of its own destiny in a truly participatory democracy.

El Salvador has a rich experience in efficient, productive, self-sustaining peasant communities, both past and present, which could be the foundation of an alternative economic structure. In order to solve existing inequalities, self-governance must be the key factor for the future.

We strongly believe that International and in particular Australian assistance at this time can contribute to long-term peace in El Salvador and to a reconciliation process based on mutual understanding between human beings. Hence, we call upon the Australian Government to:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Commence discussion with the UN Secretary General about the means by which we may become more actively involved in El Salvador, including through the provision of Australian personnel for ONUSAL, UNHCR, UNV.
2.Send an Australian Government delegation to visit El Salvador in early 1993.
3.Immediately establish a Special Humanitarian Fund (SHF) of $2,000,000 over a three-year period to be made available through Australian NGOs currently working with Salvadoran partner agencies.

PARA.TAB: We, your petitioners, therefore request the Senate to implement the above.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that

(1) One of the most critical issues to the Vietnamese people today is the persecution of their freedom of religion and expression, which has been carried out by the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) since 1945. World media reports have shown consistently that this persecution has increased greatly since 1992, when Buddhists, despite violent repression by the GOSRV's armed forces, started asking for `real' freedom of religion.

(2) The continuation of the GOSRV's centralised and corrupt structure, as well its failed and disorderly `economic renovation' and its declared loyalty to the atheistic socialism, has seriously degraded the moral, cultural, family, economic and spiritual life of most Vietnamese people.

(3) The GOSRV's policy of oppressing religions has, since 1945, applied equally to Catholics, Protestants, Caodaists, Hoa Hao Buddhist members and, most seriously, to the Unified Vietnamese Buddhist Church (UBCV) which represents the faith and spiritual life of 80% of 72 million Vietnamese.

(4) As the rightful heir of the 2000-year old Buddhist tradition in Vietnam, the UBCV was formally formed in 1951 by all Buddhist sects, lineages and regional congregations. It is the sole legitimate umbrella Buddhist body in Vietnam despite the GOSRV's unsuccessful attempt, in 1981, to disband and forcibly replace it with the State-run Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), and instrument for the GOSRV's propaganda purposes.

(5) Despite being held under strict house arrest since February 1982 simply because of his opposition to the GOSRV's attempted disbandment to the UBCV and its formation of the State-controlled VBC, the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang, a nominee for 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, has been repeatedly and patiently appealing to leaders of the Communist Party and the GOSRV to ask for:
a) the urgent restoration and legal recognition of the UBCV's independent status,
b) the separation of Church and State and the withdrawal of the GOSRV's control over, and politicisation of, the Buddhist church.
c) the release of all arrested clergy, including the Patriarch, along with thousands of other prisoners of conscience,
d) the return of, and compensation for, all confiscated and misused Church properties.
e) open negotiations, free of pre-conditions, between the leaders of the UBCV and the GOSRV to establish mutually agreed solutions to the current conflicts.

(6) In replying to these reasonable requests, the GOSRV has, in the last few months, ordered stricter surveillance of the Patriarch's place of confinement and placed bans on all of his external communications. Whoever tries to contact, visit, help or offer gifts to him are stopped, threatened, interrogated, bodily searched (and in some cases strip searched), etc. The Patriarch's straightforward appeals have not only been ignored by the Hanoi leaders, but have also been vilified as `anti-state', `reactionary', `creating division amongst Buddhist community', etc. by the GOSRV's mass media and its nation-wide agencies, including its own VBC.

(7) All of the UBCV's brave clergy and lay members, who openly declare their support for the UBCV's appeals and who have worked sincerely for the reconciliation between the State and the UBCV, also between the VBC and the UBCV, have been inhumanely and violently attacked by the GOSRV. In the last 12 months, hundreds of monks, nuns and lay persons have been arrested and/or tortured, harshly interrogated, searched, investigated and threatened. Amongst them are the Venerables Thich Nhat Lien, Thich Tri Luc and Thich Khong Tanh (Oct—Nov 1992), Thich Thien An (Oct. 1992, tortured to death few days after arrested), Thich Hai Tang, Thich Tri Tuu, Thich Hai Thinh and about 50 lay members (5/6/93), Thich Hanh Duc, 17 other monks and about one hundred of lay followers (9/7/93), etc.

(8) The GOSRV's violent attack and mass media campaign against Buddhists' appeal for Church independent have caused suffering to many thousands of people, resulting in increased instability for the whole country. Despite the GOSRV's current campaign to illogically calumniate them and to deceive the world, these monks and lay Buddhists are arrested solely because of their aspiration to be involved and support their chosen church, the UBCV.
(9) To politicise the traditional Buddhist community in Vietnam, the GOSRV has publicly been, and is:

TAB.TAB: a) recruiting members for the VBC by forcibly converting the UBCV's moderate clergy to join it, and arresting or exiling other leaders who refuse to do so. (The GOSRV's view of `religious freedom' is not in accord with natural human dignity and heritage, but a rare favour given reluctantly on the terms of the State),
b) forcing the VBC to include, in its Charter, `Socialism' as its third aim of service—the other two, which originated from UBCV Charter, are People and Buddhism,

c) creating mutual distrust and conflicts between the lay Buddhist community and their clergy or amongst the clergy themselves by appointing VBC senior leaders to artificial political positions, and by closely controlling and intervening in the limited activities it is permitted to perform training programs such as ordination procedures, seniority promotions, etc.
d) requiring the VBC to make frequent political statements supporting the GOSRV's inconsistent policies, with the consequence of eroding the VBC's religious identity.

e) directing the VBC to start a nation-wide campaign to accusing the UBCV of having political ambitions, and forcing it to declare the VBC as the `only legitimate Buddhist authority' and its `everlasting loyalty' to the GOSRV. This is whilst the GOSRV is facing huge pressure and condemnation from the international community about its oppressive attitude to the Buddhists and its systematic violation to all human rights of all non-party-cadre citizens in the country.

PARA.TAB: (10) The GOSRV's exclusively economic renovation has not, and can not, lead to democratisation or potentials which will allow long-overdue human rights to its citizens, such as freedom to select their own political aspirations, ways of expressions, religions, education, employment, place of resident, etc. The greater its economic strength, the more determined and confident the GOSRV is in its opposition to such a democratisation process and the worse its treatment of its citizens becomes. This causes ever greater social instability and a sense of total hopelessness for Vietnam's future, and more broadly, prevents the development of stability in the SE Asia region as a whole.

(11). As its history has proved, if the UBCV is completely free and independent of political intervention, it would be a most beneficial part of, and the best spiritual force to contribute to, a humanitarian and ethically orientated redevelopment process for Vietnam.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate requests the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: 1. make conditional the release of currently approved financial assistance, and any future aid, to the GOSRV, on its granting of all internationally accepted human and civil rights to its people, without discrimination. This must be demonstrated by the GOSRV through its complete cessation of persecution, in any form, of all religious organisations, particularly the UBCV.
2. urge the GOSRV to cease all ill-treatment of the UBCV, and to achieve a mutually acceptable resolution, by means of fair negotiation, of all appeals made by the UBCV's Patriarch;
3. make clear statements requesting the GOSRV:

TAB.TAB: (a) not to conduct in any further suppression of those who non-violently demonstrate their beliefs and involvement with their chosen religious organisations;

(b) immediately release all who are under arrest, with or without trials, because of their religious beliefs, including the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang and other clergy; the GOSRV should also cease their unreasonable political accusations directed towards the UBCV leaders concerning their appeals and commitment to religious freedom and the Church's independent status;

(c) completely withdraw its politicization of religion obstinate and its gross intervention in the internal affairs of religious bodies such as supporting the VBC whilst inhumanely oppressing the UBCV or by using the official mass media to create staged scenes dishonouring and defaming holders of religious authorities.

(2)It is appropriate for children of both sexes to have access to a variety of toys and activities. It is totally inappropriate for a teacher to demand that a child follow, not his/her own preferences when it comes to choosing these toys/activities, but instead follow a preset agenda designed to eliminate the differences between the sexes. Equality of the sexes does not equate to bland uniformity between the sexes. In fact, the differences between the sexes are complimentary and need to be appreciated as such.

Christmas is not a pagan festival but a Christian celebration of the birth of Jesus Christ. The singing or playing of carols/songs with their message of `peace on earth and good will to all mankind' is a vital aspect of the celebration of Christmas and promotes cross-cultural unity not division. (4)It is reprehensible for the Federal Government to undermine the professionalism of trained childcare teachers/workers through these dictatorial guidelines and to attempt to control in this way the reading material, toys/activities, songs and disciplinary procedures used in these centres.

SPEECH.PARA: We have before the Senate a report from NBEET on credit transfer and related issues. I would like to note initially, as I have done with previous reports from NBEET, that the timing of this report seems very strange. The letter at the front of this report was written on 27 October and yet here we are in the middle of December receiving this report in parliament. One wonders why it takes seven weeks to get this report through. I believe the reporting date is 15 parliamentary days and that is exactly what we have. It amazes me that this lands in parliament in the last week of sittings. The Senate will recall that this happened before when we had a huge number of education reports come in at the end of the parliamentary sittings. I wait eagerly for Thursday to see if the same thing happens again.

PARA.TAB: This report draws attention to a very important area of education that deserves better treatment than it receives with this reporting program. Credit transfer refers to a system where students who have prior learning in a particular area are given credit for that when they move on to another area. Such a development is most welcome. We have a very sorry history in this country of not recognising prior learning properly. Certainly for many years we have been way behind the sort of credit given in countries like the United States.

Fortunately, we have moved a very long way from the 1940s when the University of Sydney would not recognise anything from the University of New England which was a college of the University of Sydney that had broken away to become an independent university. Thank heavens that sort of academic snobbery is behind us.

In the 1960s we found examples of students being severely disadvantaged because there was not proper credit transfer between courses. My sister-in-law had completed eight-ninths of a degree at the University of New South Wales in the mid-1960s when she transferred with her husband to New Guinea and studied through the University of Queensland. That university recognised only four-ninths of the degree so she lost half of the degree and had to do all that work over again. That is no encouragement for people to go on to study for higher awards.

Fortunately in the 1990s we are recognising and trying to create greater articulation, not only between universities but also between different levels of education. There have been considerable problems in developing articulation between TAFEs and universities. These are slowly being overcome and again there is the academic snobbery issue. There are also some very real issues in terms of the standard reached in various courses. It is good to see that the different levels of education are now cooperating to overcome that sort of problem.
A Senate committee looked at this issue a few years ago. There also seems to be great progress. The new direction in credit transfer is the recognition of informal learning before people come in.

It is surprising that in this report there is an emphasis on moving in that direction. The report seems to be indicating that most of these sorts of problems have been addressed. On page six of the report, the recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising that the continuing momentum of credit transfer through recognition of formal prior learning is becoming well established, the National Board recommends:

I think that is a little premature. We certainly have not solved all the problems. A consultative forum met in 1993 to consider some of these problems that still exist. At the forum it was pointed out that there is still not universal support for credit transfer arrangements. The industry representatives perceived that there was a lack of progress and that in some areas things could be made a lot clearer and articulation between courses could work far more effectively.

PARA.TAB: One of the big problems they had was the issue of assessment of prior learning and who pays for that assessment. Certainly as more students come in from adult and community education they will need mastery tests and a whole series of other expensive systems to work out whether they are appropriate to come into a particular course. This move towards credit transfer is most welcome. I recommend the report to the Senate. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
