The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 20 of 1993-94: Efficiency audit—Northern Land Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a most fundamental and important report. It is also very timely that it has been tabled here today before the Senate proceeds later this day to the debate on the Native Title Bill. Implications arise from this report that should be measured in the detailed consideration that the Senate will be giving to the important issue of land administration. I am sure that all senators are very well aware that the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory has been in existence since 1976. In that period, a lot of the operation and day-to-day administration of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act has been very satisfactory, but there has also been a lot to be critical of and a lot of criticism. This report is, as I said, very fundamental to the accountability, scrutiny and criticism that is so vital and so necessary.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General has made 52 recommendations on a wide range of issues that were drawn to his attention. Most of the issues arise from details that I put on the agenda back in the estimates considerations earlier this year. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, followed up that matter at that time by commissioning this very important consideration. I commend the minister for the terms of reference that he extended to this audit.

At the same time, the report must be read in parallel with two other very significant reports to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, particularly its Office of Evaluation and Audit. Two reports of May 1993 and September 1993 by Walter and Turnbull deal with the management of the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. I must address a couple of points in those reports before proceeding to the Auditor-General's report.

In the Walter and Turnbull report that was tabled here in the last month or so, some very fundamental points were made with regard to the depletion of funds in the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account. Under the cash flows for the period 1989 to 1993, the ABTA funds peaked at $33.7 million in 1992, based on balances at 30 June, and this dramatically declined to $23.6 million at 30 June 1993. That is a depletion of $10 million.

Walter and Turnbull went on to draw our attention to the deteriorations in the fund and the various distributions that were totally out of whack by any consideration. They made the point that section 64(7) distributions have averaged 47 per cent of the available 30 per cent of royalty equivalent income from 1984 to 1993. For 1993 the percentage was 155 per cent of the available royalty income. The combined average level of distributions for 1989 to 1993 have been 134 per cent of the 30 per cent royalty equivalent income for the same period, and this has been the cause of the diminution of the fund. Similarly, land council estimates of expenditure have certainly outgrown the CPI increases. It was important that Walter and Turnbull in their report, whilst addressing many other issues, drew attention to the fact that `a major review of the mechanisms of funding and clarification of the provisions of the ALRA Act probably by amendments is overdue'.

I turn now to the Auditor-General's report that has been tabled today. I am sure Minister Tickner now feels that his fingers have been cut off and that he is getting pretty close to having his head chopped off. There is a degree of ministerial responsibility that Mr Tickner must take into account in respect of the issues that have now been addressed by this report, particularly the exercise of his delegation of authority to staff members in ATSIC with regard to the distribution of funds. The minister himself must be accountable and must accept full responsibility in that area. I notice that one of the principal officers who was involved at the time I raised these issues back in March—Mr Castine, who was then the regional manager for ATSIC in the Northern Territory—has since disappeared from the scene; he has resigned, been pushed or whatever.

I now turn to the report in detail. As I said initially, there were 52 subsequent recommendations. We must not take one part of the report and isolate it. We must put it together and look at it. If we do that, we will see very clearly that it is a very severe and savage criticism of very poor, and in fact rotten and lousy administration. I am going to call for either the removal or the resignation of two particular people from any office of the crown. One is the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Mr Galarrwuy Yunupingu, and I will come to the particular issues that have been found in this report against Mr Yunupingu.

The second person whose administration I want to call into question is the current occupant of the position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, Mr Mick Dodson. Mr Dodson was the Director of the Northern Land Council for the entire period that is under review by this report. By any measure, I cannot see how the government can have any confidence or any faith whatsoever in Mr Dodson as a result of this report. He should resign from any public office or the government must remove him.

The precedents that have been set out in this report require very careful consideration. The minister set out seven terms of reference for this inquiry. They are royalty trust account administration, advances to council members of the Northern Land Council, the fringe benefits tax arrangements, the use and engagement of consultants, the control of expenditure, the distribution of surpluses, and scope for other improvements in administration. On each and every one of those particular terms of reference, the Northern Land Council has been found to be far from satisfactory and, in fact, under very serious criticism.

The area of royalty trust accounts worries me particularly. This is similar to a solicitor's trust account that each and every one of us might want to rely on—the degree of fiduciary duty to the people who are the owners of those trust funds that have been dissipated. It is not just the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account that I mentioned, where $10 million went walkabout. This is the trust account for the day-to-day operation of all of the communities and groups of Aboriginal people throughout the Northern Territory whose income and royalties are derived from many areas.

This report has found some very unsatisfactory and very poor systems and procedures. In fact, the audit office could not track a clear audit trail to get its hands on much of the accountability that was necessary. The accounting database was not adequate for any efficient and effective measuring of those royalty trust accounts.
I want to make my first point about Mr Yunupingu. I draw attention to the following statement at 3.12 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Gumatj Galupa Association, which receives mining royalty equivalents, was often paid advances on those mining royalty equivalents from NLC funds. In 1992-93 a total of $27,124.96 was advanced to the Association from NLC administrative funds prior to the receipt of mining royalty equivalent moneys by the NLC.
Further on, the report notes:
There was no evidence that other royalty associations had received similar advances of their mining royalty equivalents.
Very clearly, the chairman misused his position and directed funds to his own particular advantage.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I turn to the issue of the advances to council members. The Auditor-General found that these were made against the resolutions of the council itself. He refers to the way in which funds and payments were made, particularly the payments to the Chairman of the Northern Land Council, Mr Yunupingu. Paragraph 4.7 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It has also been the practice of the NLC to advance moneys to the Chairman. These advances include cash advances and payments of personal credit card accounts for travel and accommodation on council business as well as for private purchases.
Further on, it states:

Since June 1992 the Chairman has been indebted to the NLC for amounts of up to approximately $23 200 for advances and credit card payments. The Chairman's account frequently remained outstanding for lengthy periods of time.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the term of reference which the Auditor-General euphemistically entitles `flexible remuneration packages'. SPEECH.PARA: Consultancy objectives or tasks were not well defined . . .
. . . objectives were very general
the required outcome of the consultancy was not specified, or
there was little justification of the need for the work and, in some cases, reference to related work being undertaken by other consultants
internal approval procedures were not adhered to . . .
claimed expenses were not documented . . .

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General refers to the underestimation of project costs; the unforeseen expenditure on land claims; the expectation among project coordinators that estimates would be restored in the additional estimates process later in the financial year; project coordinators being slow to advise the accountant; and significant variations between recorded commitments and invoices rendered. With regard to the distribution of surpluses, over a period of years under Mr Dodson's control the Northern Land Council very cunningly used the surpluses that arose from a particular year to buy shares in a company which it had no legal right to go into. Paragraph 8.49 points out:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . staff of the NLC are entitled to recreation leave return airfares to Adelaide for themselves and their dependents residing with them.

This is allowed on an annual basis, contrary to government guidelines and there are no acquittal requirements. What do they do? They turn up, get a cheque, probably go to the bay around the corner and not south, and pick up thousands of dollars. That is totally unsatisfactory.

PARA.TAB: In the area of motor vehicle misuse, there are some damning indictments in this report. The Auditor-General goes on to make a number of very important recommendations.

As I have said, this is a damning indictment of the minister for political control; of the chairman for his lack of personal responsibility, and for that reason he must go; and for the former director who now holds a much more senior office under this government of social justice commissioner, and he must go. Dodson must bear the full responsibility for the need for all 52 recommendations arising from this report. The import of this, particularly the hide of Mr Dodson who has been running an international agenda with regard to indigenous people and with regard to the Native Title Bill, is of fundamental importance. This report is dramatic. If the government does not respond to it in the debate on native title, I will certainly pursue the issue to make sure that the principles that the Auditor-General has now recommended will flow on and will be met in the Native Title Bill.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 21 of 1993-94: Efficiency Audit—Department of Finance—Australian government credit card—its debits and credits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress at the outset that the Auditor-General's report No. 21, entitled Australian government credit card—its debits and credits, is a very important report. We have already had a foretaste of much of it through the leaks—or the early release—of it in the media last week. The report confirms many of the things that were made public last week but presents them in much more detail. Time is very brief so I will just take a few minutes to raise some of the matters that I think are the most important. The report raises very grave concerns about the effectiveness, efficiency and appropriateness of the usage of government credit cards by public servants.

PARA.TAB: You will recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the Australian government credit card was introduced in 1987 following investigation and report by the Block committee. This Auditor-General's report examines the use of the AGCC in various departments and is the first comprehensive review that has been undertaken since the introduction of the credit card.
The report highlights several major deficiencies which require attention. For example, the report states:
The original intention was that the AGCC would be used to pay minor claims typically under $1000, yet out of $418m expended with the AGCC in 1992-93, ANAO estimates $283m—

SPEECH.PARA: which is 68 per cent of the total—
involved transactions in excess of $1000.
The report gives numerous other examples. It states:
. . . where one Commonwealth agency pays another by means of credit card thereby incurring a fee for what should be a simple funds transfer.
Again, that is a very inefficient, incompetent and wrongful use of the credit card. The report also states:

PARA.TAB: Departments were unable to identify to what use the AGCC is put or what advantages or disadvantages accrue from different patterns of use . . . Nor can departmental management monitor expenditure trends associated with card usage or payment mode.
ANAO concluded that many of the benefits claimed for the AGCC when it was established did not eventuate.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons it is therefore somewhat surprising to me that the audit office has supported the continued and appropriate use of the credit card arrangements, and I will come to some other reasons in a moment. This is despite the fact that the card is not widely used across the Commonwealth. Page 31 of the report states:
-9% of AGCC holders accounted for 77% of expenditure
-26% of AGCC holders do not use their cards
-one department is responsible for 62% of AGCC expenditure, and
-3 agencies account for 63% of AGCC transactions.
The credit card is not broadly used, but it is certainly very heavily used by the few departments or agencies that do. The report also states:

PARA.TAB: There are instances of purchases of capital items, such as speed boats and ancillary parts for missile launchers, using the AGCC.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the credit cards were never intended to be used for these types of items. Indeed, if one takes the time to read the report, page four contains a couple of photographs of people who are very heavily covered with gear. The caption accompanying the photographs reads:
During 1992-93, bomb suits and accessories to the value $893 000 were paid for with the AGCC.
That is absolutely crazy! It is a ridiculous and wrongful use.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was for the Prime Minister to wear to a public rally.

—As my friend Senator Campbell says, the Prime Minister probably needed it. He will probably need a lot more in the future the way this government is going. It is a ridiculous and quite wrongful use of the credit card. It is important to point out that the Auditor-General in his report found:

PARA.TAB: The level of reported fraud identified was very low.

SPEECH.PARA: He then goes on to make this important point:

However, the full extent of fraud on the AGCC is not known because of inadequate control systems and ineffective reporting of fraud and misuse. The audit found 25 cases of fraud reported since 1987 with an approximate value of $400 000.

It is quite clear that that is very likely to be a major underestimate of the fraud. It is an indictment of the departments that they do not have proper control and monitoring systems in place to ensure that we do have a reasonable fix on what the real situation is. It raises quite fundamental questions about accountability and the potential for misuse.

PARA.TAB: It is of serious concern that this report follows hot on the heels of not only Auditor-General's report No. 20, which was also tabled today and to which Senator Tambling spoke so passionately and eloquently in raising such a matter of major concern, but also last week's Auditor-General's report on performance pay in the Australian Public Service and on inadequate dealing with under-performing Public Service officers. Taken together, these reports give the impression—rightly or wrongly—that the Public Service has some major problems which are costing Australian taxpayers a not inconsiderable amount of money. For example, in last week's report on performance pay in the Public Service, it was pointed out that more than $52 million was involved just in the administration of the performance pay scheme, let alone the additional payments which are often made for quite unjustified reasons.

It is about time that this Labor government began paying a lot more attention to the way it runs and administers government. With every passing day we glean more evidence of the massive and wildly costly incompetence of this government, in terms of both policy making and straight administration. This Auditor-General's report is just one example—but it is a classic example—of this fact, which I am sure will not be lost on the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General's report No. 21 of 1993-94, entitled Australian government credit card—its debits and credits, which Senator Short has just referred to, is an alarming report. As he said, we were given an early taste of the report because of some leaking last week. However, our worst fears have been more than confirmed by the actual report itself. Senator Short has gone through some of the detail in it and I will seek to cover some other points.

PARA.TAB: What we need to understand is that not only does this report follow on from the inquiries into the performance based pay scheme and the inadequate dealing with under-performing officers, where it was revealed last week that one non-performing officer had cost a department $300,000 to go through the procedures related to inefficiency, but also this report follows on from the one which was tabled a couple of weeks ago—which the people of Australia have yet to forget and I hope should never forget—on the inefficiency, maladministration and financial mismanagement of the sports rorts affair by Minister Kelly. I cannot believe that she is actually still a minister. What all of these reports show the Australian people is that no-one is responsible any more.

This Auditor-General's report contains pages of evidence relating to what should have been an efficient scheme for government purchasing that has run amuck over six years. No-one has reviewed the scheme to see whether or not it is working properly. When I asked Senator McMullan last week what he was going to do about it, he had a very carefully prepared brief which said that if anyone was found to be misusing the system they would be fined $20,000 or put in gaol. That is all very well, but the trouble is that over the last few months we have seen evidence that no checks have been made to see whether fraud has taken place or whether anyone is misusing the scheme. As Senator Short said, the Auditor-General's report states quite clearly that we cannot assess what fraud has taken place within this system because no-one knows what is going on.

One of the most alarming statements made by the Auditor-General early on in the report was that `There was no understanding of how the AGCC was used'. That lack of understanding was by the departments that use the card. In other words, we have 16,000 credit cards, some of which have credit limits of $2 million every month. So that is a $24 million per annum credit limit running around the country in the hands of some 16,000 Australian public servants who have very little understanding of how they are used.

The report highlights the fact that most of the people using the credit cards have had insufficient training. In ATSIC, which was just referred to in another report, there was absolutely no training in the use of the credit cards. The better example, of course, is that of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services, where training has been 100 per cent effective. But there are other departments that use the card quite regularly, such as Defence, where the training is less than adequate.
To quote the Auditor-General's words, the report highlights some interesting expenditure on things like:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . chocolates, electricity generation and distribution—
I ask honourable senators to envisage how a credit card could be used to pay for electricity generation and distribution—
floor coverings, flowers—
that reminds us of the Tax Department revelations—
gas production and distribution, guns and ammunition, licensed clubs, lingerie—
an interesting expenditure—
. . . mens and ladies fashion clothing, musical instruments—
just to mention a few. Many Australian taxpayers' minds would boggle as to why credit cards, being paid for by the taxpayers, would be used on many of these items.

PARA.TAB: One of the more serious concerns of the opposition, which it shares with the Auditor-General, is the cost of using the credit cards. Originally, the scheme was introduced back in 1987 as a way of reducing paperwork and transactions costs and, therefore, saving taxpayers' money.

All honourable senators would recall what used to happen a few years ago. A box of paper clips or something like that might cost $20, but with all the red tape that is involved in purchasing something for the Commonwealth or state governments, such as filling in requisition orders, issuing the cheque and having it cross-checked by half a dozen under deputy secretaries and assistants, the cost of purchasing the box of paper clips might be $60 when it should have been only $20.

There is no doubt in anyone's mind that if we have a credit card system that has proper accountability, proper checks and proper audit trails, purchasing a box of paper clips for $20 using that system would be much more efficient. So the opposition does not oppose the use of a credit card system; indeed, we support it. However, we must learn from the alarm bells that the Auditor-General is ringing and make sure that we put in place adequate controls, checks, scrutiny and substantiation of all these expenditures.

As Senator Short said, the original system was designed for purchases of less than $1,000. Indeed, what we have had are examples of expenditures well in excess of that. In fact, in the period between 23 March and 27 June this year, when the trial was run, there were 3,647 transactions in excess of $5,000. I remind the Senate: for a scheme that was designed and devised to expedite and make more efficient purchases of less than $1,000, there were 3,647 individual transactions in excess of $5,000 just in three months of the last financial year. These transactions represented something like 44 per cent of all expenditure on credit cards. So nearly half of all these expenditures was way in excess, more than five times in excess, of the guidelines.

As Senator Short said, there was one interesting purchase where a credit card was used to buy a bomb suit for $893,000. The cost of these transactions is an important point. If the credit card system is used wisely, it will save the taxpayer money. In the case of the bomb suit, the cost of the transaction, including the minimum transaction fee, which is an added expense of using a credit card, was $11,603. The government actually pays that sooner or later, even though it is a charge that the bank puts on the supplier of the goods.

A sensible purchasing officer who wanted to buy a bomb suit would go to the suppliers of the bomb suit—which is nearly $1 million worth of expenditure, just under $900,000 dollars—and negotiate with them. I think any of us would do that if we were using our own money to buy ourselves a bomb suit. Of course, if we had the choice of paying that supplier by cheque or electronic funds transfer or credit card and the supplier knew that the credit card would cost him something like $11,000 in servicing fees, it is not silly to assume that if we were to use an alternative purchasing method we could probably negotiate the price of the bomb suit down by somewhere in the vicinity of $10,000 or $11,000. This is a fact that the Auditor-General highlights.

We understand—and it is understandable—that public servants are probably frustrated by the process that one would need to go through to get expenditures on these sorts of items approved. If a public servant needs to buy himself a bomb suit and he has a credit card that has a $2 million a month limit on it, it is probably a lot quicker to use the credit card.

One of the other major concerns—and I will restrict my remarks because we have a long week ahead of us, and my Whip has just given me the wind-up signal already—is the potential for fraud. Senator Short referred to the fact that only a few cases of fraud have been detected. They are very hard for the Auditor-General to pinpoint because of the incredible lack of scrutiny of expenditure; there could be fraud going on all around the place and we would not know about it.
The report deals with the use of credit cards for personal use. On page 94 under section 30.6, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Examples have come to notice where a cardholder has used the AGCC for private purposes. This has been reported by the cardholder shortly afterwards, accompanied by payment for the private expense. Alarmingly, the attitude of those cardholders and, indeed, that of the management of their agencies, sometimes appears to be that this is tolerable as the Commonwealth is not out of pocket and the cardholder has reported the matter.

This is a serious matter of concern because, in that case to which I have just referred, the cardholder was honest. He turned up on the Monday morning and said, `I spent some money on some private use over the weekend, and here is the money', so the Commonwealth is not out of pocket. For every one of those honest people, there are probably a couple of others who use the card for private use and no-one ever finds out. The trouble with this situation is that one of the other uses of the card is for cash withdrawals, which is explicitly against a number of guidelines and generally discouraged.

PARA.TAB: We see from the Auditor-General's report that, in the last financial year, there were cash transactions and cash withdrawals in excess of $500,000. The mind boggles to think of holders of Commonwealth government credit cards going to handy tellers and withdrawing hundreds of dollars. The average transaction was actually $600 for these credit cards.

Many of them, I am sure, were for proper purposes and would have been properly accounted for. But the Australian taxpayer needs to know that all of that expenditure is being properly acquitted and properly substantiated. I suggest that we are inviting fraud. I am sure that 99 per cent of public servants are totally honest, decent human beings who serve the Commonwealth in the best possible way they know how. But, when we give 16,000 Australian citizens a credit card on which there is a limit of up to $2 million and allow them to get cash out of the handy tellers—there is no bar on it; they have the plastic in their pockets and, if they want to go and get the cash, they can get it—we are inviting fraud; we are saying, `Here, come and get me'.

I conclude by saying that there is international experience in this area which the Auditor-General has analysed. The federal government of the United States has a similar scheme; however, it has much stricter guidelines. The use of the card is better controlled and the average transactions are a hell of a lot lower than the average in Australia. The holders of those cards generally stick to using them for small purchases of less than $1,000. Also, there is a bar on those cards for cash withdrawals, which is one of the opposition's serious concerns with this report—they just cannot get cash, even if they want it. The Americans also have a far better system of scrutiny of expenditure.

This report is a very detailed one. With the renegotiation of the Australian Government Corporate Card coming up in June 1994, it is extremely timely that the taxpayers of Australia, the Department of Finance and the relevant sections of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services have this report when reviewing a system that has been in place for six years. It is quite incredible to think that this scheme has been in place for six years and only now do we have a review of it.

But, again, this is indicative of some of the problems that are being experienced with this general devolution process. I believe that devolution in concept can be very good, as long as that devolution does not mean that in the process we dissolve responsibility, as opposed to devolving it. One of the problems we have here is that no-one in this parliament seems to be held responsible when these schemes muck up. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) will not take any responsibility for the maladministration and financial mismanagement, let alone the blatant, corrupt pork-barrelling, which has taken place during the sports rorts affair.

Either the Minister for Finance or the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, or both, should at least take responsibility for what has taken place in respect of the Australian government credit card. If they will not take responsibility for what has taken place over the last six years, they should take responsibility for fixing it up and bringing back accountability. Someone has to take responsibility.

I would like to see Mr Willis get up in the other place and say, `We are going to fix this. This is what we are going to do'. But in response to this report, the Department of Finance has basically said, `We just want some modest changes'. This report demands sweeping change to purchasing. It does not require fiddling at the edges; it requires a lot more accountability, checking and scrutiny to ensure that Australian taxpayers know that their money is not being wasted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of comments on the same report, principally because, as chairman of the opposition's waste watch committee of which Senator Campbell is a member, from time to time I come across very extravagant and bizarre waste of public moneys. But I must say that, looking through this report, the potential for misuse of funds on all sorts of things is quite incredible.

PARA.TAB: I think this report and the report that was presented earlier this afternoon certainly strengthen the case for the Auditor-General and the Australian National Audit Office to be retained. Perhaps some of those on the other side who have been critical of the Auditor-General and seek to dilute his authority should think again after seeing what he is bringing forward to the parliament.

As Senator Campbell said, the Australian Federal Police Association, in its submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, said in regard to the level of fraud in the Commonwealth, `The simple fact is that we just do not know'. When this credit card system was set up, the government thought it was going to save money. But one should look at some of the facts that the Auditor-General has uncovered. If one believes that it is cheaper to use credit cards than cheques, one should look at this case: $354,000 was spent for the purchase of 202 containers. This generated a merchant services fee of something like $4,606, whereas the cost of paying by cheque would have been $12.60. One has to start asking oneself what this really is all about.

The potential to rort the system has been highlighted in this report. For instance, take the travel and hospitality area. The report instances the case of a traveller who received a cash advance for his travel allowance and then payed his hotel and restaurant bills with a credit card. In other words, he is double dipping. What took my eye was that part of the report in which the Auditor-General identified particular areas. I note that nothing was spent on undertakers, cemeteries and crematoriums; nor was anything spent on massage parlours.

But I note that there were two transactions for men's hairdressing totalling $155 and seven transactions for women's hairdressing totalling $2,631. One would have to ask: for what reason would any Commonwealth public servant use credit cards for nine transactions totalling something like $2,786 for men's and women's hairdressing? It is just quite bizarre.

Other areas include doctors, dentists and camping equipment. As Senator Campbell said, the potential for fraud in these areas by using credit cards is quite immense. The figure for cafes and restaurants is $295,000; licensed hotels, $1.4 million; and private hotels, motels and other accommodation, $2.1 million. It is a damning report of more and more government waste and potential government waste. I hope that, as a result of this, potential fraud within our Public Service is looked at once again and that proper arrangements are put in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is an agreement between the parties that speeches in relation to the tabling of this report will be incorporated. I present the third report of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech read as follows—

From 1 May 1992 Victoria's Kirner government refinanced $1.267 billion in existing debt by converting it from a short-term borrowing within the public account to a medium-term borrowing from the private sector. In so doing, the Kirner government breached by that amount the 1991-92 global limit for new borrowing that had been set by the Australian Loan Council.

The Kirner government did not promptly advise either the Commonwealth government or the Loan Council about this refinancing. The Commonwealth was not informed until 17 June and the matter deliberately was not raised by Victoria at the Loan Council meeting on 12 June 1992.

There followed a period of more than three months during which this breach of Victoria's Loan Council global limit was not divulged either by Victoria or the Commonwealth. While the refinancing was referred to in the report State Finance Victoria released on 23 September 1992, it was not until after the Victorian State election (on 3 October 1992) that the new Victorian government made public on 26 October that the global limit had been breached. Significantly, the refinancing was not revealed by the Commonwealth Treasurer (who is also Chairman of the Loan Council) in the 1992 Federal Budget papers.

Although the Commonwealth Treasury has argued that the Victorian refinancing needed to remain undisclosed so as not to precipitate an adverse reaction in the financial market, there are reasons to believe that the market had already made a suitable assessment of Victoria's overall position. From the perspective of the then Labor governments in Victoria and Canberra, the imperative for non-disclosure undoubtedly was the imminent state election, if not the federal election due in the new year.

Crucially, then, the events surrounding Victoria's breach of its Loan Council arrangements in mid-1992 demonstrate that executive governments, both Federal and State, can act to conceal financial decisions taken contrary to, not only formal commitments, but the national interest. While being significant in its own right, Victoria's breach of its 1991-92 global limit draws attention to a range of issues that deserve to be addressed and remedied.

The first of these issues is accountability. The Financial Agreement under which the Loan Council was established does not specify ways in which the Council and its individual members should be accountable. Even the most recent proposals for reforming the Loan Council (announced in December 1992 and July 1993), while advocating accountability to the markets, do not propose accountability to parliaments. The Committee inquiry has established that it has been a major shortcoming of the Loan Council process not to have established clear conventions where the Council and its members are accountable to parliaments specifically for decisions taken in that forum.

The second significant issue is the reporting of borrowing activity that is subject to Loan Council scrutiny and decision making. While the recent reform proposals provide for quarterly reporting to Loan Council on a uniform basis and an annual Financial Statement, they do not require that annual reports from the Loan Council be presented to parliaments. On this issue the Committee concluded that each jurisdiction under the Loan Council should present a report annually to its parliament. The Loan Council would present a consolidated report to the Commonwealth Parliament, this report also being tabled in the parliaments of all Loan Council jurisdictions.

The third issue is closely associated with both the first and second—the auditing of reports to Loan Council and to parliaments. It was clear from the Select Committee inquiry that Auditors-General need to audit such reports and that the consolidated report presented to the Commonwealth Parliament and tabled in the parliaments of all Loan Council jurisdictions also must be audited. Without auditing, neither parliaments nor the Loan Council could have confidence in the information with which they were being presented. And given that adequate reporting is of major significance, the Loan Council must be capable of monitoring comprehensively the information with which it is provided.

Fourth, and as importantly as any other issue, the inquiry confirmed that numerous changes are required to the Financial Agreement (currently being redrafted). These changes must also be contained in legislation complementary to the redrafted Financial Agreement. They should cover each of the major issues to which I have already referred and others associated with them:
-the requirements with regard to Commonwealth and State parliaments to ensure Loan Council accountability;
-quarterly reporting and annual financial statements as already agreed by Loan Council;
-the adoption of accrual accounting;
-full auditing of relevant Loan Council statements by Auditors-General;
-annual reports by all Loan Council jurisdictions to their parliaments, such reports to include the audit reports of relevant Auditors-General;
-a coordinated Loan Council annual report (audited by the Commonwealth Auditor-General) covering all jurisdictions to be tabled in all parliaments; and
-Auditors-General to review annually their auditing practices at their regular meetings to ensure uniformity of approach.

Clearly, if these initiatives are enshrined in a redrafted Financial Agreement and established in complementary legislation, then reform of the Loan Council and its processes will be considerably enhanced.

The Committee's recommendations for reform of the Loan Council, honourable Senators will be aware, have not been achieved without considerable controversy about the inquiry. Some have gone so far as to describe it as a `political witch-hunt' because the circumstances of Victoria's breach of its global limit were considered in detail. Of course, the inquiry was anything but a `witch-hunt'; the Committee's conclusions and recommendations that propose comprehensive reform of the Loan Council bear testimony to that.

By the same token, it is regrettable that a number of persons invited to give evidence to the Committee did not cooperate. They include the Federal Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, and the former Victorian Premier Mrs Joan Kirner. Nevertheless the inquiry was most successful in hearing from a more than adequate range of witnesses as was pointed out in the dissent to the Second Report by Government Committee members. SPEECH.PARA: The Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council was established following major public concern over the disclosure of the Victorian Kirner Labor Government's massive breach of its Loan Council borrowing limits.

The $1.267 billion transaction occurred on 1 May 1992. It was not publicly revealed until 26 October 1992, when the new Victorian Treasurer, Mr Stockdale, made it public following the election of the Kennett Government on 3 October 1992.

The deceit and complicity of the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, in this matter became apparent during the hearings. Treasurer Dawkins never revealed the breach publicly and instead took part in an elaborate concealment of the fact. Page 67 of the final report confirms the interim report's findings in March 1993 that "the Committee believes that the Treasurer's actions had the effect of concealing a major breach of financial discipline from the public, who had a right to know the truth.".
Also of note on page 67 is the following question posed by the Committee, but unable to be answered adequately.

"Given that he was advised of the Victorian breach on 6 July 1992, why did Mr Dawkins not make the Victorian borrowing explicit in the 1992-93 Budget papers, indicating that a breach of Loan Council limits had taken place ?"

The only conclusion that can be drawn from this is that Treasurer Dawkins acted to protect the Kirner Labor Government from public criticism, as they were due to face a State election in the near future. That election occurred on 3 October 1992 and saw the Kirner Labor Government comprehensively defeated, largely as a result of its financial mismanagement and incompetence.

The fact was that Treasurer Dawkins was advised of the breach at the latest on 6 July 1992, when he was fully briefed, (Commonwealth Treasury was officially informed by Victorian Treasury as far back as 17 June 1992) yet neither said, nor did, anything publicly, and apparently little privately, about this massive breach (described by the Committee as "the most significant and public undermining of the Loan Council's procedures in its history") until it was announced by Mr Stockdale at the end of October 1992.

The refusal of the main political participants—i.e Treasurer Dawkins, then Victorian Premier Kirner and then Victorian Treasurer Sheehan—in the breach and its subsequent concealment, to give evidence to the Committee can only heighten speculation that they had something to hide in a party politically inspired manner.

The events of 1992 dubbed the "Victorian Loans Affair" were important considerations for the Coalition Senators in arriving at the conclusions and recommendations in the report. Our Minority Report contains some qualifications to the main report itself, but does not seek to lessen the final chapter, 8, in particular. Those recommendations are essentially about reducing the opportunity for political cover ups, like the Victoria Loans Affair in 1992, and increasing disclosure, accountability, and the integrity of the Loan Council system. They are practical worthwhile proposals which would undoubtedly be of benefit to the Australian public.
The work of this Select Committee is further evidence of the fundamental role the Senate has to play in monitoring and curbing the incompetences and the excesses of executive governments.

SPEECH.PARA: In the interests of securing the passage of major legislative packages through the Senate this week, I intend being brief on what has been a long over-due end to this committee's deliberations.

We have now had 3 reports to the Senate and quite a number of minority reports. As opposed to the long winded debate on the I.R. bill, I am pleased that senators opposite have shown some restraint in debate on this report and refrained from simply restating old arguments which have been canvassed in previous reports by incorporating their speeches in Hansard.
In addressing this report I wish to make a number of things clear:

PARA.TAB: The Loans Council is a voluntary entity, it can only operate effectively if its participants respect the sovereignty of the other governments and enjoy some confidentiality in regard to the detailed discussions which occur.
In the view of government senators, much if this committee's work has been a waste of time as all substantive issues were addressed in the 1992 and July 1993 Loans Council reforms.

In spite of the fact that Victoria does not appear in the inquiry's terms of reference, much of the committee's time has been wasted on an opposition witch hunt which has produced no new information about events in Victoria in 1992—what is known is that there was no illegality on the part of the then Victorian Labor government.

The Treasurer Mr Dawkins has been totally exonerated from accusations of any wrong doing. In regard to the sale and lease back issue, Mr Dawkins simply maintained the confidentiality as befits a voluntary arrangement. He acted conscientiously in regards to the best interests of the Commonwealth and Victoria, and on advice from his department.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be understood that Loan Council borrowing agreements have been breached on numerous occasions—the Sydney Harbour tunnel, the Eraring project, the finance and lease arrangements of New South Wales railway stock are all examples of technical breaches.

If this committee has served any useful purpose, it is to throw public light upon the questions and processes of the Loan Council deliberations. Unfortunately, the unbalanced attention to Victoria has often obscured the positive aspects of this discussion.

Sovereign governments must make decisions in regards to their infrastructure needs, debt management and their budgeting circumstances and at times this has involved breaches to borrowing limits. Flexibility has traditionally been a central element of the arrangements between the members of the Loan Council. As Mr Nicholls told the inquiry, only the Commonwealth has historically been interested in policing agreements.

What is important is the issue of accountability—accountability to the people who elected them to manage the affairs of the state. The major reform principles, already agreed by the Loans Council over the last twelve months, will encourage greater disclosure and accountability.
Many witnesses before the committee have expressed views on accountability and this issue is crucial in considering the current and future operations of the Loans Council.

I remain unconvinced by the arguments supporting greater market regulation of government borrowing activities. It has been suggested that there is no need for institutions such as the Loans Council. Many on the opposite side of the chamber would like to see it abolished in favour of a free marketeer approach which would rely on the discipline of the markets to monitor and restrain public sector borrowings. The government senators consider this to be a most irresponsible course of action.

Without ruling out a role for the financial markets, the Loans Council is essential to control the quantum of public sector borrowing; provide a forum for the states to discuss economic difficulties and; it provides a useful macro-economic lever for the Commonwealth government.
Many witnesses confirmed this viewpoint and expressed concern about relying too heavily on market discipline.
Standards and Poor stated:

Major credit rating agencies such as Standard and Poor's (S&P) play a specialised but restricted role in financial markets. Credit ratings perform the isolated function of credit risk evaluation, which is one element of the entire investment (i.e. lending) decision-making process.
Schroeders Australia stated:

Where there continues to exist a residual Commonwealth responsibility for the financial obligations of State or Territory Governments, either real or perceived, then it would seem to be inappropriate to leave the responsibility for monitoring financial performance entirely to the market. In the event that a State or Territory Government was unable to meet its commitments the market may not readily accept this responsibility without looking to the Commonwealth for redress.
Des Moore from the Institute of Public Affairs stated:

The main problem with such a "market solution" is that governments do not necessarily respond to market signals, or at least not in a timely way. Further, markets and credit rating agencies are susceptible to allowing governments to borrow excessively because they know that, in the end, governments can and do generally fall back on their taxing powers to service their debts.
Barbara Veoh, the former general manager of Vic Fin stated:

Dilution replacement of Loan Council controls of the public sector borrowing requirement with a more market driven mechanism for the rationing of credit needs to take into account some of the following aspects. Firstly, there is the potential moral hazard at the Commonwealth and State government level. The extent to which the market operates on the basis of an implicit government guarantee can act to counterbalance market efficiencies in the rationing of credit.

Secondly, an entirely market driven system of credit rationing with heavy reliance placed upon credit agency assessments of public sector entities and governments would not necessarily encourage cooperation between the states and the Commonwealth in the development of macro-economic policy.

Thirdly, an entirely market driven system to ration public sector calls upon the capital markets would, in practice, primarily reflect market assessment of reported or rumoured information and not in itself be a panacea for prevention of non-disclosure.

And so we see a broad cross section of groups all cautioning the government on the total reliance of the markets. It would appear that only the Liberal Party with their discredited ideological objectives still believes in this irresponsible approach.

Of course government senators, along with the Commonwealth Treasurers clearly see a role for the financial markets—a role that complements the Loan Council which would continue to set borrowing limits.

Governments must be accountable to the people who elected them. In making deliberations about spending on health, education, infrastructure or a range of other social policy they are accountable to the general community, not just the financial community.
They must take into account the perspective of current taxpayers, future taxpayers as well as the views of the financial community.
In Conclusion

It is regrettable that this committee has taken 12 months to produce results which have basically been superseded by Loans Council reforms and which have little relevance to the current operations of the Loans Council.
I look forward to the end of this committee so that we can direct our attention to the more important issues facing the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia between 17 October and 5 November 1993. I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.

The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation comprised myself as leader of the delegation; Senator Jim Short, deputy leader; the Hon Don Dobie, MP; and Ms Mary Crawford, MP. Ms Robyn McClelland was delegation secretary, and my wife, Ms Jackie Watkins, accompanied the delegation.

The visit of the parliamentary delegation was timely. In Vietnam, there has been a recent surge in Australian investment and commercial interest. The visit preceded the forthcoming visit to Vietnam of an Australian delegation on human rights.

In Laos, the Mekong River Friendship Bridge between Laos and Thailand, which has been funded by Australia, is nearing completion for opening in April 1994. The visit preceded the visit to Australia this week of the Lao Prime Minister, Mr Khamtay Siphandone.

The timing of the visit to Cambodia is particularly significant, following immediately after the establishment of the Constitution, the Parliament and the Government of the Kingdom of Cambodia. The three countries have not been visited by official parliamentary delegations for some time.

As leader of the Parliamentary delegation to Indo China, the three main themes I have gained from the mission to Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia are the desperate struggle for Peace, Economic Development to alleviate poverty, and the Re-Settlement of people who had previously fled their homelands in fear of their lives.

The Leaders and Parliamentarians of all three nations were determined to work for internal and regional peace. Many experienced war and conflict at first hand, most have lost close relatives in the respective conflicts.

Each country faces unique and individual problems but all share the fact that they have recently been ravaged by war, have lost hundreds of thousands of people, and are poor and underdeveloped. I found a very firm resolve to work for greater national and regional stability and with that, to alleviate poverty. Politicians in each of the countries all realised that economic development would not and could not happen in conflict or warlike situations.

The aim of the delegation's Report is to inform members of the Australian Parliament and Australians in general about the three countries, and specifically in relation to the status of economic and political development, the prospects for national stability and trade, and foreign policy and development cooperation issues.

The Indochinese region is significant to Australia because of its proximity and size, its importance for regional stability, and because many Australians are immigrants from the Indochinese countries. The report presents a number of recommendations, aimed at optimising Australia's role in the region, and ensuring that our good relationship with the three nations continue and develop.
The delegation saw it as important to ensure that its Report was presented quickly: the information in the report may become less valuable with the passage of time.
The Report presents Australian business people with information on the opportunities for developing Australia's investment and commercial interests in the three countries.

Australia is well placed to be part of regional and in-country economic development, we are already the third largest foreign investor nation in Vietnam, and enjoy good political, diplomatic and business relations with Laos and Cambodia.

An investment promotion and protection agreement between Australia and Laos is expected to be signed this week during the visit of the Lao Prime Minister. Whilst exports of Australian goods to all these nations is relatively small, all of them represent opportunities for growth in the foreseeable future. However, Australian business should be warned that there are high risks in chasing short term high return projects, rather they should prepare for the long haul.
I would like to refer to two other matters included in the Report, human rights, and the Australian development cooperation programs in the three countries.

Whilst human rights was not a principal focus of the delegation, the delegation did raise particular issues on behalf of the constituents of its members. The Report includes two recommendations on human rights.

The delegation's investigations into a number of Australian funded aid projects showed in most instances, the programs addressed basic needs of the people, and were geared to be sustainable with training for locals being built into each program.

Relatively little funding was made to go a long way with people and communities were being developed at the same time. The delegation visited many aid projects, and was generally satisfied with what it saw. There were, however, issues of viability and accountability for some projects. The delegation considers it very important for aid administrators to get out into the field to see their projects. A project that looks fine on paper may not be so in practice.
The showpiece of the aid program was undoubtedly a visit to the recently completed Friendship Bridge over the Mekong River which joins Laos and Thailand.

The Report is likely to be of particular interest to members of the Vietnamese, Lao and Cambodian communities in Australia. For example, the Report presents information on the situations facing `returnees' to each of the three countries.
It includes in particular, a detailed statement from the Government of Cambodia on this issue.

I was particularly pleased with the responses we received in each country to questions about returnees—people who had previously fled their homelands to escape from war and the after effects of conflict.

A total of 42,000 people have returned to Laos, 30,000 of them voluntarily deciding to leave refugee camps and take control of their own lives. The number of Vietnamese who have returned so far is 50,000 and a staggering 370,000 have gone back to Cambodia.

What pleases me most is the fact that these people, almost half a million of them, have not been punished, discriminated against or otherwise victimised. The delegation members questioned Ministers, Members of Parliament, Human Rights organisations, representatives from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, National Red Cross organisations and others including Australian Embassy staff in Hanoi, Vientiane and Phnom Penh.
Vietnamese Vice Foreign Minister Vu Khoan welcomed the return of boat people. Over 100,000 Vietnamese people are still in camps in South East Asia.

The delegation were told that a number of Lao had returned to investigate business possibilities and several had remained operating businesses. We were told of a refugee who returned from France to Lao only six months before the December 1992 National Assembly elections. He had stood as a candidate and is now a Member of the Lao National Assembly.

HRH Prince Norodom Sirivudh, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs in Cambodia, assured the delegation that boat people would be welcomed back and that exit formalities for those who wanted to leave again, would be freely available to Cambodian citizens.

His Royal Highness went on to say that the Royal Cambodian Government understood that people had fled previous regimes, not from the democratically elected Royal Government. He specifically mentioned and welcomed the Australian Government's Special Assistance Category Program recently announced by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Nick Bolkus.

The delegation would like to record its appreciation to the Chairmen of the National Assemblies of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia for the hospitality and courtesy extended during its visit. The delegation also thanks the Australian Ambassadors to each of the countries: H.E. Michael Potts, H.E. Michael Mann and H.E. John Holloway. Australia can feel justly proud of the efforts of our Ambassadors and the staff of embassies in these countries.

I thank officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Parliamentary Research Service and the Parliamentary Relations Office for helping with the delegation's program. I make special mention of the delegation secretary, Robyn McClelland, whose assistance and advice, prior, during and after the mission was invaluable. The fact that this report can be presented within weeks of the delegations return to Australia is a testament to her ability, loyalty and dedication. I trust her superiors are as aware as members of the delegation are of what a fine officer of the Parliament she is.
I recognise and thank the personnel in the House of Representatives printing unit for their fine effort in producing the report.

I thank my colleagues—Senator Short, Mr Dobie and Ms Crawford for their co-operation and assistance throughout the three weeks of the delegation. Their active participation in the delegations deliberations ensured a wide range of topics of interest to Australia were raised with our hosts.
Thanks are also extended to my wife Jackie who was much more than an appendage and spouse during the mission.

In closing I would like to say that the delegation was privileged to visit these countries. It was clear that Australia has good relations with the three countries. The visit served to reaffirm the strength of Australia's bilateral relationship with each of the three countries.
I commend the report to the Senate.

The report which I have tabled deals with the RAAF Williams rationalisation project, Laverton, Victoria.
RAAF Williams, which comprises Point Cook and Laverton bases is located 20 kilometres west of the Melbourne Central Business District and 5 kilometres from the township of Werribee.

The Defence Force Structure Review rationalised the disposition and functions of all Defence units and subsequently, in May 1991 the Minister for Defence, Senator the Hon Robert Ray announced that the airfields at Laverton and Point Cook were to be closed or sold.

Following the Minister's announcement a Consultative Committee under the chairmanship of the Hon Barry Jones, MP, examined the implications of the possible base closures and the impact this would have on local communities.
This proposal consists of three major items, minor adjusting works and engineering services. The major items are:
refurbishment of the School of Radio Building at Laverton to accommodate RAAF Headquarters Logistics Command, which will vacate rented premises in the Melbourne CBD
refurbishment of existing facilities at Laverton to house all elements of the RAAF Publications Unit
construction of purpose-built facilities for the RAAF Institute of Aviation Medicine which will be relocated from Point Cook Base to RAAF Base Edinburgh in South Australia

At the public hearing the Committee was advised of the savings in rental which will result by relocating Headquarters Logistics Command from premises presently occupied in the Melbourne Central Business District to RAAF Base Laverton.

The Institute of Aviation Medicine will be collocated with the Aircraft Research and Development Unit which is currently located at Edinburgh. One of the functions of the Institute of Aviation Medicine is refresher training for current aircrew and service transport will make Edinburgh easily accessible.

While recognising the historical significance of Point Cook and supporting the proposal, the Committee does not see the logic of maintaining the two operational bases at Laverton and Point Cook. Apart from the RAAF Museum, the Committee does not see the necessity for maintaining other units, such as Headquarters Training Command and the RAAF College at Point Cook. Should the National Air and Space Museum be established at Point Cook, then the Committee believes the RAAF Museum should be incorporated into it.
The Committee recommends that no further capital works be commenced at RAAF Base Point Cook and that units located at Point Cook, with the exception of the RAAF Museum be located elsewhere.

The Committee also recommends that the Department of Defence keep it advised of the results of the ground decontamination surveys of RAAF Williams and of possible costs of decontaminating both RAAF Base Laverton and RAAF Base Point Cook.
The estimated cost of the RAAF Williams rationalisation project is $19.8m at August 1993 prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow opposition amendment No.13, dealing with secondary boycotts, part 6, pages 65 to 82 inclusive, and clauses 36 to 54, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is hereby declared, for the avoidance of doubt, that the statute laws of the Commonwealth relating to secondary boycotts, as in force on 7 December 1993, served the public interest.".

In speaking to this amendment, the opposition wants to put it fairly and squarely on the record that we believe that the situation which now relates to secondary boycotts is appropriate for Australia from a number of points of view. Firstly, it gives protection to business from unfair and unjust interference across a full spectrum of boycott activity, including political boycotts.

PARA.TAB: What the government does in its legislation, in transferring certain aspects of sections 45D and 45E to the industrial relations bill, is remove that aspect, which we believe is a step in the wrong direction. In fact, it will give open slather to a number of organisations or individuals to pursue matters of a political nature, which will in fact do serious and continuing damage to the Australian economy. It will also do serious and continuing damage to employers, or businesses, and, of course, the employees within those businesses, because they will suffer equally from this type of action.

The other point that we want to make in terms of the secondary boycott provisions is that in dealing with them under the Trade Practices Act and through the Federal Court they remain in what I would term a proper court of law, not a specialist court. We believe it is a dangerous precedent, in terms of industrial or political matters, to be establishing an industrial court or one that is a specialist court that has certain restrictions around it in terms of carrying out its functions in a fair and equitable way.

I particularly refer to the 72-hour clause, relating to the length of time before action can be taken, which will be contained in this legislation. One must note here that the principal role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the industrial court attached to it will be conciliation. In a national context, enormous damage can be inflicted on a business or on our reputation as a reliable supplier of goods and services.

In addition to that, damage can be done to a particular business which is a supplier within Australia. For example, I know of a Western Australian business which produced mining equipment which was needed by a deadline in New South Wales. Because the company did not meet that deadline, it lost the contract.

In addressing the position that we believe is the proper one, we must reject the government's proposals. One must also question some other aspects of the government's proposals, which I will deal with when we look at the bill clause by clause.

I also raise this issue with Senator Bell from the Democrats. Senator Bell sat through most of the inquiry's hearings, if not all the hearings, into sections 45D and E. One could not but conclude at the end of those hearings that a number of aspects were raised about the use of sections 45D and E and their effectiveness.

I refer to some of the evidence given to the inquiry. Between 1977 and June 1993, only 206 court actions involved the use of sections 45D and E. The vast majority of those court actions were taken against unions. Forty per cent of the applicants were able to obtain interim injunctions to halt the damage to their business. Under the government's proposal, we will find that there can be up to 72 hours of damage. As one witness said to us, 72 hours can be a long time, particularly if we are dealing with a Madonna concert, for example.

The other thing that came through very clearly was that this measure was a very strong deterrent. People thought very carefully before they went into boycott action, which I think is a very important aspect of this matter. Law must be a deterrent. We must be aware of the consequences of taking an action which can harm and hurt somebody else. There must be balance in dealing with these aspects between the various parties. The government's proposal removes that balance. During this debate, we have heard much from a number of speakers here about discrimination.

Quite categorically, the removal of sections 45D and E from the Trade Practices Act and the changes being made are creating a serious and severe discrimination against the wealth producers of this nation, against those who will be responsible for overcoming the unemployment difficulties we have in this nation, and against those who are prepared to invest and expand our economy to maintain our standard of living.
When this matter was last debated, former Senator Jack Evans of the Democrats summed it up absolutely perfectly:

When one gets to a secondary boycott which is non-industrial—an economic boycott or a political boycott—one has a very difficult position which probably cannot be satisfactorily resolved under a conciliation and arbitration system.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what the government is trying to do and, as I understand, it is supported by the Democrats today. Jack Evans further stated:

It will probably need to be taken out of that system so that it can be handled through other courts. Partly because of that but, in the end principally because of the unwillingness of the Minister to budge at all in looking at a number of alternatives that have been put to him by industry representatives—representatives of the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia and many others—
That is exactly the same as the situation we have now. He continued:

the Australian Democrats have been put into the position that we will have no alternative but to reject outright the proposals in this legislation. We will do so unhesitatingly, without any qualms of conscience, because we know that we will be protecting a very vulnerable group. Such a group includes people in small business who, if they become the targets of a secondary boycott, are likely to suffer not just a brief economic setback but could suffer annihilation.
He later said:
Regrettably the alternatives to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, as proposed by the Minister, simply give access in the first instance to a conciliation system.
I have already made that point. This is very relevant. Jack Evans continued:

This means sitting around the table and having a chat—nobody would have any power to arbitrate—in the hope that something good will come out of it. That is fine if the person who was subjected to that sort of pressure was not in the vulnerable position of having to expect an instant decision.

I cannot emphasise enough the importance of that instant decision. I also want to lay to rest a couple of furphies that were thrown at us about the position of employees not being protected under the current provisions of sections 45D and E as far as taking action with regard to their working conditions and their position. That matter is covered in section 45D(iii). It is backed up by precedent established in a 1990 court case involving the AMIEU.

PARA.TAB: Another furphy that came up related to political boycotts. Once again there is precedent in law. In a case involving the BLF and a company in Western Australia, action was taken with regard to a boycott situation. Because the boycott was targeted at the Western Australian government and Homeswest—this is a very important precedent relating to sections 45D and E—the court did not consider it to be targeted at the business on which the picket line was put up. That was known as the Jaycorp case.

I say to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) who is at the table and to Senator Bell that when they are dealing with this matter they should take into consideration these aspects of the law and the precedents. By removing sections 45D and E from the Trade Practices Act, they are destroying a whole set of precedents in law.

In the next two, five or probably 10 years under this legislation, we will see a whole series of precedent-setting court causes to establish precisely what I call the gobbledegook, because I am having a great difficulty understanding this, and so are a lot of legal people. Only the courts will sort out what it actually means. The government and the Democrats are creating a situation where the lawyers of this country, the legal firms of this country, will have another bonanza. If they want a lawyer-led recovery, they are going the right way about it, not only in terms of this legislation but also the legislation that we will be dealing with either tomorrow or the next day—the Mabo legislation. I will not say any more about Mabo now, because I will have my opportunity then.

The government seems hell-bent on this, and the Democrats seem to be in the same situation. They want to create bonanzas for legal people when proper precedent is already set down in law. People understand the rules. The rules have worked effectively; they have protected Australian industry. There is protection for people's working conditions—which was established quite clearly in the inquiry's hearing—and there is protection when the action is targeted, as it is in this case, at the government of the day—the Western Australian Labor government.

In foreshadowing this amendment, I emphasise to Senator Bell, who is here on behalf of the Democrats, that we believe that what Senator Evans said back then is as true and factual today. Nothing has changed in the government's fundamental thrust, except that it is giving additional privileges to the union movement—we will deal with that when we get to some of the clauses in the bill—at the expense of those who are not in the union movement.

Some of these issues which we will be raising are quite horrendous. I ask the minister to think very carefully before he continues down this path. He has probably gone so far down this track that he cannot reverse. But he will live to bear the fruits—he will get the rewards—of what he has done. Those rewards will damage—I should not be using the word `rewards'—the Australian economy, business in this country, our reputation as an international supplier and the employees who work in those various businesses. One could quite easily address this subject for a significant time, but that outlines our principal objections to what is being done, and that is why I will be moving this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the history of industrial relations in Australia, secondary boycotts—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I do not want to interrupt Senator Chapman later, so I thought I would raise it now before he gets started. Can you tell me where we are on your sensible proposal to take clauses 36 to 54 together. It will indicate how we all speak in the debate from here on.

—I have allowed the debate to be as wide as it has been because this issue would be covered irrespective of whether Senator Chapman were speaking only to clause 36 or clauses 36 to 54. I understand the question that you are asking me, Senator McMullan, but I am looking to see whether I can facilitate what I was putting to Senator Crane without compromising myself by explaining the benefit to him in a partisan way. I thought Senator Chapman might like to continue, if that suits you, Senator McMullan.

—Mr Chairman, I seek some information from the minister. In a debate we had yesterday about conventions and customary law, Parliamentary Secretary Sherry mentioned that I would be receiving within 24 hours a letter which answered my questions. Can the minister tell me the status of that letter?
—I do not know anything about the 24-hour commitment because I was not here at the time, but I am advised that such a letter is being prepared for Senator Kemp.

—Mr Chairman, I want to clear up a procedural matter. If we lose this amendment, we want to move a further amendment to clause 40. How does that fit in with the handling of what you have suggested? I have no problem in facilitating the arrangement so long as I understand where we are going.

—Senator Crane, my understanding is that you are seeking to have clauses 36 to 54 inclusive removed. So you can deal with that question. In the event that you are successful, you would then move your subsequent amendment. I understand that you are opposed to clause 40—in fact, you are opposed to all the clauses.

—We are opposed to all the clauses, but if we are not successful in removing them, we particularly want to deal with clause 40. We do not want to end up removing clauses piecemeal; we do not want to end up having some removed and some left in. We either remove them all and come back to clause 40 or we do not.
—It might be helpful if Senator Chapman continued and Senator McMullan and Senator Crane had a chat about it, because I am limited as to how much advice I can give from the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I oppose clauses 36 to 54 which we are presently dealing with. They seek to remove the legislative provisions relating to secondary boycotts from the Trade Practices Act and install a much watered-down version of those provisions into the Industrial Relations Act through this amendment bill. Like all my coalition colleagues, I am vehemently opposed to this proposal. I indicate that opposition and also indicate support for the amendments which have been foreshadowed by Senator Crane with regard to declaring that the statute laws of the Commonwealth relating to secondary boycotts, as in force on 7 December 1993, serve the public interest. I also support the amendment to clause 40, which has been foreshadowed by Senator Crane.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying before being interrupted by the discussion on the procedures to be adopted in relation to these clauses, secondary boycotts have been a serious and significant problem throughout the history of Australian industrial relations. Until the introduction of legislation by the Fraser government that provided for a remedy against secondary boycotts through the Trade Practices Act, they were a very costly problem for the business and industry sector and for the nation as a whole. Since that secondary boycott legislation was introduced by the Fraser government in 1977, there has been a continual campaign by the trade union movement and certain academics to have that legislation repealed and having at least—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it was effective.

—As Senator Kemp says, because it was effective. Those groups failed to get the legislation repealed so they sought to have it watered down in the way the government is seeking to water it down through these proposed new clauses in this bill. That campaign by the trade union organisations and their supporting weak-kneed academics has been entirely self-interested. The reason they have sought to water this legislation down is that it has been so effective in preventing the enormous damage which secondary boycotts previously caused to business activity and ultimately to employees through the damage it caused to businesses and therefore their capacity to provide jobs.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting that as far back as 1984 the predecessor to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry conducted a survey of employers to see how many employers had used sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act relating to secondary boycotts in the previous 18 months. It is worth looking at some of the reactions it got in that survey. A typical response was, `The unions involved in the boycott were totally recalcitrant until section 45D proceedings'.
