That word is fashionable these days. It is good to see that it was used as far back as 1984. That word has been highlighted in recent days so we know what it means. It means stubborn.

While it was possible pre sections 45D and 45E for employers to take action to overcome secondary boycotts, that action took much longer to initiate and it took much longer to get an effective result. By the time successful action was taken under the legislation that applied prior to 1977 companies could be bankrupt and out of business and the jobs that those companies provided destroyed.

Any delay in court proceedings which occurred before sections 45D and 45E were available was disastrous for particular businesses. I cite as examples the waterfront industry and the building industry. In those industries even one day's delay can destroy a business. In the waterfront industry it can even destroy the goods that are waiting to be shipped overseas to our customers.

We know only too well the damage that has been done to our export industries for years and years by industrial action of this sort on the waterfront. Australia has become known around the world as an unreliable supplier of goods and services because of our waterfront disputes and the use of secondary boycotts. These actions cause enormous damage to our trade.

Do we really want to encourage secondary boycotts to rear their heads again? That is what the government's proposed amendment will do. This proposed amendment will make it much more difficult for employers and businesses to act against secondary boycotts because we are making them less effective and much weaker. There is also a 72 hour delay in having effective access to secondary boycott provisions under the government's proposal. The removal of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act and their installation into the industrial relations legislation will undoubtedly reduce the protection that is available to employers against primary and secondary boycotts.

I refer to the claim by some that these provisions are not really necessary because they have not been used all that often to seek and to ultimately award damages on the part of employers. In evidence given to the Senate committee that investigated the government's proposal to change the way sections 45D and 45E operated, it was made clear by witness after witness that it was not the fact that this legislation provided for damages to be claimed and obtained but it was just the availability of this clause that was useful. Businesses that were threatened by secondary boycotts would have access to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and could use that as a deterrent. A submission to that inquiry lodged by the National Farmers Federation stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than have 45D and 45E seen in negative terms, these provisions are a positive method of settling disputes and more importantly a means by which to prevent them. As more employers have exhibited their willingness to exercise their rights to legal redress, the union movement has been forced to be held accountable for their actions. With the realisation that unions may have to make some contributions to the damages that they cause, this has created a situation where unions are more cautious about engaging in prohibited conduct. This in no way impinges upon a union's rights but merely places those rights into perspective with the rights of all in society.

That was specific evidence from the National Farmers Federation but it mirrored evidence from many witnesses to that inquiry, which highlighted the usefulness of sections 45D and 45E being maintained within the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: Witness after witness to that inquiry clearly showed that sections 45D and 45E were usually used as a last resort. Those sections were used when attempts to obtain relief within the industrial relations jurisdiction had failed. Sections 45D and 45E were available as a last resort because those provisions are not presently contained within the industrial relations jurisdiction. They are within the Trade Practices Act and therefore outside the jurisdiction of the industrial relations system and outside the jurisdiction and the control of the industrial relations club. Given that these provisions are used only when the industrial relations jurisdiction has failed, to include these provisions within that jurisdiction will emasculate them in terms of their effectiveness and their utility to employers to defend themselves against rapacious unions.
Another witness to that inquiry was asked why injunctions rarely led to damages, and that witness responded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a common experience in relation to any forms of statutory or common law relief which is available to employers. They are, as a rule, not availed of as a first resort. There is normally an attempt to resolve the issue by other means and, if those means fail, the employers will turn to whatever remedies are available to them. As we pointed out, section 45D has proved very effective in that sense, either the threat of the relief being sought or of the injunction being obtained.

Again we see that the effectiveness of this legislation is simply its availability. It is not that it has on many occasions resulted in payment of substantial damages. I can recall cases where that has occurred. In the Mudginberri Abattoirs and the Dollar Sweets cases the ultimate penalty has been exacted from the recalcitrant damaging behaviour of trade unions, and substantial damages have been obtained by those particular businesses.

PARA.TAB: It is quite unjust and it is contrary to the interests of this country to have access to common law remedies seriously weakened in the way that these proposed new clauses will do. Incorporating those provisions into the industrial relations legislation will weaken the anti-boycott provisions of the trade practices legislation.

It is a direct threat to small business because by and large it is small business that has benefited from the application of this legislation. Again I cite the Dollar Sweets and Mudginberri Abattoirs cases because they are typical small businesses. I do not know what the generosity of Senator Murphy, who has just handed out some sweets, has to do with this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a dollar sweet.

—It is indeed. I recognise it now. Would Senator Murphy like it tabled? Once I have had my say on this very important issue I will certainly settle down to enjoy that and I will certainly express my regards to Dollar Sweets for the provision of this item.
—A great company.

—As Senator Kemp says, it is a great company. A further difficulty that the opposition has with these proposals is the requirement that 72 hours must pass before a business can seek remedy under the government's much watered down secondary boycott provisions that will apply in the industrial relations legislation. That is far too long for a business to have to wait to seek remedy when a secondary boycott is put in place. A business may be staging a one-day event. That time would be passed and the whole event would be ruined, with enormous losses to that particular business. Under these proposals, there is no protection afforded against politically motivated secondary boycotts.

PARA.TAB: I draw my remarks to a close by saying that in no way can the opposition countenance this proposal. It is a direct threat to all business, particularly small business, in its capacity to protect itself against the rapacious activities of militant trade unions. The benefit of this legislation is in its deterrent effect, the very fact of it simply being there, simply being available for use by a business threatened in this way. That benefit will be completely lost if these clauses are passed and become part of the Industrial Relations Reform Act.

In effect, these proposals put unions above the law, and that is something that ought not to be countenanced. Unions ought to be subject to the law in exactly the same way as every other member of our community is. But this again shows the bias of this legislation; it shows the bias of this government; it shows the pay-off that this government is giving the trade union movement by putting it above the law and by not making unions subject to the law in a way that other members of our community are. It is simply a device by which this government is seeking to reinforce the privileged position of trade unions in our community. It is a privilege which the unions abuse time and time again; it is a privilege to which they are not entitled; and it is a privilege which this legislation ought not give them. That is why these clauses ought to be removed from this amending bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of the expeditious handling of matters—and Senator Crane is trying to accommodate this, although not in the way that I had proposed, but with an alternative mechanism with which we will seek to cooperate—I will speak briefly. I had intended to make only one contribution, which would have been similar to that just made by Senator Chapman. Whilst I disagreed with his contribution, it was properly pitched to all clauses, so that we could have only one debate on this. But I understand Senator Crane has some points about particular clauses. I am happy to accommodate him. So I will save my more general remarks for a later, but even then brief, contribution.

PARA.TAB: I refer to amendment No. 13, with which we are specifically dealing and on which Senator Crane specifically wishes us to vote initially. Quite clearly, the government does not support the amendment; it does not support the deletion of the clause or the proposed insertion. It simply highlights the contrasting approaches—not just to secondary boycotts but to the question of industrial relations overall.

There was an historic debate and a major confrontation in 1983 about the issue of alternative approaches to industrial relations—the confrontation versus consensus debate of 1983. Over the decade nobody has been able to tell what the outcome of the confrontationist approach would have been. Its advocates can claim that all sorts of wonderful virtues would have followed if only it had been pursued. But we can certainly establish that the consensus approach has been remarkably successful, with historically low levels of industrial disputes. I know that people who like to downplay the success of the accord say that is because of the economic difficulties in Australia, but even in the periods of sustained high growth during the early 1980s we had remarkably low levels of industrial dispute as a result of the consensus approach. The government sought to make changes to sections 45D and 45E consistent with that consensus approach. We were not successful then. We are seeking to do so again.

It is not a question of good versus evil. It is about alternative approaches to industrial relations and finding an approach that will most effectively serve the national interest. The national interest is not well served by our saying that one side is in defence of the national interest and that the other is in some way malicious, poorly motivated or seeking in some way to undermine the national interest. That is not the case. We have contrasting views. I strongly disagree with the views of the opposition about industrial relations, but I accept that it sincerely holds them. I would not mind if it returned the compliment. But we accept that the opposition's views are sincerely held, even if wrong.

If we take away the overlay of prejudice and the overlay of pre-conditioned views about what role the trade union movement will undertake based on people's experiences in the 1970s and deal with the contemporary realities, I think we will find that the government's proposals strike the balance between fairness and efficiency; they highlight the consensus versus confrontation approach. I will speak about it at more length later, but we certainly do not support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is it the wish of the committee that we deal with clauses 36 to 54 inclusive? Following debate, I will then put the amendment that has been moved by Senator Crane. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 36 to 54—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the procedure, we are actually discussing the appropriateness of the sections 45D and 45E style proposal in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill and what the coalition wants to do with it. I understand that the substantive debate about that is taking place now. I will address that issue now and support whatever procedural arrangements are necessary to bring about Senator Crane's amendments.

PARA.TAB: The most important thing that has been said so far was hinted at by the minister. He did not spell out a couple of the observations that I was able to make while participating in the public inquiry which Senator Crane referred to earlier. What the minister hinted at—he did not spell it out because he was not there—was this change in culture and change in reality of the industrial relations scene, which some have been unable to observe through their prejudiced position. This change has occurred in small business, large business and certainly in large unions.

To me and, I think, to any observer it must be obvious that a great number of those early actions sought under sections 45D and 45E were occasioned by the 70s-style disputes which were essentially demarcation disputes—arm wrestles between unions establishing power bases; a lot of huffing and puffing between those seeking power bases; and a lot of victimisation of legitimate businesses going about their legitimate business and suffering at the hands of the unions. I do not move away from my horror at the ramifications of these quite stupid actions by unions which, at that time, were irresponsible and arrogant in their attitude towards the welfare of others.

However, it has to be recognised that this has occurred in the past 20 years. Indeed, events in the early 1970s provoked these measures, the mid-1970s justified them, and in the late 1970s these practices were effectively quelled. In relation to union amalgamations, the changes in work practices and the reorganisation of awards, I am sure we would be helped constructively by a contribution from Senator Gibson, if he were now present. Were he here, he would be able to tell us of the reduction in the number of awards directly affecting the Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission—from several hundreds down to a mere handful today. He would tell us of the multi-award arrangement, the change in job specification and the change in union representation. There has been a huge, drastic change in the climate of the workplace and the confrontationist attitude—the minister hinted at that—to one where at least teams were recognised and the benefits that flowed from seeing a common goal between the work force and the employer.

That change has brought about a situation in which the provocations, which were essentially brought about by demarcation disputes, have diminished to such an extent that in evidence in Hobart the advocate for the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce, Mr Abey, was unable to indicate how relevant sections 45D and 45E would be in addressing the sorts of problems that we have now.

That change has been responsible for different needs to be addressed on the industrial relations scene. And here we have the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. In this debate there have been suggestions by some speakers that past behaviour was bad—I have often agreed with them—and I have responded by saying that that is the very reason why we need to change and indeed why this bill is before us.

I need to address a matter that was alluded to earlier in the discussion by Senator Crane. I refer to the application of sections 45D and 45E to matters other than industrial. In this area the Democrats have to disagree. We stand without equivocation on our assertion that it is not at all appropriate to use provisions which, to all intents and purposes, were intended to deal with industrial matters, albeit in the Trade Practices Act, later as a means of effectively preventing community protest at environmental inroads or concerns that are other than industrial. We contend and strongly believe that those who engage in legitimate community protest over environmental matters should not be subjected to provisions which were originally intended to govern industrial relations processes.

If it is thought to be appropriate by any government to regulate the opportunity of citizens to protest about any matter, it should be up-front and come in here and describe what rights and privileges of the community it wishes to regulate. It should regulate them up-front in a manner that is honest about those protest rights which that government wishes to diminish. On the basis of that, we could see the sorts of measures that were brought in in Queensland where it was made very difficult for a family of four to stand together on the street.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—Those provisions were ridiculed, and I have stretched the argument to prove the point. My point is that if any government wishes to bring in measures to regulate protest by its citizens on any matter whatsoever, let that government come in here and admit that that is what it is doing. Let it not persist with hiding behind measures of the Trade Practices Act which are then extended to deny citizens the opportunity to protest on environmental or other matters which they are concerned with. We will insist on that. I think we have made it very clear that we believe that there should be regulation of the sorts of actions that are taken in industrial matters.

PARA.TAB: I return to one other aspect about which people have become a little confused. I refer to the question of 72 hours. That number has been repeated quite often in this discussion. It is unfortunate that it is used in a couple of different places, in that 72 hours written notice of the intention to take action has to be given. Unfortunately, it has been interpreted right from the beginning—the very first time it was mentioned—that 72 hours would be a period of time which would apply as the time during which so-called protected industrial action could be taken.

The Democrats were concerned that there would be a 72 hour free-for-all. I believe we have now ensured that it is expressed in the bill as being a maximum period of time and that any number of conditions can apply to bring an end to that period of protection. The commission has the capacity to determine, for example, that perishable goods are being threatened—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you consulted with small business?
—It is precisely because small business was consulted that we negotiated this position.
—They wanted this change?

—They certainly did. The success of that negotiation was as a result of looking at the fact that this bill would be before us and that possibly this bill was negotiable. Because of that fact and because the Democrats took a constructive attitude and sought to achieve these changes in negotiations, we now have before us not 72 hours as the required time, but rather 72 hours as a period of time after which there could not possibly be any further action, and that the certificate of access to the industrial court would be granted. It was a maximum period rather than the required period.

PARA.TAB: It is important to look at the coalition's position; it cannot have it all its own way. When representatives of small business have represented opinions at the public inquiries—and we know the names of the organisations that purport to represent small business—some have taken the trouble to consult with their membership, and some have actually expressed opinions on behalf of small businesses. But when I contacted the actual individual businesses—and large businesses, I might say—of this several hundred which have contacted me I was unable to find any which had communicated with their representative industry groups. Not one. Even their political representatives had not taken the trouble to inform these individuals that there had been a public inquiry started over a year ago, and another public inquiry started a couple of months ago.

Last night Senator Woodley gave the committee one example of a direct expression of the inadequacy of representation by the local political representative. At that time a great fuss was made by the coalition as if it was a slur on that local representative. What is wrong with that? As Democrats we have to come in here every day and suffer the groundless assertions that the coalition makes about our particular capacity to represent small business. I actually quite enjoy hearing members of the coalition making fools of themselves in that way because they are simply saying that there has not been enough time to represent things. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct a comment made by Senator Bell earlier. Not even the Australian Labor Party would disagree that the purpose of getting rid of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act is a longstanding policy inspired by the ACTU. It has been on the books ever since the act was enacted in 1974.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell has said that today is different from the 1970s. According to Senator Bell, most of these secondary boycotts were to do with demarcation disputes, which no-one on the other side would agree with. It is absolute nonsense. It has obviously been made up by Senator Bell who thinks he can say anything in this place and get away with it. It is quite a dishonest statement that the main cause of these secondary boycotts was demarcation disputes. Nothing could be further from the truth.
He said the climate has changed today. It is only six weeks ago—I have said this before and I will say it again—that the coal mining industry in Australia went on strike—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that.

—Senator Bell said things were different today. This is a classic example. The coal mining industry went on strike because it did not like the price that BHP got for its coal in Turkey. Companies which were not involved—CRA was one and I have forgotten the other one—took out an injunction against the union. Instead of it being a five-day strike it came back to a three-day strike because of the deterrent contained in sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making is that what Senator Bell said was quite wrong. This example is an up-to-date version of the sorts of things that have happened. As Senator Bell would know, the whole purpose of section 45D was to prevent boycotts occurring by people who are not involved with the company concerned. It was simply to make life difficult for the company, to cost it money and markets, and to cost us reliability. This is yet another example of the Democrats selling out the small business community. Senator Bell knows it. He is trying to make lame excuses and, in fact, quite nonsensical arguments as to why sections 45D and 45E should be removed from the Trade Practices Act.

This is not surprising because only the other day, in response to Senator Kemp, Senator Bell disowned the founder of his own party, former Senator Chipp. He almost referred to him as some old fogy of years gone by, when it was former Senator Chipp who came in here allegedly to represent small business and keep everybody honest. It is a matter of being honest on this side. As I mentioned earlier, the Labor Party has not pretended otherwise—it knows what it is doing and Senator Bell is aiding and abetting it.
Amendment (Senator Crane's) proposed:
Clauses 36 to 54, pages 65 to 82, omit the clauses, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Secondary boycotts law serves the public interest

PARA.TAB: "36. It is hereby declared, for the avoidance of doubt, that the statute laws of the Commonwealth relating to secondary boycotts, as in force on 7 December 1993, serve the public interest.".
Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, after having had discussions with Minister McMullan when we broke for dinner, we have determined, as was suggested by you, that we will deal with all the clauses relating to secondary boycotts in part 6 of the bill. We will then deal with the clauses in part 7 relating to the Industrial Relations Court of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken about our position in respect of secondary boycotts. So I will endeavour, once again, not to traverse that ground—and I hope Senator Sherry notes that. However, I wish to raise a number of matters with regard to secondary boycotts. Mr Chairman, in view of the fact that we are dealing with the bill in the way I have just outlined, you may have to bear with me a little.

I refer in particular to proposed section 160 under clause 38 on page 68 of the bill. I would like an explanation from the parliamentary secretary, if possible, as to how proposed section 160 (c) interrelates with proposed section 162(3). I have had some problem—as have a number of other people—in trying to come to a conclusion as to exactly what this means. We are intrigued because proposed section 160(c) states:

SPEECH.PARA: in subsection 162(3) the words `if either the third person or the fourth person is a constitutional corporation' were omitted.
Those words are also contained in proposed section 162(3). Could we have an explanation of the interrelationship between those proposed sections?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed section 160 allows proposed section 162 to rely on section 51(i) of the constitution—in other words, the trade and commerce power. The purpose of paragraph (c) of proposed section 160 is to enable proposed section 162, the boycotts provisions, to rely on an alternative power under the constitution. That alternative power is the corporations power rather than the trade and commerce power of section 51 of the constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I appreciate that information, the parliamentary secretary has not exactly answered my question. I was seeking the interrelationship between proposed section 160(c) and proposed section 162. I particularly mentioned the removing of the words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . either the third person or the fourth person is a constitutional corporation.
How do those words relate or what do they cover; in other words, what does it mean?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, it broadens proposed section 160(2) because one does not need to rely on the corporations power; so one does not have to be a corporation to engage in trade and commerce.
—That being so, does that mean that in the case of industrial disputation or boycotts, action can be taken against any business, regardless of whether or not it is a corporation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is engaging in interstate or overseas commerce, yes. As I understand it, this provision reflects what is currently the effect of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will leave that. What is the difference between paragraphs (a) and (b) in proposed section 162(4) and what currently exists in 45D(3) of the Trade Practices Act? Proposed section 162(4) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person is not regarded as taking part in a boycott by engaging in conduct the ultimate purpose of which is substantially related to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the remuneration . . .

SPEECH.PARA: My question is: what is the difference between that and what exists at present in 45D(3) of the Trade Practices Act?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Act refers to the `dominant purpose', whereas this provision refers to the `ultimate purpose'. That is the critical difference between this provision and the current provision in the Trade Practices Act.

—That is indeed interesting. I shall leave my comments on that until later in the debate. Can the parliamentary secretary explain what proposed subsection 162(9)(a)(ii)(A) and (B) at the top of page 71 means? Does it mean that if one is a member of the trade union one will not have to comply with the law in the sense that one will be exempted from any boycott actions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This provision means that if members or officers of the union that is engaged in a secondary boycott are engaged in activities contained in subclauses 162(7)(c) and (d), they are excluded from the provisions of the secondary boycott as outlined in clause 162.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In effect, the government is giving a privilege in the form of immunity to a group of people who can go into the workplace, be involved in a picket line or take action through a boycott. That is what it means, and I have to say that I think it is a damned disgrace. Maybe I should withdraw that.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—No.

TALK.START.PARA: —All right. It is an absolute and total disgrace. Those opposite need to have a really hard look at themselves. They come in here and talk about discrimination and privilege. Senator Bell needs to have a very good look at himself too. If he can support this sort of rubbish—this nonsense—if he can give people immunity when they are involved in something which will damage somebody, what are we coming to? I ask honourable senators to address that question.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am aware, this proposed section of the law will be the only one in this country that gives a privilege. Why select a member of a trade union? What about an ordinary person who has chosen not to join a union? It is another case of discrimination—of privilege. The next time I hear those opposite talking about us being involved in privilege, protection and elitism I will remind them that this is the worst example, to my knowledge, that has ever been brought before this parliament.

Those opposite must really ask themselves some pretty serious questions about fairness, decency and equity. The government supported some amendments against discrimination from the Democrats that should not even be in the Industrial Relations Act, yet they come in here, in what is supposed to be the highest body in this country, and put this rubbish in an act of parliament. They really should have a hard look at themselves. I hope tonight when they go home and look in the mirror that they just think about what they have done. There is probably no more I can say other than that I am proud that the opposition will not be part of this type of unfair, unjust and inconsistent treatment of decent human beings. We will not have a bar of it. Clause 162A(a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: obtaining information from, or communicating information to, people wishing to enter or leave the premises or place . . .

Clause 162A(b) deals with the obstruction, molestation or intimidation of any of those people. My first question is: when does information become offensive? Secondly, when does obstruction, molestation or intimidation become persecution? I think the parliamentary secretary needs to answer those questions because the way this clause is framed is totally and absolutely unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the parliamentary secretary is seeking advice, I will ask a few more questions. This clause exempts people from picketing. It says that the secondary boycott does not apply to conduct consisting only of persons being present outside premises for one or more of a number of purposes including obtaining information from people wishing to enter or leave the premises. I would like to know what obtaining information means. Does it mean that they can seek the names of those people who are entering the premises outside of which there is a picket? Is it not a fact that picketing itself, as we have known it in practice—forget about the nice flowery words—is a form of intimidation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Parer's point is similar to the point that Senator Crane raised on obtaining information. I do not accept that obtaining information is a form of intimidation. One can ask for information. Senator Parer has referred to asking for names. Certainly, one can ask for anything in this world; whether one gets an answer is another matter. I am sure the meaning of that is quite clear. We can ask for information and I do not believe that that is intimidatory action.

PARA.TAB: In relation to obstruction, molestation or intimidation, if accepted modes of behaviour are defined within the law, and there is case law of people who have been involved in cases of obstruction, molestation or intimidation, that case law will define the precise meaning, depending on the facts. I believe that would be quite clear, depending on people's individual behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we get a wishy-washy answer because the masters have delivered the message. In these situations why can these people not be like any other decent ordinary Australian? Why can they not just write a letter if they want information? Why can they not get on the telephone? Why can they not knock on the door and go in and see the people? I must say to Senator Bell and the Democrats who are supporting this: you are putting in place what will be intimidation of small business and large business.

PARA.TAB: I do not care what anybody says. As soon as there is a barrier and someone has to walk through a particular group whose reason for being there is to interfere—that is why they are there, for no other reason—that is intimidation. If the group's purpose is solely to gain information and not to interfere, they could do what I suggested before.

Senator Bell and Senator Kernot have to ask themselves what they are doing to small business in this nation and why they want to go down this path of legalising interference with people going about their normal business—being ordinary, normal, decent Australians. It could be just a family business with a husband and wife; it could have one employee, it could have thousands of employees. But that will be the result of what the Democrats are doing. I cannot believe this situation. This will destroy some of the trust that has been built up in the workplaces around this country. It flies in the face of everything that is decent in human relationships.

I say again that the coalition totally and absolutely rejects this type of behaviour. I knew that the government would be going down this path—it has always been its position—but I cannot believe that the Democrats have also decided to take this course of action, to go down this path. It is indeed a very sad day for this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the parliamentary secretary's confirmation of my interpretation of proposed section 162A. If a person is involved in conduct which involves obstruction, molestation or intimidation, presumably they are then subject to proposed section 162, which puts them in breach of the secondary boycott provision.
—Yes.
—Thank you, Senator Bell. I would like to know what anyone can do, under those circumstances, about those who have been responsible for intimidation, in view of proposed section 163F which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Criminal proceedings do not lie against a person merely because the person has engaged in boycott conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Sherry is getting that information, I ask: what methods can be used to collect the information in view of the fact that it is not going to be done in the normal way, which I touched on in the previous debate? How can such information be obtained?
—They could put a brick through the windscreen.

—As Senator Panizza says, putting a brick through the windscreen. We really want to know: can they use thumb screws? Can they use a cattle prod? Just how far can they go? It is not a funny matter and one should not laugh, but just how far can one go to obtain information? There is no limitation; there is no description. It just says `obtain information'. We know how it is done in a lot of circumstances. Is this just going to add to the types of things that have gone on in the past?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come back to Senator Parer's point in a moment. I will just deal with Senator Crane's point about the cattle prod. I am interested to see how we have got primary industries matters into an industrial relations debate.
—How do you get the information?

—I am going to deal with the point. Senator Crane dealt with it with some levity, so he should allow me to obtain a bit of a smile for a few seconds during what is a long night on a long issue. Clearly, the sort of example Senator Crane gave of a cattle prod—and there was another example of a brick through a window—
—I have seen it before.

—They are clearly acts that would constitute assault. I do not think anyone would argue that they are not acts that constitute assault. I do not think there could be any doubt about that. Any reasonable person would come to that conclusion.

PARA.TAB: What I have to emphasise is that Senator Crane needs to examine the facts relating to the actions that occur and what a reasonable person would come to conclude and what a court would come to conclude. I can only highlight what I believe is an appropriate mechanism for obtaining information. You can ask; you can hand a letter to a person as they are coming to the picket line. I do not believe that a court would find that that is obstruction, molestation or indeed intimidation. I think one has to look at the facts as they occur and the type of action that occurs in order to determine what is obtaining information and what is obstruction, molestation or intimidation.

Senator Crane alleged that picketing is destroying trust at the workplace and he talked a deal about small business. I just point out that, unfortunately, picketing really is an action that follows from industrial action already having taken place in a workplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only in a secondary boycott context.
—Well, in the secondary boycott context. If that occurs, then trust at the workplace would have been substantially undermined before the picket anyway.
—That is not the point. You exacerbate the problem.

—It may exacerbate what Senator Crane sees as the problem, but I would contend that the trust would already have evaporated to some extent. From my knowledge of industrial action and picketing, a picket reflects a form of action to demonstrate that a difficulty in relationships has already occurred.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the question asked by Senator Parer, if we look at proposed paragraph 162(2)(a), we see that, for example, intimidation is not exempt from proposed section 162. If the picket is a boycott under proposed section 162, then the liability for injunction or damages will follow. Proposed section 163F says that if all you have done is infringe proposed section 162, then that is not criminal. The proposed section states that criminal action does not lie merely for engaging in boycott conduct. Section 78 of the Trade Practices Act already provides that if you engage in criminal conduct you are criminally liable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to come back to the answer Senator Sherry gave in relation to what I had to say about upsetting things in the workplace. Senator Sherry made reference to the notion that if there was a boycott, there would already be disharmony in the workplace. I could debate with Senator Sherry—I am not going to do so tonight—the extent to which putting in a picket line would increase that.

PARA.TAB: This is about exemption of peaceful picketing. I would have thought that if it were a peaceful picket there would be no disruption to the workplace, but this is interfering with people as they go about their normal business. It could well be that the people carrying that picket have some political axe to grind, some religious axe to grind or something else to grind. This is about intimidating people. It would seem to be a direct interference with the capacity of people to go about their work. Surely people are not exempt if they put up a picket when there is an industrial dispute on the site. From what Senator Sherry said, we could conclude that that is the case, but I do not believe that that is what he meant.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The approach of the government in the bill does allow for peaceful picketing. Senator Crane may or may not agree with the action of picketing, but we do provide for peaceful picketing. That is a philosophical approach to industrial relations that he and I will just have to disagree on.

PARA.TAB: We define peaceful picketing—I think in a very reasoned way—to be obtaining information. The other provisions in proposed subparagraph (a) clearly define what is not acceptable in the context of peaceful picketing in language that I believe is commonly understood. It will be found so by the courts, should there be recourse to them, should people engage in that type of behaviour, as outlined in proposed subparagraph (b).

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed section 162 of this bill highlights what is objectionable about the government's approach to secondary boycotts. This shows that the government is removing the secondary boycott provisions from the trade practices legislation and, in so doing, is substantially watering down the impact and the practical capacity for employers to use that legislation in a practical way.
—Emasculating.

—As Senator Parer says, and as I think I said in my remarks before dinner, it is emasculating the effective use of secondary boycott legislation. It does that in the first part of proposed section 162 by completely removing the capacity to take action against primary boycotts. It removes the capacity of an employer to take any action against primary boycotts, which can be substantially damaging to a business—and, of course, against which it is possible to take action under the existing legislation.

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 162A, which Senator Crane has been dealing with, supposedly allows peaceful picketing for, among other things, the purpose of obtaining information from people wishing to enter or leave the premises or place. For what earthly reason would people want to obtain information from people entering or leaving a premises?

TALK.START.PARA: —To intimidate them.

—Senator Parer's prescience amazes me. I am amazed by how he can know exactly what I am about to say before I have even said it. It shows how blatantly obvious this legislation is and what it is all about. It is about giving more power to trade unions. It is about reducing the capacity of employers to respond to the sort of thuggery that employers had to experience before we ever had primary and secondary boycott provisions written into legislation.

PARA.TAB: The only possible reason that pickets would want to obtain information from people entering or leaving premises is so that they can later exact retribution against those people for the fact that they refused to support the boycott action in which the people picketing the premises were engaging. That is what it is about—so the thugs of the union movement can exact retribution against those innocent people at a later date by seeking information from them, by hassling them, as they enter or leave the premises. Among the various proposed sections that relate to this boycott legislation and the changes that the government is making to it, proposed section 162 is perhaps among the worst of those, and it ought to be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Chapman. I think this is giving a blank cheque to unions. In a moment I would like to press the parliamentary secretary on what amounts to intimidation and what does not amount to intimidation. I would like the parliamentary secretary to give us his view on whether offensive signs telling people that they are scabs amount to intimidation or not.

PARA.TAB: I would like to seek some comment from Senator Bell as well, because this is an issue which simply would not go through if it were not for Senator Bell and his colleagues. There would be no debate in this parliament on this issue if Senator Bell had been true to his tradition and true to the general attitude of his party in the past, which proudly joined with us on a number of occasions to fight the government and the ACTU to prevent them removing sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act.

I know Senator Bell does not like me referring to history, but history is writ large in this chamber with how he and his colleagues joined with us to prevent these very proposed sections which are to be passed in this chamber. I think he is correctly sensitive. I understand Senator Bell's sensitivity every time we press him on this matter and ask him to tell us which of the employer groups support these clauses in the bill—or, indeed, support the bill at all. I have waited in this chamber for a number of hours to hear which of the business groups support his views. We have waited in vain for him to indicate to us which of the small business groups support his actions. I am aware of the views of many business associations. As far as I can read, they are absolutely unanimous that this bill is a disaster.

I wonder where the Australian Democrats get their information. At the end of the day, when the first person in small business is ruined, whose life savings are wiped out, as a result of a secondary boycott—or, indeed, a primary boycott, which my colleague mentioned—in these clauses relating to pickets, I will get up in this parliament and sheet home blame where blame is due. The Australian Democrats, for reasons which I find beyond belief—I can see no advantage to business or to employment and I can see no political advantage—have joined with the ACTU and supported this bill.

Every time Senator Bell gets up and seeks to explain to us that a small company in some area has made some comment to Senator Woodley, it does not seem to be in connection with the issue before us. Senator Bell, you are speaking to your adviser now; he may well be able to assist you more than you are able to assist yourself. In your dealings with small business, your consultation—and I know it was a bit difficult to get a phone call through to you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, however irritating it might be, you are required to address your remarks through the chair. Senator Bell happens to be outside the strict parameters of the Senate, so it is rather difficult to direct your comments to him.

—This is a very serious debate which relates to an issue which goes to the protection of people in small business, the protection of their capital and indeed the protection of their future. We are quite entitled to press the Australian Democrats on this issue. We are entitled to press the Senator Bells of this world and his colleague Senator Kernot on just why they are taking this action. I was very interested in what Senator Chapman had to say. We are going through each of these clauses in detail, and that is appropriate, but the reality is that these arrangements were working perfectly well. There was no need for legislation. These arrangements had been tried over a very long period of time and were working extremely well.

PARA.TAB: Where did the pressure come from to change all this? Why do we have to go through this incredible bureaucratic detail which will have the ultimate effect of paralysing small business, making small business vulnerable to the ravages of the Wally Currans and the John Halfpennys of this world? The answer is that we have to go through this process because Senator Bell and his colleagues have succumbed to the ACTU. I have to tell Senator Sherry—and I say this without breaking any confidences—that his party was basically happy with sections 45D and 45E as they were. Every time Bill Kelty came to the Labor Party, it said, `You can rage on, you can threaten us but, mate'—you guys opposite use `mate' a lot—

TALK.START.PARA: —Comrade!

—They have dropped the term `comrade'. It is a bit unfashionable these days. The Labor Party would say, `Mate, I agree with you, Bill, but we can't get it through the Senate. So let's just drop the issue'. Sections 45D and 45E are there to stay because the Australian Democrats will always support the coalition on sections 45D and 45E. I think those opposite were quite happy to have it there because, at the end of the day, they knew that it stopped rapacious union behaviour.

PARA.TAB: What changed was that Bill Kelty decided, `Let's not waste our time speaking to the government on this. Let's speak to the Australian Democrats'. The ACTU has conducted a three-year campaign trying to convince Senator Bell and his colleagues on this issue. In the privacy of their own rooms, Labor senators would support this. The ACTU knew that the last thing the government wanted was a rogue union movement. Bill Kelty is not stupid; he might be quite contrary to the national interests of this country, but the guy is not stupid. He focused on Senator Bell, and these guys in the Democrats have bought it. The tragedy is that these guys have bought something which the government itself did not want to change, and which we did not want to change.

The Democrats have not consulted with small business. There would be not one business group which would support any clause in this bill. Of course they support the odd amendment because they have to. Anything to ameliorate this bill is infinitely preferred to what exists. It is a great pity that Senator Kernot has done this, because I think she started off quite well. I think people looked at Senator Kernot and said, `Let's face it, this is a vast improvement on what went before'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what they thought.

—Yes, that is what they thought. Senator Kernot has somehow bought this nonsense from the ACTU. She has taken her party further to the left than it actually was. On no other occasion would her party have supported this bill. But that is what the Democrats have done this evening. The onus is on Senator Bell to get up, to go on to the record and to explain to the 800,000 people in small business—the men and women who put their capital on the line—why the Democrats have done this.

PARA.TAB: I would like Senator Sherry to address his mind to clause 162A which refers to conduct which does not involve intimidation. Does directing offensive signs at people walking in amount to intimidation by Senator Sherry's standards?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I did not know Senator Kemp better, I would have thought that he was being a little intimidatory of the Democrats in his comments. It would have been interesting to have videoed his contribution and to have asked people if they had a view that his words were intimidatory within the meaning of this provision in the act. Unfortunately, the question Senator Kemp asked was asked two or three times between 8 o'clock and a quarter to nine.
—But we still haven't got an answer.
—I gave an answer and do not intend to repeat myself.

—I wish to endorse the comments made by Senator Kemp. Senator Bell and the Democrats will wear this on their heads forever. Hopefully, now that we have the minister back we might get more precise answers because I presume that he understands the matter. I refer to clause 162(7)(d), which is an exemption. Could the minister explain whether a boycott could be put on live sheep if their owners constituted a `fourth person'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be some circumstances in which the action that Senator Crane broadly described could come under the exemption and there would be some circumstances where it would not. I am not going to give legal opinions all the way through the debate, but it is conceivable that it could apply. It may not, depending on the circumstances of the case.

—The minister has confirmed my worst fears about this legislation. One would not have expected much more than this from the government. Once again, I ask Senator Bell and the Democrats whether they are going to be party to this business of allowing the live sheep dispute to be revisited? If the Democrats pass this bill, that is what will happen. As I said in the debate the other day, when it comes to loading the sheep at Esperance, I will be back down there again, because I will not tolerate this nonsense.
—So will I.
—Senator Panizza tells me he will be there too. I will sit down if Senator Bell wants to speak, as I am interested in hearing what he has to say.

—I will be happy to address that question. Although I have already answered it three times, I will answer it once again. I only answered it about five times for Senator Kemp. I have said this privately to Senator Crane and I will now say it publicly. As far as the live sheep issue is concerned, I would personally be prepared to take any action whatsoever to participate in a protest to express my opinion that the live sheep issue is a matter of animal welfare. I believe that to express my opinion in any way, shape or form is a fundamental right which I will continue to use. If my action here facilitates other people being able to express their opinions, I feel proud to stand here and do it.

—We have the answer to that. Mark my words: this issue will revisit us. Let us now go to proposed section 163D(4) which relates to disputes totalling 72 hours. As I interpret it—I believe I do so correctly—it in effect states that if a dispute in an organisation runs for less than 72 hours, and another dispute occurs after that time, the second action can be considered by the commission to be cumulative. What happens if it occurs in a different organisation? One organisation may have an action lasting 50 hours and the next one may have another lasting 50 hours a little while later. What situation then exists?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed subsection (4)(c) states that the commission has to form an opinion that the other contravention—that is, the one covered by proposed subsection (4)(b)—is substantially related to the first-mentioned contravention. In other words, people will not be able to play tag in the same dispute just by saying that it was the TWU yesterday, it is another union today and tomorrow there will be another. The commission will have the discretion and the capacity under subsection (4)(c) to be able to take that second contravention, for the purpose of subsection (3)(b), to have occurred when the first-mentioned contravention started; that is, the 72-hour clock continues.

—My only point with regard to that is that we will wait and see. I now move to clause 40, which deals with restriction on certain actions in tort. Once again, I think it is absolutely incomprehensible that we are giving privilege to a group of people in law. We are going to allow them to be immune from legal action for a time because they happen to be involved with the trade union movement. Nobody else in society gets this privilege. Once again, it is total discrimination.

PARA.TAB: I must say—I will keep on repeating this—that the Democrats argue strongly against discrimination on the one hand, yet, with this government, they will be a party to providing the most irresponsible form of discrimination that one could possibly anticipate. Clause 40 probably is the worst of the worst in that sense. It discriminates in favour of a group of people by making them immune from legal action and from the laws that everybody else has to obey. Senator McGauran has to obey those laws, as does Senator Hill and Senator Panizza. Even Senator Bell has to obey those laws, yet he is going to vote for them. Senator McMullan also has to obey them.

The government is creating a situation where a privileged group of people will be given immunity for a time against breaking the law. It is incomprehensible. I do not know, but I do not believe they would have done this in Russia. They had more sense. They did not have to serve particular masters. Actions such as this in relation to tort action really make the mind boggle.

We on this side of the chamber absolutely and totally reject this aspect of the bill. We think that a great wrong is being put in place. The law should at least attempt to deal equally with Australians. This legislation will blatantly favour a privileged group.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly. This is essentially opposition amendment No. 14. I realise that we are not dealing with it in that sense, but I have mentioned it in terms of addressing the paperwork. The government thinks this is an appropriate and balanced position. It does not exclude common law actions; it merely requires pre-litigation conciliation. In those circumstances, it will be seen to work in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: I have been in this parliament for nearly six years. Most times, when a major change is under way, somebody is capable of interpreting it by saying, `If you do this, the sky will fall in'. One day it might. But in these last six years, the sky has not fallen in. I think this will be another safe year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an irrelevant, pathetic answer! I now want to deal with clause 41, which puts some people in a totally different situation in relation to everybody else in terms of the law. Clause 41 repeals sections 311 and 312 of the principal act. I will explain what the government is doing here. Section 311 of the principal act states:

SPEECH.PARA: An organisation or person shall not wilfully contravene an award or an order of the Commission.
Penalty:
(a) in the case of a natural person—$500; and
(b) in the case of a body corporate—$1,000.
Section 312(1) states:
A person who is an officer or agent of an organisation or branch of an organisation bound by an award shall not:
(a) advise, encourage or incite—
It continues down to subsection (h). It then deals with two or three other matters.

PARA.TAB: The government is legalising a union organiser to go into the workplace and incite people to break the law and their award, and to interfere with the business of the businessman. Once again, one must point the finger at Senator Bell and the Democrats. It is a waste of time appealing to the government, because it has already decided that it will give all these privileges in law to its mates, who are the organisers. One can repeat time and again exactly the same words: the government is just giving preference in terms of the law.

We will actually have a situation where the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations are talking about a better industrial system and a more harmonious industrial system yet the government is allowing people to go with immunity on to sites and incite. That is precisely what will happen if we remove these clauses. If that is where Senator Bell and Senator Kernot are leading the Democrats in terms of industrial relations, God help small and big business in this country. Senator Bell should hang his head in shame below that desk. He should not be proud about supporting this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put my head above the desk for a moment. I understand Senator Crane's enthusiasm about this matter. It is a fairly typical opposition situation. The opposition will use any stick to beat the unions. It will never put an old disused stick away just in case it wants to belt the unions again.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Leader of the Opposition interjects from other than his seat, far be it for me to say anything about it. The way Senator Crane has described the industrial relations system is not how it has worked for the last 40 years.
—It is just because the clause is there.

—The clause has not been used because industrial difficulties have been resolved by the orthodox conciliation and arbitration process. There are other remedies for breaches of awards. This is the way people have been working for 30 or 40 years.

PARA.TAB: I know that the opposition believes that any old stick is better than no stick at all. Those opposite may think that they are able to use it sometime to beat the trade union movement. Really that is a pretty old fashioned idea. I have been advised that the employers of Australia have not been using this process since the 1950s. I do not know of anyone who has recently reverted to this sort of process. I think this clause ought to be repealed for those obvious reasons. It is inappropriate in contemporary industrial relations. However, honourable senators are entitled to their views.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately I cannot put my hand on the piece of paper that I had relating to this matter. I will challenge the minister with regard to his last statement. I will pursue it at another time. I put on the public record that I do not believe the minister is right.

PARA.TAB: The minister says that we use this as a stick to beat the unions around the head. That is the typical sort of pathetic answer that one would expect. The removal of these clauses does not allow the ordinary citizen of the land to go into a workplace and carry out these things. These issues are specific to particular cases. If the minister thinks this through he will discover that one of the reasons this clause has had limited use is that the law is in place. People know that if they break the law they will get themselves into a situation where they will be prosecuted. I will leave it at that. If I get the opportunity and I find that piece of paper I referred to, I will put on the public record where we are in respect of these matters.

I have one more matter I will deal with in terms of these clauses. It is difficult when we are dealing with clauses separately and not dealing with them in conjunction with one another. I will deal with the repeal of section 66 of the Public Service Act. I would like to have a better explanation than just saying that we are living in a different world today than we were living in yesterday and a different industrial relations system. It will sure as hell be different in the future because there will be a lot of industrial disruptions because the disciplines in law have been taken away.

Section 66 of the Public Service Act refers to officers taking part in strikes against government. Up until this bill was proclaimed, we had a situation whereby if an officer took part in a strike after being given the opportunity to explain the rationale and reason behind the strike that person could loss their job for taking part. The government is removing this provision. So it is giving officers of the Public Service immunity against the sanction of losing their job for taking strike action.

Once again, I cannot understand why the government would want to remove this particular clause. This also highlights something I said earlier. I read out 10 acts that related to the Industrial Relations Act. In the process of looking further at this bill we have discovered another two bills. It would be rather interesting to know at the end of the day how many acts there really are and why we do not have a consolidated act. I ask the minister why the government is removing this provision from the industrial relations legislation that is before us?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 66 of the Public Service Act is being repealed simply because it is outdated, cumbersome and entirely inappropriate. I do not want to offend Senator Crane's concern that he raised last time I spoke in similar vein. I have to say I cannot absolutely swear that this section has never been used. But I can say that nobody I know and no department involved, neither the Department of Industrial Relations nor the Public Service Commission, has any record of it ever having been used. The simple fact is that this is a hangover from a bygone era.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Act gives the Industrial Relations Commission very wide powers in relation to industrial action in the public sector and the disciplinary provisions of the Public Service Act provide a range of remedies for behaviour which goes outside the bounds of legitimate industrial action. If staff are taking orthodox trade union industrial action then they get dealt with in the orthodox way through the Industrial Relations Act. If they are going beyond that which is reasonable in that circumstance they get dealt with by the Public Service Act in its normal disciplinary provisions. We do not need this particular section which is a relic of a bygone era, the master and servant era, and, to the best of my knowledge, it has never been used.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no other matters that I want to raise at this point. There are many more anomalies in this section. I will wind up my comments by saying that the opposition totally rejects the propositions put in this particular legislation. We have already identified that extensive privilege was being granted to a small number of people. It makes it a nonsense when other honourable senators come in here and put other clauses into the bill to prevent discrimination.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I drew to the minister's attention the live sheep industry—and this will apply to every other industry we want to think about—which will highlight very clearly the fact that this legislation will take us into an era of industrial disputation. I think that is a very sad and sorry thing for Australia. Shame on the government! There is even more shame on the Democrats because they had the opportunity to be consistent with their forefathers in terms of dealing with this legislation. They have determined for whatever reason, with Senator Kernot as their leader, that they are going to abide by the rule of the ACTU. They are not going to look after their natural constituency—that is, small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one question for the minister. Last night I asked the department to provide me with information as to how many lockouts had been recorded by the Department of Industrial Relations over the past 10 years. I think that information was to be given to me today, but I have not got it yet.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there is a letter which I can provide Senator Parer with before the end of the night.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That clauses 36 to 54 stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 55 to 67—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing these clauses. We do not believe that it is necessary to set up a separate court to handle industrial matters. The industrial division of the Federal Court has, with great independence and clarity, handled industrial matters now for a number of years. In fact, the history of the industrial division of the Federal Court goes back to 1978 or thereabouts when Lionel Bowen, on the Labor Party side, made some very interesting comments in the parliament in support of it.

PARA.TAB: This was reinforced once again by Minister Ralph Willis in 1988, just 10 years later. He articulated why the government at that time was not proceeding with an industrial court. The evidence given by the Law Council to the Senate standing committee that dealt with this act made it quite clear that, with a couple of small amendments, the industrial court was, in its view, the best jurisdiction.

There are two principal reasons that I want to put on the record as to why the Law Council thought it was the best jurisdiction. The first relates to the independence of that court and the fact that it is at arm's length from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Secondly, it did not believe it was good for the law making process in this country to have a situation whereby there are specialist courts. We have already canvassed that subject tonight so I will not go over it again. The other point that it raised which is most valid—I would like the minister at the table to address this because it appears that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was either not willing or not capable of doing so—is the issue of the cost of setting up a totally new court, how many people will be involved in it, and what will be the independence of the people who are appointed to the industrial court.

In speaking to this amendment and expressing our strong objection to it and saying that after the next election we will not be continuing with an industrial court, I would like an answer to those questions. They are as follows: what will be the cost; what will be the independence of the appointments to that particular court; where will it be set up; and what will be its structure?

TALK.START.PARA: —Clauses 55 to 67 deal with the establishment of the industrial relations court of Australia. As Senator Crane has indicated, the opposition is vehemently opposed to this initiative of the government's as contained in the legislation. Our opposition is based not simply on our own view of this issue but on the evidence that was presented to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, which inquired into this bill a couple of weeks ago. The evidence presented to that committee clearly indicated that there were dangers in the establishment of this court and that the new court was unnecessary. The Law Council of Australia provided evidence to that committee and it has also provided subsequent correspondence in which it makes very clear its opposition to the establishment of this court. There is no demonstrated need for the establishment of a specialist industrial court. That view has been put very clearly by the Law Council and others.

PARA.TAB: The jurisdiction of the proposed court can be quite readily exercised by the existing industrial division of the Federal Court of Australia. For that reason alone, the court ought not be established. The new court will unnecessarily incur additional expenditure of taxpayers' money to operate, both in terms of the costs of setting up the court and its continuing operation, including its location, administration and staffing. We have heard no justification whatsoever from the minister for the establishment of this court, which effectively duplicates the existing industrial division of the Federal Court.

There is also the question of who will constitute the new court. Under these proposals, a judge of the court may also be a judge of the Federal Court. Again, it raises the question: why cannot these same judges simply continue to perform the role that they perform as Federal Court judges within that industrial division of the Federal Court?

Senator Crane has already raised the issue of the perceived lack of independence of this court. Perhaps that is the most damning charge that can be made against this proposal. At the moment the industrial division of the Federal Court, being part of that Federal Court structure, has absolutely guaranteed independence, as our courts and our judges ought to have. Once this court is moved under the Industrial Relations Act and becomes part of the industrial relations specialised jurisdiction, there is always the question about its degree of independence and its degree of impartiality as compared with the existing Federal Court structure.

This issue raises the question of courts being linked to programs and policies of particular governments, rather than being part of the mainstream system of justice—the mainstream court system. It simply serves to underline the ease with which they may be abolished by a government of a different persuasion in the future. Senator Crane has made the opposition's attitude to this matter very clear. When we come to government, as we surely will after the next election, given the recent results of state elections around Australia—particularly in my own state of South Australia last Saturday—we will abolish this unnecessary structure. Although we will abolish it because we are opposed to its being established and believe it is unnecessary, the very capacity that a future government has to abolish this industrial court simply highlights its vulnerability—a vulnerability that does not exist under the mainstream court structure of the High Court and the Federal Court.
There is no justifiable reason for the establishment of the industrial court. That is why we oppose it and seek, by amending this bill, to remove these clauses that will establish that court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to raise my voice of concern about this proposal to establish a specialist court in the industrial relations field. I would like Senator McMullan to indicate to us the need for the establishment of this new court. Is there some suggestion that the industrial division of the Federal Court has not performed its duties properly? Is there any complaint about that division of the Federal Court? Why is it necessary to establish a completely new court system when, from all sides, it would seem that the current industrial division of the Federal Court has performed its duties well and has been judged to be fairly concerned about the issues brought before it? Is there something particular which the industrial division of the Federal Court cannot do that this new court can do?

PARA.TAB: Like my colleagues Senator Crane and Senator Chapman, I ask the minister to give some indication of the costs of establishing this new court and to indicate from where the judges of this new industrial court will be drawn. I understand that a judge of the new court may be a judge of the Federal Court. If that is to be the case, it could well be asked: why cannot those same judges who currently sit on the industrial division continue to play that role as part of the Federal Court rather than being appointed to the new industrial court?

In its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and in correspondence to many honourable senators, the Law Council of Australia has indicated its opposition to this proposal. It is an opposition that is not predicated on any political motive. In fact, the Law Council specifically, and by its constitution, never becomes involved in party political matters. It has an interest in the proper and fair distribution and treatment of the law. It is for that reason that the Law Council has become very seriously concerned at the proposals in this legislation, a concern which I share and which all of those on our side share as well.
I ask Senator McMullan to indicate to us why this new court is necessary. I am not sure whether the Democrats are supporting us on this—I assume they will be supporting us.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could assume they would if they were sensible!

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Order! Senator Chapman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to get some assistance. Perhaps it would be interesting to—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot is a bit spirited tonight.
—Senator Macdonald, please continue your remarks.

—Maybe Senator Kernot will tell us why this new establishment is needed. I understand that $164 million has been set aside for the Federal Court this year. Why does that have to be duplicated or added to for the creation of the new court? Senator Kernot might tell us that. I know her party is one that likes increasing taxes all the time. Perhaps it is just part of its psyche to add more impost on small business. It is a high tax party.
—They are a high tax party.

—Yes, they are. I often say that if the Democrats applied for membership of the Labor Party they would be rejected because they are too left wing even for the Labor Party these days. It would be interesting to hear their views as well. I await anxiously Senator McMullan's explanation of the need, cost and details of this proposal.

—I support previous speakers in their opposition to the establishment of this court. Like Senator Ian Macdonald, I fail to see where the government has outlined any reason for the establishment of such a court. I start by looking at the committee's report on the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. Nowhere in that document can I see any reason for the establishment of this court.
—Maybe we could get it from the dissenting report.

—I read the dissenting report with interest and cogent reasons were offered in it as to why this court should not be established. For a start, there are 164 million reasons. As mentioned by Senator Ian Macdonald, $164 million has been provided in the budget for the Federal Court from the taxpayer of this country. I ask the Minister: where will this new court advance the rights of workers? Where has the Federal Court fallen down in its exercise of the industrial division? Where will this court advance the interests of Australian taxpayers, the Australian citizens? Where is the reason for the establishment of this court? To date, the government has not offered any reason at all. It has not answered any of these questions.

PARA.TAB: What I would like to know from the minister is how will this court do things differently? Obviously it must do, otherwise why set up a new court? Where is the reason for having a new court because of this new legislation? Since 1976 the Federal Court has accomplished itself admirably in the industrial jurisdiction, and I have never heard any complaint about it. Not once. Where has the government previously said that the Federal Court was not doing its job?

I can only assume that the government must have ulterior reasons for setting up this court. The establishment of a specialist court—a specialist judicial body of this nature—makes it more vulnerable to government interference. It makes it vulnerable to becoming an arm of policy and not the judiciary. That is one of the very reasons why the Law Council of Australia has opposed this very measure. I ask the minister concerned: has he had any regard to the submissions of the Law Council of Australia? Does he disagree with what the council says? If he does, why?
