As Senator Ian Macdonald says, it is not often that the Law Council of Australia comes out and makes such a bold statement. One can only assume that Mr Mansfield QC, the president of that august body, has seen the prospect of a major intrusion into the rights of citizens of this country. I therefore ask the Democrats, because they always take human rights so seriously, to hearken to the fact that this could be a body which could be vulnerable to government control. Who knows—maybe not this government; perhaps other governments of different persuasions. We know not which.

The whole idea of the judiciary as we know it in this country is to insulate it from both the executive and the legislative arms of government. That is the essential core—the essential foundation—of this country. I do not think it has been said that the Federal Court has been influenced to date. Perhaps that could be the reason why the government wants to set up a specialist judicial body.

For those reasons, I fail to see any merit whatsoever in the establishment of this court. On the basis of cost to the taxpayer, there are the 164 million reasons that I mentioned. There are also other reasons including the dark prospect of a judicial body becoming an arm of policy and vulnerable to government interference; and the prospect that even the rights of workers and the rights of Australian citizens might be intruded upon by virtue of setting up a small specialist judicial body which is easier to control.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —One would imagine from having heard the speeches that there is something unusual about Australia having a specialist industrial relations court—that it has never happened before or that it does not happen anywhere else. There was a specialist industrial relations court from 1956 to 1977. There are specialist industrial courts in the Liberal governed state of New South Wales and there has always been one in Western Australia in the time that I can remember, as there are in South Australia and Queensland. Let us get some of the hyper-enthusiasm out of this and get down to deal with it in some sort of calm and rational manner.

PARA.TAB: Of course there are different views about whether or not there should be this separate court. Some of the views that have been expressed have some legitimacy in the balance, and it is a decision on balance as to whether we should go in one direction or the other. If we strip away all the hyperbole that was thrown around a bit, I understand that there is a case for and against.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sum of $164 million is not hyperbole.
—And it has nothing to do with this matter, but it is just a nice figure; throw it around. It might get Senator Ellison's name in the paper but I doubt it.

PARA.TAB: The government believes that this court will make a significant contribution to the proper conduct of industrial relations. It will have a wider jurisdiction than the Federal Court. It will have a different structure involving judicial registrars which is potentially quite important. It is a growing area of jurisdiction. For example, it will cover termination of employment matters under the minimum entitlements provision and constitutional matters arising under the act that are remitted from the High Court; and it will also take over the responsibilities of the Industrial Relations Commission for reviewing and rectifying harsh and unfair contracts involving persons working as independent contractors.

I accept that people will have an alternative view. The government's judgment on the evidence is that, on balance, given the way in which this area of jurisdiction is broadening and the potential for judicial registrars to play important roles in some of the matters that will develop over the years to come, the approach—which I reiterate is not an unusual approach in either contemporary Australian practice or Australian industrial history—will deliver a better contribution to the proper conduct of industrial relations. That is why we have put forward this proposal. That is why on balance we think it is the preferred approach and why we will be persisting with these clauses in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a nice little political speech for Senator McMullan's union mates but it did not really tell us anything. My colleagues and I pointed out that no justification for this new court has been given in either the second reading speech or the explanatory memorandum. I will tell the chamber what Senator McMullan said in response to our quite legitimate questions as to why it is needed.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan said that it has happened before. I assume he is saying that, therefore, it must be right this time. He said it has happened in Western Australia, New South Wales, South Australia and Queensland. I assume his argument is that, therefore, it is right here. He says the new court will have wider jurisdiction. Why not imbue the industrial division of the current court with wider jurisdiction, if that were a problem, although I would not have thought it was. That is easy to fix under a current set-up without having to go through the red tape and cost of forming a new court.

Senator McMullan said that judicial registrars would play an important role. But neither he nor the minister's second reading speech have given any indication of what role those judicial registrars will play and where that role cannot be performed by the current industrial division of the Federal Court. He said the new court would deal with constitutional matters. Perhaps Senator McMullan does not know, but the High Court already deals with constitutional matters and so does the Federal Court and, in certain circumstances, so do state supreme courts. So that does not seem to be an argument.

Senator McMullan said that this new court could deal with harsh and unconscionable contracts. In case Senator McMullan does not know, the Federal Court and, in fact, all the courts of the land, currently deal with harsh and unconscionable contracts in the general contract law; and the current industrial division of the Federal Court would have no difficulty in dealing with that because the Federal Court currently deals with those sorts of matters.

Senator McMullan dismisses all our arguments by saying, `We think it will be better'. Simply saying the words, `We think it will be better' is supposed to convince us—and, I assume, the Democrats—that this is the right way to go. He gave us no argument, no explanation at all, as to why it is needed, why the current industrial division of the Federal Court cannot do it, and why the Australian taxpayer has to be put to this expense of setting up another court to do exactly the same things that the current industrial division can do.

I want to be convinced. I suspect we are going to lose on the numbers, but would Senator McMullan please let us know why he wants to do it rather than simply saying, `It's better'. Can he just give us some examples—some arguments—as to why it will do a better job than the current court, bearing in mind that the current court is already established. This court will take a lot of money to set up. It has all the problems which Senator Ellison, Senator Crane and Senator Chapman mentioned in earlier speeches. It has the downsides; it does not seem to have the upsides. If there are upsides, would Senator McMullan please let us know about them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 9.40 p.m., we have been debating this bill for a very long time, Mr Brereton has spoken about this matter on several occasions and I have given some explanations about it which I do not intend to reiterate. People are entitled to form an alternative view if they wish. Minister Brereton has also stated—and I am happy to reiterate it—that the cost of this industrial court has not been finally settled because it is not possible to do that yet. There is, for example, the necessity—
—So we have a blank cheque?

—If Senator Crane thinks that everything that is set up for which the final cost is not detailed to the last dollar is a blank cheque, he does not understand. The court will share, to the maximum extent possible, the existing facilities of the Federal Court. The Chief Justice of the new court, when he or she is appointed, will need to conclude arrangements with the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, which will have a significant impact on its costs, as will decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal about things like salaries of registrars. I cannot give those opposite a detailed answer on that, and they know I cannot; but I knew that they were going to ask that question, so that is the best answer I can give.

—I ask the Democrats, if they are going to support the establishment of an industrial relations court, whether they can give us some reasons why, and tell us how it could do a better job than the Federal Court. Perhaps they could enlighten us.

—I think the legislation was changed in 1977 and included setting up the industrial division of the Federal Court. It is fair to say that practitioners in that area are neither strong supporters nor opponents of the industrial division of the Federal Court. There are some extraordinarily competent people in that court; there are others who are less so. The opportunity now exists for skilled persons to be appointed to this new court with its expanded functions. If any government—and I do not expect this government will—stacked it with deadbeats, it would falter and fail, and so would a lot of the work that has been done with regard to this legislation. The credibility of the legislation, to some extent, will depend upon the goodwill and competence of those involved.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister a specific question with regard to the old legislation and the ability of the industrial division of the Federal Court to give advisory opinions. Section 46 of the legislation as it now stands enables the commission to refer a question of law arising from a matter before the commission for an opinion to the court. Perhaps now or at some other time, the minister might be able to provide me with information as to exactly on how many occasions this has occurred. Frankly, I do not believe it has occurred; it may have, but I do not believe it has. It might be even more appropriate for the new court to exercise that power because, as the minister has said, there is a whole range of new matters and functions which the new specialised court will be required to consider.

I acknowledge the comments and statements that have made by opposition senators. They are concerned about a change in this area. But I do not know why they are necessarily so much in favour of the industrial division of the Federal Court. As I indicate—and I think it is fair to say—if the government judiciously makes appointments which are clearly appointments of persons who are the best people for the job and for the credibility of the new court, it will succeed; if it does not, it will not, and we will be back here again with this division of the legislation before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not bring it back.
—The government might not bring it back, but pressure from employers and organisations of employees and perhaps employees themselves might force the government to bring it back.

—I thank Senator Harradine for attempting to take over the minister's role and trying to explain this. The minister, again, simply said, `Mr Brereton spoke about it; I am not going to tell you people'. The fact that this is a chamber of the parliament and we are entitled to ask these questions and understand these matters does not seem to rate with the minister at all. So I do thank Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: As I am not getting any sense or any cogent arguments from the minister, perhaps Senator Harradine could help the minister by explaining to me why the skilled persons that he talks about could not be appointed. I think that was his main point on why this new court should be set up. Senator Harradine is saying that skilled persons can be appointed to it. Why cannot skilled persons be appointed to the industrial division of the Federal Court? Is Senator Harradine suggesting that the current people in the industrial division of the Federal Court are not skilled persons? If that is the case, I think he would be one of the few people in Australia who does suggest that. The industrial division of the Federal Court is well regarded and it is composed of skilled persons. But the government can appoint skilled persons to the industrial division of the Federal Court as it can appoint skilled persons to the new labour court.

Senator Harradine has asked, `Why do we object to it?'. I simply say to him: why change the current system that seems to have worked well? Sure, maybe if we did change it, it would not really be too bad, but why change it? Apart from Senator Harradine's skilled persons argument, I have not heard any other. It is the only argument that has been given. At least he has given one argument; Senator McMullan has given us no argument, and I am still waiting to hear why the Democrats support it. Maybe Senator Bell can throw some light onto the subject of why it is necessary.

We are told, `Well, maybe it would not do any harm'. Maybe it would not, but why change a system which has worked and which is acknowledged to have worked well and fairly at no extra cost? To establish a new court will be very expensive. I would appreciate Senator Harradine's and Senator Bell's assistance because I am obviously not getting much assistance from the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not here to speak on behalf of the minister. I think the minister has satisfactorily made certain comments in respect of this division. I am sorry: I did say `skilled'; I should have said `specialised'.

—I want to expand on the remarks of my colleague, Senator Ian Macdonald. There is nothing that one could not do by amending the relevant legislation governing the Federal Court, or in fact its rules, that one could do in the establishment of this new court. What Senator Macdonald says is quite right: if we need specialised officers, if we need registrars with a certain skill or background, we could simply amend the legislation and the pertinent rules.

PARA.TAB: It has been put to me that this new court could provide greater access. I fail to see why, but if there is something wrong with the Federal Court in that it does not offer enough access, perhaps we could simplify that part of the Federal Court rules dealing with the forms and filing of papers at the court to make it much easier for people to file things in person, to conduct their own matters. That could all be very easily done without the millions of dollars of expense that a new court is going to cost the Australian taxpayer.

With 15 years legal experience, I have seen that we can simplify and make courts perform a lot better by simply amending the rules under which they operate and the legislation which governs them. That is the way to go. We do not have to set up an entirely new court system with an entirely new set of forms, bureaucracy and judicial officers. We would have to find such a court a new building and new staff to work at the counters—and that all costs a lot of money. At the moment we have that set up very well in the industrial division of the Federal Court of Australia.

The so-called reasons that have been put to me thus far have not convinced me in any way. In fact, they have merely made me think that perhaps we could streamline or amend the existing system in some way and accommodate those concerns, but without the extra cost. I could also say to the chamber that there is no doubt that by making these amendments we would have a much better system because we already have one in place.

It always takes time for most new institutions to thrash out problems. So for the first year or so the consumers—if we could call them that, and this is particularly so with courts—run into the problems while the new court sorts itself out. I refer to the Family Court in 1975 and the problems it has had. Look at how many amendments there have been to the Family Law Act and to the rules of that court. All of that has come about with the benefit of experience.

I am not against any changes for the better but if there has been some experience which has shown that we should amend the rules of the industrial division of the Federal Court, then so be it. But so far nothing has come close to convincing me that a new court should be set up. In fact, the problem with this country is that there are too many judicial bodies being set up, so much so that I would say that we are running into jurisdictional problems. We have administrative appeals tribunals, equality of opportunity tribunals, small debt courts, local courts, district courts, supreme courts, the Federal Court, the High Court, the Family Court—the list goes on.

It all sounds very nice; it sounds fantastic when one puts it in terms of human rights but, at the end of the day, the people concerned have to live with that system. They have to find out which courts they have to go to. They try to avoid the cost of engaging the services of a solicitor by going to a body, only to be told, `I'm sorry; we can only go that far because that is the end of our jurisdiction. You have to go down the hall to another body and apply there'.

That is what happens in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. People think they can lodge a complaint but then they are told, `No, we do not have jurisdiction. You have to go somewhere else. You have to go via the Social Security Appeals Tribunal'. So, at the end of day, the government is thoroughly confusing the average citizen; it is making it harder. In fact, what it is doing is making a bonanza for the lawyers. The more courts and institutions we have to confuse people, the better it is for lawyers because, at the end of the day, the individual will have to go to a lawyer.

Believe you me, I am telling honourable senators that from 15 years experience. There were not as many courts and bodies 15 years ago. It was not as complicated, confusing and convoluted as it is today. So all these things start out with the greatest of intentions but they never end up serving the purpose for which they set out to achieve in the first instance. Unless someone else can come up with a better reason, it has me tossed as to why the government should set up a new court when simple amendments could easily do the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I support the remarks of my colleagues on this issue. I suspect that we should not beat around the bush too much. There is a real problem with the creation of a new court. There is a feeling—I think probably a justifiable feeling—that people who will be appointed to this court will be in sympathy with perhaps the philosophy of the ACTU and will adopt an approach which, I think, probably will be out of kilter with what mainstream Australia would want.

PARA.TAB: But this is an important issue. I have listened carefully to the debate. I agree with Senator Ellison; I am not at all convinced that Senator McMullan has been able to explain carefully to us why the industrial division, which exists now, is not suitable. Again, we have been subjected to a bit of unpleasant verbiage from Senator Bell in this debate. This would not be an issue, this would not occur, if the Australian Democrats were not supporting the measure. I think we are entitled to a full explanation from Senator Bell as to why his party is supporting this.

The Law Council, as Senator Bell will be aware, has made a very comprehensive submission as to why this should not occur. I just hope that this is not just an another part of the blank cheque which the Democrats seem to have given to the government on this issue. I think it is important, as a matter of record, that if Senator Bell believes in it, he should have the guts to stand up and tell us why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Provocative though Senator Kemp is, he has yet to see the result of fully intimidating somebody who is not easy to rile. The fact is that several speeches were made on this matter in the second reading debate. If Senator Kemp's interest is professed to be real and not just a series of the usual games he plays in this place, the lack of seriousness with which he approaches this matter can be illustrated by the lack of attention he pays to answers. I counted the times I actually answered one of Senator Kemp's previous questions. It was five, yet still we had the same garbage trotted out.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion the answer has been given and I think it is quite clear. I indicated on behalf of the Democrats in relation to this proposition that, if this court is to be operated in the way described by the minister, we hope that he will take account of the need to operate such a court with a minimum of cost and procedural fuss and bother.

In the negotiations which took place, in which I encouraged the minister in the formulation of this proposed legislation to consider various matters and also to consult with employer groups, one of the very important concessions that was made in response to the argument that was put by the Democrats, in line with that which I have just described—the need for a minimum of costs and procedural matters—was that judicial registrars will be established. We believe that judicial registrars will have the capacity to deliver more rapid and less costly access both to employer groups and to those who are aggrieved by what virtually are small claims.

It is with that satisfaction that we understand the minister's true motive in establishing this special court; that is, to serve the purposes that Senator Harradine hinted at and also the purposes specifically outlined by the minister in his second reading speech. If Senator Kemp needs to come in here and adopt intimidatory language and make his usual set of vague assertions and inflammatory remarks just to get what has already been said said again, then I do not see any need to respond any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not heard Senator Bell say anything about this matter in the committee stage before. I thought that was the first time he spoke. Maybe he mentioned it at the second reading stage.
—In my speech at the second reading stage.

—I hope Senator Bell gave a more persuasive argument. As I paraphrase his speech, it simply pointed out that he has `negotiated' a court that will be run inexpensively. I point out to Senator Bell, in the hope that it may, at this final hour, have some impact on him—also to Senator Harradine, whom I really would like to consider these matters—that proposed section 362(3) indicates who can be a judge of the court. It states:

PARA.TAB: (3) a person may be appointed as a Judge only if the person:
(a) is or has been a Judge of a prescribed court; or
(b) has been enrolled for at least 5 years as a legal practitioner of the High Court or the Supreme Court of a State or Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The judges, via proposed section 365, shall be paid the same salary and expenses as apply to a judge of the Federal Court. So there will not be any savings there because the judges will be paid at exactly the same rate.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the registrars, as outlined at proposed section 381. The registrars of the proposed court will be required to have the same qualifications. They have to have been a judge of a prescribed court or enrolled for at least five years as a legal practitioner. Senator Bell says that their remuneration and allowances—I think this is what he hangs his hat on—will be less. But, according to proposed section 383(1):

SPEECH.PARA: A Judicial Registrar is to be paid such remuneration as the Remuneration Tribunal determines.

Senator Bell is a recipient of a determination of the Remuneration Tribunal. I will guarantee to him that the registrars will not get a lesser salary than he is getting. In fact, I suggest that it will be considerably more. So there is not going to be any saving there with the judicial registrars.

PARA.TAB: I refer Senator Bell and Senator Harradine to proposed section 401, which deals with the personnel of the court, apart from the judges and the registrar. Quite clearly, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are the following officers of the Court:

PARA.TAB: (a) a District Registrar of the Court for each District Registry;
(b) such Deputy Registrars and Deputy District Registrars as are necessary;
(c) the Sheriff of the Court;
(d) such Deputy Sheriffs as are necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: And so it goes on. So there is a completely new set-up with all the paraphernalia needed to run an Australian court.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell cannot tell me that one can do that cheaply or without cost. Certainly it cannot be done less expensively than by adopting the current court system, the Industrial Division of the Federal Court, which, as I say—and nobody has disputed this—has been well regarded and has performed its duties with skill and learning. There simply is no reason to change what is there, a court that has performed properly, to put in this new court.

I can only assume, unless someone can give me some answers to this, that Senator Kemp is right and that it is simply a court to which the Labor Party will appoint its mates to ensure that it can influence the decisions of a specialist court since it finds itself unable to influence the decisions of the Federal Court of Australia. If that is the reason, it is another sad day for Australia in relation to the way this government deals with the judicial system.

I make a final plea to Senator Harradine and the Democrats to seriously ask themselves: what this new court will give us that the current Industrial Division does not give us; what skilled personnel the new court will have which the current division either does not have or will not get; and why we have to pay all that money for a new court when we have the court set-up currently sitting there as part of the Federal Court?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In normal circumstances, I would tend to agree with the proposition of not changing what is currently occurring. But the answer to Senator Ian Macdonald is that this new industrial relations court will be a specialised court. If we look at the Federal Court of Australia annual report 1992-93, we will see that the current Industrial Division is not necessarily served by persons who are specialist in this particular area.
—They have had a lot of practice.

—As I have said before, there is really no great support, nor great opposition I suppose, to the current Industrial Division of the Federal Court. But page 2 of the annual report of the Federal Court of Australia points out that there are 34 judges of the Federal Court, and they are listed on pages 3 and 4. The list provides details relating to each judge and any other commissions held on Australian courts and tribunals. Most judges are assigned to both the General and Industrial Divisions, so in that sense it is not a specialist operation.

PARA.TAB: There are 29 judges with primary commissions on the court—judges whose primary responsibility is as a judge of the Federal Court. The remaining five judges have primary commissions or appointments elsewhere. The interesting part about this aspect of the report is on page 5, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: As can be seen from the variety and range of commissions and appointments, the judges of the Court are required to devote considerable time to other courts and tribunals.
So essentially it is not a specialist function.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can appoint new ones to it.
—But it is not a specialist function.
—You can appoint specialists.

—I heard what Senator Macdonald said about its being open to the government to appoint people. I notice that the last appointees to the Federal Court were Anthony Phillip Whitlam and Margaret Joan Beazley. That is no reflection on those two persons, of course. All I say—and I come back to it again—
—That proves the point exactly.

—I will not say what some people in the industrial sphere, both employers and unions, say about some judges, and I am not reflecting on these two, because they probably have not been tried out. If the government stacks this court with deadbeats, it will lose credibility, and so will much of this legislation.
—Why take the risk?

—I think it is important for employers, as well as unions and employees, that we do have specialists in this area who will be subject to the approval or disapproval of their peer specialists. If the government is prudent, it will ensure that those people who are appointed are specialist in the industrial relations area and are people of great integrity and competence. If it does not, as I said before, we will be back here again discussing this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —We very strongly oppose this clause. I ask the government: why should an organisation of employers have to inform the Industrial Registrar when it receives a resignation from a member? That is an absolute breach of privacy. If a person wishes to resign from a particular organisation, it is his privilege to do so with privacy. We do not see anything in this bill which says that members of a union have to report to the Industrial Registrar upon resignation.

PARA.TAB: Why is it necessary for the government to seek this information? That is a very legitimate question. Is there some ulterior motive behind it? There is certainly no rationale for it. How will this information be used? Who does it benefit to have an employer's name put forward? What is the necessity for seeking this information? I see Senator Burns and Senator Murphy shaking their heads.

I am pleased to see that Senator Kernot is in the chamber. She totally sold out on this bill and has become a puppet of the ACTU in the process. I thought that the Democrats stood for the rights of the individual. This part of the legislation means that the name of every employer who resigns from an employer organisation will become public. I would like the minister to explain why this is necessary. I think it is a total breach of the privacy and the rights of the individual.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the simplest of all matters. As I would have thought Senator Crane would know, many employers get their respondency to an award by virtue of their membership of a relevant organisation. If they resign from the organisation, their workers are in danger of losing the protection of the award unless the employee organisation concerned gets the opportunity to protect its members' interests under the award. Happenstance should not affect people's industrial relations situation. If there is some matter of substance that means that the award should be varied or that people's conditions should be varied, that is a legitimate matter for the normal industrial processes to take care of. But the mere matter of an individual resigning from an employer organisation should not affect the respondency and award rights of those who work for that person. It is a straightforward, simple, but important industrial point.
—Senator Crane knows that because he heard evidence to that effect before the committee.
—I would suggest that if Senator Murphy wishes to speak to this clause he can do so in a proper manner, not try to deliver some backhand lecture across the table.
—You were caught out.

—I was absolutely and totally not caught out. Senator McMullan gave a very weak, unnecessary answer. The fact is that even if an employer does resign from his organisation, that does not stop his obligations under an award, under the law of the land. Senator Burns and Senator Murphy know that. If one employs somebody, it does not matter whether one is a member of an organisation or not. One cannot pay people less than the equivalent to that which they would get under the award, nor can one not give them what is put down in law. Senator Murphy stated that himself in the committee hearings.
—What about state laws?

—The states have their laws and their way of dealing with it. Senator Murphy should not try to mix up the state situation and the federal situation. In Western Australia this matter is covered by law. Senator Murphy should know that because he claims to be an expert. This measure is simply a breach of privilege. It is not necessary and it should be rejected out of hand. I appeal to Senator Bell at this late stage to join us, to reconsider his position and to get this nonsense out of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are voting against Part 9 of the bill. We do not believe that the government has made the correct decision. It has been made for the wrong reasons. It has been made to punish the ACCI because it supported the opposition at the last election.

PARA.TAB: The thuggery arises when people stand up and say that they prefer a particular position. Any reputable government, having survived an election, should govern for the whole of Australia. If the government thinks it is beneficial to change the National Labor Consultative Council, it should do it through a proper structure of negotiation with the parties. Other parties might well be interested or have expertise, knowledge or a contribution to make. It should be done through a proper process.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be done through the proper processes of consultation. It is interesting to note that this amendment is adjusting in a mandatory fashion the membership of the employer side of the equation. It is not addressing the trade union movement side of the equation. As such, we reject it. The government should think this one through again. If it believes that it is in the interests of industrial relations in this country it should do it through a proper process, not by just decreeing that this shall happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is funny that after all the slings and arrows those who perpetrate them are not here to hear this. I agree with everything that Senator Crane has said and fully support the amendment. We recognise, as the coalition does, that this process is taking place without sufficient consultation and without considering the role that is performed by the existing members of the National Labour Consultative Council. A review by the Department of Industrial Relations was conducted of the membership of the National Labour Consultative Council on 17 September 1992. Page 10 of that review states:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the ILO Constitution, the CAI—
which has become the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry—
and the ACTU, as the most representative organisations of employers and workers, have a particular standing in the Australian context and broadening the membership of the IAC—
that is another argument—
could be construed as interfering in their rights.

I suggest that that assessment would apply equally to the National Labour Consultative Council. I could read other excerpts from this review to demonstrate that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has well represented not just employer groups but also commerce and industry in general. It has acted as the spokesperson on behalf of commerce and industry particularly well. Perhaps it has fulfilled that role too well and perhaps that has motivated this; I do not know. What I do know is that there has not been sufficient public debate or discussion of this move by the government. We fully support the amendment moved by Senator Crane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having exhorted others to brevity, I will not take long in capitulating. I need to say a couple of things. I reject the explanations put forward for the outcome. I accept that the amendment will be carried. We will see what happens after that with the National Labour Consultative Council. The simple question is: why should there be six representatives of the ACCI, one from the MTIA and none from the Chamber of Manufactures? What is the logic behind that? There is none. It has grown like Topsy. If one were setting up a new body today, as we are doing in this legislation, one would not say, `We'll have six from the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, none from the Chamber of Manufactures and one from the MTIA'. It is all arbitrary and inappropriate. That is the basis of it. People can get themselves in a lather about all sorts of other explanations. I understand the arithmetic of this place and we will not be dividing on it.
—Why have five members been nominated by the ACTU? You're shot in the foot.

—No other employee organisation is seeking to have part of the funds. There will be five employer organisations and five employee organisations. No organisation is competing with the ACTU to be part of that five. But many organisations are aspiring to represent the employer point of view on the NLCC.

—I was right the first time and I was right the second time. It is too late in the day for me to explain it to Senator Crane, but I will try again tomorrow morning. I accept that we will lose this amendment. We will not divide on it, but we are opposed to it.

Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to make two or three comments with regard to the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. The opposition regrets that the government has gone down this path. We do not believe that it will achieve the objectives that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) set out to achieve on 21 August 1993. In fact, it will put privilege in law for a select group in this country. Never in the history of this nation has there been so much protection and privilege put into the law in favour of one group. It is interesting to note that when we started—
—Come on!
—Senator Burns can rabbit on all he likes, but he should look at the facts.
—Master and servant.

—What a load of rubbish. We are not dealing with master and servant now. I cannot believe this. I will make a few concluding remarks. Senator Burns wants to carry on all night. This legislation is about giving privilege to a select group in the community. Australia will pay an enormous price for that.

PARA.TAB: I want to put it clearly on the record that the opposition is not opposed to unions but it is opposed to unions or anybody else in the community being given privilege over other groups. This legislation is about the survival of the trade union movement. Today 70 per cent of the work force—and that figure is growing—choose not to join a union. This bill will not enhance flexibility in the work place. In fact it is so bad that it will drive people away.

The one thing that was noticeable in all the questioning of honourable senators tonight is that when I put the proposal to Senator McMullan whether it will be possible again to put boycotts against live sheep without fair protection under boycott law, the answer was yes in some circumstances. We know that that will be widespread.

Finally, I express the opposition's deepest regret at the capitulation of the new Democrats, led by Senator Kernot, to the ACTU. They have now, by voting for this legislation, abandoned the small and large business sector in this country. They have also abandoned those 70 per cent of workers who choose not to be members of a union.

If it were not so serious one could laugh about it. If Shakespeare had been alive today his latest comedy would have been one of political life in Australia—the trilogy of the ACTU, the Labor Party and its puppy dog left faction, the Australian Democrats. That is what he would be writing today. One must not leave out the wonderland twins, Tweedledum and Tweedledee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use this opportunity to remind the Senate of part of the Hansard report of the proceedings of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training's inquiry into the operation of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act 1974. I say that for accuracy. During the debate on this matter one of the fundamentals upon which part of my contribution was based was an assessment of the genesis of those very sections. At the time of making that assessment I indicated that my assessment was based on evidence given to the committee. I will read into Hansard part of the record of that inquiry because it demonstrates that my assessment was accurate. In evidence we were told:

PARA.TAB: Secondary boycotts in the pre-1977 era, in the area in which I—

SPEECH.PARA: I will acknowledge shortly the person who gave this evidence—

was involved—which is across all industries as virtually every industry in Tasmania comes within the membership of the Confederation of Industries—were the rule rather than the exception. They were almost a daily occurrence. They invariably took the form, quite crudely, of a black ban imposed on a target. The objective invariably related to something to do with union membership or demarcation. On occasions, there were other issues such as shop trading hours. But, invariably, it came back to union membership agreements and/or demarcation issues.

That is essentially how I described it. That was evidence given to the committee by Mr Tim Abey, Chief Industrial Advocate of the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. I do not wish to make a meal of that. It was for the sake of accuracy. That assessment was questioned by other speakers in the debate. The Democrats stand by the basis for our assessment of this bill and support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this third reading debate I want to express my extreme disappointment that this legislation, as it has passed the second reading and committee stages, will probably pass through the third reading stage and pass into law. It will damage the fabric of industrial relations in this country and ultimately the capacity of this country to provide a stable environment for business and economic growth and the provision of jobs which this country so desperately needs.

PARA.TAB: We have now spent four days debating the various clauses of this legislation in the committee stage. It ought to be noted that this legislation has come out of the committee stage worse than when it went in. The purpose of the committee stage of debate in parliament is to improve legislation and to make it better than when it entered the committee stage. Because of the amendments that the government and Democrats have successfully moved to this legislation over the last four days, we find the anomalous position that this legislation actually came out of the committee stage worse than it went into it.

TALK.START.PARA: —A coalition of conspiracy.

—It is a coalition of conspiracy. It is to be severely regretted that the committee processes of the Senate have been abused in this way. Throughout this debate we have indicated that there is substantial opposition to this legislation especially from the small business sector and also the large business sector.

PARA.TAB: In the concluding stages of the debate I want to read into the record a letter that I received from a chief executive of one of the major motor vehicle component manufacturers in this country. It is a very successful company. This company exports its products and is highly respected in the community. This letter reinforces the stupidity of this legislation. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is extremely damaging for the future of this country and I am surprised and amazed that more people, particularly the Chief Executives of major corporations, are not standing up and objecting. It will do nothing to attract investment in this country, and will certainly ensure that Australia largely misses out on the growth opportunities in the Asian region at large.

By committing Australia to an inflexible industrial relations system the `reforms' will ensure that our standard of living, relating to other countries, continues to decline, whilst our unemployment rate remains high.
The lack of support from business at large is most disappointing and perhaps reflects a lack of understanding of the `reforms' in some quarters.
Please continue to do whatever you can to prevent this legislation from passing in its present form.
Kind regards.
ANDREW W GWINNETT
He is the Chairman of the Arrowcrest Group. As I said, it is one of the major successful manufacturers and exporters of motor vehicle components in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has sought to do what we could to prevent this legislation passing. Unfortunately, because of the left wing of the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats, combined with the government, we have been unable to prevent the legislation passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Greens.
—I am reminded by Senator Panizza to include the Greens. We have been unable to prevent this legislation passing. That is a matter of great regret.

PARA.TAB: I want to conclude by paying tribute to the dozen or 15 small businessmen who have sat in the Senate gallery throughout this debate. They have a very deep understanding of this legislation. I am sure, as a result of observing this debate—and they have sat here into the early hours of the morning while we debated this legislation—they are even better informed about the shortcomings of the legislation and the devastating impact that it will have on small business. I am sure they will go out into the community and tell their small business colleagues about the damaging effects this legislation will have. They will also tell them about the role that the Democrats and the government have played in passing this legislation. I am sure they will be doing all that they can to make sure that the Democrats and the government suffer the penalty for their stupidity at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill allegedly is to introduce enterprise flexibility agreements so that we can have a more productive private sector, so that we can increase employment, so that we can make more of the goods that people wish to buy in Australia and so that we can export more. But the bill will have the opposite effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. This has been a stunning victory for the ACTU. No-one in the community, apart from the leaders of the ACTU and the union movement, wanted the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. It was quite rightly bagged by all the major newspapers. —Within 24 hours the government will be receiving a report on employment options. PARA.TAB: Within 24 hours of receiving that report, this government will suddenly switch over to being concerned about the unemployed in this country. As I said, this was its best opportunity to help the unemployed in this country.
