SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Native Title Bill 1993 is in an unsatisfactory state, I am at least pleased to have the opportunity to explain the coalition's opposition and to further detail the coalition's policy in relation to this very complex matter—a policy which sets down a better approach. This is a complex, emotive and potentially divisory issue which has been appallingly handled by this Prime Minister (Mr Keating). If ever there was an issue which required a carefully thought through cooperative response, this was it. But, of course, that is language that the Prime Minister does not even understand.

PARA.TAB: It is an issue which tests our federal constitutional structure, which tests the communities' confidence in the rule of law and which potentially threatens the pace of economic development in rural and remote Australia. It is an issue that goes to the heart of Aboriginal development and the confidence of Aborigines in their society and their place within the wider Australian community. It is an issue that called for real national leadership, a cooperative federal response and a genuine effort to build community confidence in the decisions reached.

We have none of that. We now have the states opposed to this legislation, the mining industry opposed to it, the Aboriginal community divided, pastoralists worried and the wider community confused. We have one of the most important pieces of federal legislation in our history based, as I said, on no more than what the government claims to be a fragile consensus. If ever a piece of legislation needed the sound foundation of community support, this is it. But an arrogant and inept Prime Minister, putting his own enormous ego above the national interest, is hell-bent on ramming this bill through on the eve of Christmas. It is a disgrace. The inevitable division and disunity which will flow from this ill conceived and poorly executed piece of legislation will be Mr Keating's legacy.

We accept the existence of native title as declared by the High Court and the right of indigenous people to protection of that right of title. Having said that, sudden and dramatic turnarounds in the law do raise elements of uncertainty which many Australians find disconcerting. I remind the Senate of the established position as stated by Blackburn J. in Milirrpum v. Nabalco and the Commonwealth, which was decided in 1970, when His Honour said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a doctrine of communal native title to land does not form, and never has formed, part of the law of any part of Australia.

The accepted position in law was that the Crown took possession of a land which was regarded as `terra nullius'—a `land belonging to no-one'. It was an application of what was seen as the right to occupy uninhabited land. If one applied the uninhabited test strictly, then it clearly did not apply to Australia. But the terra nullius doctrine was extended to cover the acquisition of any territory inhabited by peoples whose civilisation was thought to be less developed in terms of ownership of property and political organisation.

PARA.TAB: Where the settlers found societies which they regarded as better developed by their definition, they accepted that there was an existing form of native title. Canada, USA, New Zealand, New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, India and Africa are all examples of that. So it was a legal doctrine which flowed from the then contemporary assessment of the society they found. There is no doubt that over the years anthropologists, politicians and lawyers have become increasingly uncomfortable with that original assessment upon which the law of title was based—particularly as our knowledge of Aboriginal society and culture and, in particular, the relationship of Aboriginal people to the land has grown.
I remind the chamber of the resolution of the Senate which was passed on 20 February 1975 in the following terms:

That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous peoples of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of this entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for dispossession of their land.

SPEECH.PARA: So the attitude of the Senate was changing by 1975.

PARA.TAB: I also remind the chamber of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report, entitled Two hundred years later . . . , put down in this parliament in 1983, a decade ago—and I was pleased to be a member of that inquiry. On page 7 of that report, the committee stated that there is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . growing appreciation of evidence that there were in existence at the time of white settlement Aboriginal people with complex systems of social, cultural and religious networks and of land tenure.
On page 39, the committee further stated:

PARA.TAB: It is apparent that the Aboriginal relationship with land is complex, and attempts to define it have perplexed anthropologists. There is no doubt that at the time of the establishment of English law in Australia this Aboriginal relationship with the land was both underestimated and misunderstood, perhaps because it was beyond the comprehension of recognised English legal principles of land tenure.

SPEECH.PARA: So a decade ago this Senate was recognising that there was a much more complex and—perhaps this is an unfortunate word—sophisticated relationship between Aborigines and the land in this country than was first understood at the time of white settlement.

PARA.TAB: Also, we see evidence within the international courts addressing the same issue of terra nullius. I remind honourable senators of the Western Sahara case, again decided in 1975. The judgment stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The nomadic peoples of the Shinguitti country should . . . be considered as having in the relevant period possessed rights, including some rights relating to the land through which they migrated.
One of their honours specifically stated:

I consider that the independent tribes travelling over the territory, or stopping in certain places, exercised a de facto authority which was sufficiently recognised for there to have been no terra nullius.

So the international courts dealing with the common law concept of terra nullius were also changing their attitude as they understood more of the nature of the relationship between land and what they referred to as nomadic tribes.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, in some way, although it is contrary to well established law in this country, perhaps it should not have come as a total surprise to see the multi-faceted arguments adopted by their honours in Mabo No. 2. I specifically refer to the leading judgment of Brennan J. First, what he said is that, with our expanded knowledge, we have now come to realise that that basis upon which the terra nullius principle was applied within Australia does not accord `with our present knowledge and appreciation of the facts'. So basically our understanding of the relationship between Aborigines and the land has changed, and therefore the application of those facts to the law can bring a different result.
Similarly, looking at the development through the international courts, I think it can be fairly said that Brennan J. also indicated that it was time for precedent to change. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the international law notion that inhabited land may be classified as terra nullius no longer commands general support, the doctrines of the common law . . . can hardly be retained.
In an application to apply contemporary values to the common law, he said:
. . . judged by any civilised standard, such a law . . .
that is, terra nullius as applied in these circumstances—
. . . is unjust and its claim to be part of the common law to be applied in contemporary Australia must be questioned.

So the High Court found that native title rights existed and survived through settlement, though subject to the sovereignty of the Crown—and that is a position which we on this side of the chamber accept and respect.

PARA.TAB: Whether any particular Aborigines still hold that native title will depend on whether they have maintained their connection with the land and to the extent that title has not been extinguished by acts of colonial, state, territory or Commonwealth governments; and their title will be defined in accordance with the traditional laws and customs of indigenous people. Obviously, therefore, such a judgment with so many ambiguities must introduce considerable uncertainty. It clearly leaves many issues unresolved.

Of course, laws have been passed in this country—and perhaps one could reflect on the Northern Territory land rights laws or, in my own state, the laws in relation to the Pitjantjatjara lands—on the basis of the then accepted understanding that native title did not exist. So it is not surprising that there was a considerable community reaction against the decision. But this government would simply label those who are concerned as racists and dismiss their concerns out of hand.

The government has also failed to appreciate how a mishandling of this matter would detrimentally affect what we are now calling the reconciliation process. Reconciliation which we support is, in terms of our Mabo policy statement—which some on the other side should read—an effort to build a just and lasting understanding amongst the peoples of Australia on the basis that we share a common destiny as citizens of an undivided Australia.

That was also the bottom line of the Makarrata inquiry of the Senate committee to which I referred a moment ago and which we put down 10 years ago in this chamber. Clearly, building a just and lasting understanding, as we found in taking of evidence in that inquiry, involves issues of land; it cannot be developed without resolving the issues of land because of the special or, some might say, spiritual relationship between Aborigines and the land.

The Mabo case, therefore, can be seen as contributing to overcoming what is regarded by Aborigines as a great injustice—that we fail to appreciate their relationship with the land and to understand the pain of dispossession. Nevertheless, Mabo, because of the uncertainty it has created, contains the ingredients for a backlash which would set the process of reconciliation back years.

Instead of understanding this, this silly Prime Minister, under the guise of extending or furthering reconciliation, decided that this legislation should further extend the concept of native title as found by the High Court and thus increased the uncertainty. But for his determination to include a social justice package, the cooperative response which he could have got with state premiers to manage and administer Mabo, in fact foundered.

The Prime Minister should have kept the issues separate; Mabo was complex enough without the Prime Minister adding to it. Mabo required certain legislative action, particularly to validate any past grants of title which might be invalid as a result of the Racial Discrimination Act or at common law; and to manage this new form of title in a way which would remove uncertainty, inhibit economic development and resolve any issues of compensation. But it should have been done in a cooperative way with the states validating title and the Commonwealth taking such action as would be necessary to facilitate that validation—and any validation again, as we state in our policy statement, must of course be accompanied by payment of just terms of compensation.

There was no need for the Commonwealth to seek to usurp the traditional and constitutional function of the states in relation to land management. Why complicate the matter even further with a battle for turf? There is no need for the Commonwealth to build a new bureaucracy of tribunals, assessors and registrars.

The best solution, which an impatient and power hungry Prime Minister would not accept, was one in which the Commonwealth and states worked together to validate existing titles through complementary legislation, leaving the states with the right to manage land titles in the future, provided that they would recognise the High Court decision and meet the requirements of the Racial Discrimination Act—our policy.

In this debate others will detail ongoing concerns and uncertainty for the pastoralists which will flow from this legislation; the uncertainty for the mining industry, which will be dealt with in considerable depth by a number of my colleagues; concerns for tourist leases and their validity; forestry leases, which was raised by the latest Senate committee report; and fishing interests—I would not be surprised if that were raised by my friend Senator Boswell. These are issues not settled by this legislation and in some cases they were created by this legislation—new confusion, new uncertainty. Others will look at the constitutional doubt that surrounds this piece of legislation, also dealt with in some detail by the dissenting report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs report put down a few days ago.

In the few minutes I have remaining I want to return to the position of the Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders whose interests might have been thought to have been advanced by Mabo No. 2. Australian governments have struggled to develop policy which would help overcome the disadvantages suffered by our indigenous people. They found it very difficult and, sadly, indigenous Australians are among the most disadvantaged of our community.

Obviously, health, education and housing services are all part of the correct policy mix. But there are other parts, some of which I think we still do not fully understand. Whilst I certainly do not claim to be an expert, my experience as a parliamentarian was to sit down a decade ago and listen to the communities at Thursday Island, Broome, Mornington Island, Derby, Fitzroy Crossing, Weipa, Cairns, Yirrkala, Alice Springs, Kakimburr, Aurukun, Balgo Hills and elsewhere. It was enlightening and the same issues seem to come through today.

What was needed, in addition to health, housing and education, was something to redress what I mentioned a while ago—the loss of identity or connection with the land. This clearly raises difficult issues and Mabo could have made a small, positive contribution in that direction if it had been well handled. The fact that it was not is one of the tragedies of the management of this particular responsibility by Mr Keating.

Another just demand was the right of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders to be recognised and respected as original inhabitants of this great land. Related to that is the need for non-indigenous Australia to respect and appreciate Aboriginal and Islander culture as vital, important and enriching Australia as a whole. There is the need for us to cease evaluating Aboriginals and Islanders against our values, particularly values of success and achievement. What came through was that it was more important to encourage confidence and pride in the path each individual might choose.

To that background, we now learn, as a result of the work of the Senate committee—I mentioned its report a moment ago and it is only a few days old—that many Aborigines are confused as to the effect of Mabo and want a longer period of consultation. Many were concerned as to what they see as the self-appointed negotiating team acting on their behalf without consent. They are concerned that the bill does not give the right to immediate exercise of native title; they are concerned with the fact that the bill is not stated to be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act; and that instead of land being controlled by its traditional owners in accordance with Aboriginal tradition and custom, the land will be controlled by corporations in accordance with corporate rules and by-laws, which is not in accordance with the Mabo decision.

All of these issues could have been explored with much greater care if the government had been prepared for sensible debate in February. It was not, and it therefore stands condemned. It has missed the opportunity to build from the challenge of Mabo a stronger and more united Australia. The Prime Minister must accept personal responsibility for this failure. We will vote against this bill and, if we can gather the numbers, we will force the government back to the process which will build a sound foundation for native title legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Western Australian senator, I think it is important that I make a contribution to this debate on the Native Title Bill. Western Australia has been very much part of the focus in the debate arising from the Mabo High Court decision. It is the state where the most impact from that decision will be felt; it is the state where legislation that seeks to abolish native title rights has been passed; and, quite clearly, it is also the state that elected the Western Australian Greens, who, in all probability, will hold the balance of power and determine the fate of this bill. A further point is that much of the industry campaign has been directed at Western Australian senators in an effort to influence how they will vote on this bill.

PARA.TAB: Because of those factors, I will abandon my general approach, which is to pursue a national perspective on issues and reject a narrow parochial view of politics, and adopt a fairly parochial Western Australian position in this debate—a position normally adopted by my fellow senators on the other side of the house.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you will.

—Senator Panizza will be proud of the approach that I adopt on this occasion, although he will not agree with anything that I say. I would like to advance three main propositions in support of the bill. Firstly, the Native Title Bill is an appropriate response to the High Court's decision. It recognises and protects native title rights, provides certainty of title for other titleholders and provides mechanisms for resolution of conflicts regarding native title land. Secondly, there exists a real conflict of interests and rights at stake that requires a balanced political solution. And there is not universal community support for the recognition and protection of native title rights, nor for the need for Commonweath legislation. Thirdly, the failure to pass legislation this year will favour those who seek to diminish Aboriginal rights, will act to disadvantage Aboriginal people and will represent a lost opportunity for Australia.

PARA.TAB: In support of my first proposition, I am very proud of the ALP's position in this matter and congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his personal involvement in developing the bill and trying to develop community support for it. I think his involvement has been crucial, and it is to his great credit.

The bill seeks to achieve four main purposes: to recognise and protect native title; to validate existing Commonwealth land titles where they may be invalid due to the existence of native title, and to allow states and territories to validate their own titles; to establish procedures for determining claims to native title; and to establish procedures for dealing with native title land. On any fair assessment, the bill is a balanced and fair outcome, given the competing interests that are at stake.

A lot has been made by the opposition of Aboriginal opposition to the bill. I was on the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that heard from many witnesses in that regard. But I think one of the things that must be recognised is that the Aboriginals most affected—those most likely to benefit from native title—have supported the bill strongly. Some have preferred amendment and are still pursuing amendment, but they accept the basic principles that underline the bill.

There is also a range of industry interests that recognise that the bill is a balanced and fair outcome, including the tourism industry, the National Farmers Federation and other interests. There is a range of mining and other business interests that think they can now do better out of the deal—the compromise—that this bill represents. That is their right, but I think on any fair, independent assessment, the bill is a balanced outcome that seeks to preserve and protect the rights of all Australians.

The more independent commentators that gave evidence to the legal and constitutional affairs committee—people like former Liberal Senator Fred Chaney and former Liberal Senator Peter Durack who, while not giving evidence, wrote a very interesting article on the subject—support the general thrust of the bill. I think their attitudes and comments ought to be seriously considered by honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do Peter Walsh and Graeme Campbell say?

—There is a range of opinion, and I accept that. But I think a fair summary was given by one of the witnesses to the legal and constitutional affairs committee, Garth Netthiem, who is a professor of law at the University of New South Wales and chair of the Aboriginal Law Centre. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: There have been trade-offs on all sides. But after 205 years of non-recognition of native title, it is only to be expected that its acceptance as part of Australia's legal landscape will cause adjustments which some groups will find uncomfortable.
But with goodwill and generosity of spirit, the new regime should be able to operate with minimal disruption to economic activity and with substantial justice for indigenous Australians.

I endorse those remarks. In relation to my second argument, which goes to the question of the real conflict of interest and rights that exist, I think it is important that we make this point because there has been a suggestion that somehow delay and further consultation will bring a better result than is contained in this bill. I think some of Senator Hill's comments go to that argument.

PARA.TAB: I think that is a naive view. Maybe I am being too generous and some people have more sinister motives, but I do not think anyone who has goodwill towards Aboriginal people seriously argues that a better result is possible than what will be achieved in the Senate this week. I do not think anyone suggests that delay or coming back to the issue some time down the track will deliver to Aboriginal people a better result. What we have is a concerted attack from those who believe that Aboriginal rights preserved in this bill can be rolled back and diminished by a further delay in the bill or by further public debate.

It is a sad fact, in my view, that the major objective of the bill is not universally supported. That major objective is to recognise and protect native title. A range of Western Australian industry groups have endorsed the Western Australian state legislation and have put out a four-point policy statement that deals with their philosophical position on the question of native title. But there is a very clear and unambiguous divergence between their position and the position the government adopts on key principles. Nowhere in the industry statement is there any reference to native title. Their fourth objective, which is the relevant one, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: To continue developing an alternative policy approach which includes strategies to improve Aboriginal standards of living in areas such as health, housing, education, employment and land ownership.

There is not one single mention of native title in the objectives in relation to this matter. They do not seek to recognise and protect native title as this legislation does. That is the major point of divergence. There is a clear and unambiguous divergence on whether or not one ought to recognise and protect native title.

PARA.TAB: We have seen in Western Australia a campaign to abolish native title. It has been supported by some industry groups and is the philosophical underpinning of the Western Australian state legislation, which has been endorsed by those Western Australian industry groups.

The Western Australian act abolishes native title. The Premier, Mr Court, claims that in fact it confers better rights than, or alternative rights to, native title. That is not supported by any independent legal advice that has been proffered in this debate. In fact, the Western Australian Law Society, hardly a socialist organisation or one that necessarily supports this government, has this to say about that act. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: On this considered view, it can only be said that the statutory rights of traditional usage created by the Bill are likely to be limited and of limited utility to any Aboriginal group able to assert them. They are rights far removed from the concept of native title declared by the High Court. In Mabo, the Merriam people were held entitled, as against the whole world, to possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the lands of the Murray Islands.

The Western Australian Law Society says that the state legislation provides limited rights far removed from the High Court decision. The Liberal Party, in the state most affected by this decision, has adopted a completely different approach from the Commonwealth on this issue. It actually does not seek to recognise native title rights; rather it seeks to abolish them.

PARA.TAB: This is not a question of a disagreement about interpretation or an argument about process, the sort of thing that the Liberal senators on the legal and constitutional affairs committee made great play of, the sort of thing Senator Hill referred to today. They cannot hide behind process forever. Sooner or later they have to stand up and say whether they support the philosophical position adopted in this bill of protecting native title rights or whether they support the philosophical position adopted in the state legislation to abolish native title rights. I will be very interested to hear from Western Australian Liberal senators as to which position they adopt because they cannot hide behind the sorts of interpretation, process and nice, fine legal arguments that were put by Senator Hill. They have to stand up and say where they stand on the fundamental issue.

We do have a fundamental philosophical difference in this debate. We have seen attempts in Western Australia to reinterpret the High Court decision, to discredit the High Court and to legislate away the rights granted by the High Court decision. There is a real political issue and real political conflict occurring here. To illustrate the point, the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia, in a submission to the legal and constitutional affairs committee, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Native Title Bill 1993 seeks to establish native title on mainland Australia, a fact not provided in the High Court's decision on Mabo No. 2 conferring a title proved for a settled agrarian and fishing community on a nomadic people of a completely different race and lifestyle.

If one has actually read the decision, one will see that that is nonsense, but these are the sorts of views that are being put about in Western Australia. In addition, we have had a range of leading Liberal Party figures seeking to run all sorts of agendas to discredit the High Court decision. A lot of people in the eastern states I think dismiss the President of the Liberal Party of Western Australia, Mr Hassell, as some sort of crackpot from the west, but he is very serious in his challenge to the High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is far from that.

—I agree with Senator Panizza. He is far from that. He has made a very serious challenge to the High Court. He accurately represents the philosophical approach adopted by Liberals in Western Australia. He challenges the right of the High Court to recognise native title and is doing everything he can to undermine those native title rights.

PARA.TAB: The Premier, Mr Court, has done his bidding and has legislated to give effect to that philosophical position. He has run a fear campaign about suburban backyards being under threat. He has advocated a referendum, suggested secession and done everything to beat up the issue and hide the real issues involved in this debate.

Some of the other contributions from Western Australian Liberals are very interesting. I do not have time to go into them, but I think people ought to look at what Mr Minson, the Western Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, said. He blames the high rate of custody of Aboriginals in Western Australian prisons on the Aboriginal Legal Service. They should also look at the comments of Mr Lightfoot, a backbencher of the Western Australian parliament, who called the Aboriginal people `the bottom colour in the civilisation spectrum'. That is the level of debate we have been having in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is to be rejected entirely.

—I concede that a member of the leadership in the Western Australian Liberal Party rejected that view and put it on the record, and I am very pleased that he did. The Western Australian Liberal Party submission to the legal and constitutional affairs committee, however, is a good summary of its views. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is discriminatory and creates two classes of Australians. Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. Aboriginal Australians will have exclusive rights to a form of land title unavailable to all other Australians. This is certain to create and foster racial division in Australia. This is especially the case where the form of Native Title, as proposed by the Federal Government, effectively establishes separate Aboriginal State within each State.

That is the formal submission of the Western Australian Liberal Party to the legal and constitutional affairs committee. Its position is to seek to abolish native title rights and then claim that it is the Europeans in Australia who are discriminated against. It advances this preposterous and twisted argument that we all ought to have one law and that somehow we are creating a separate law for Aboriginals. It fails to recognise the process the High Court undertook in recognising under common law that Aboriginal people had existing rights. I think Senator Hill explained the High Court analysis very well, but the Liberal Party in Western Australia rejects that whole argument and that whole philosophical position.

PARA.TAB: I listened carefully to Senator Hill and I am still not quite sure what the federal Liberal Party's position is. It says that it supports native title, but I do not hear any criticism of the Western Australian legislation. In fact, I hear support or silence. What I want to know is: does the federal Liberal Party support native title or does it support the Western Australian legislation and the Western Australian Liberal Party position? Opposition senators cannot avoid the issue forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports native title.

—I will be interested to hear Senator Panizza on this question because we really do want to know. The position of those opposite is not clear and they cannot keep hiding behind the question of process. They are going to have to put their hands up and be counted.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill suggested that we work for consensus with the states—consensus with a premier who refused to recognise the native title recognised in the High Court decision! Premier Court spent months saying that it should not have happened and that he did not recognise the judgment.

We had the Liberal Party president actually claiming that the High Court had no right to make such a decision, yet Senator Hill says we should have negotiated a consensus position with these people. We are not on the same planet; I concede that. We have no basis for that sort of consensus and the only way we will get the Western Australian Liberal Party to come to its senses and deal properly with this issue is to negotiate from a position of strength; that is, when this bill is passed. The Western Australian Liberal Party has passed its legislation and until the federal parliament passes this legislation there will be no native title rights in Western Australia and no bargaining power for Aboriginal people in Western Australia.

Senator Hill made a great deal of the `fragile consensus' in support of the bill. Sure, there is a fragile consensus of interests which have conflicting views, rights and attitudes to this bill, and it is hard to hold that consensus together, but the most fragile consensus in this debate is the decision of the federal Liberal party room. Liberal senators and members of the House of Representatives walked out of their party meeting when they finally adopted a position on native title saying, `We've achieved consensus. We've resolved all those conflicts'. It reminded me of Chamberlain returning from Munich, because it meant nothing; it had nothing to say about the hard issues and it does not face up to the real problem. Just like Chamberlain and the Munich Pact, it is not going to take those opposite anywhere. They cannot hold their fragile consensus together, because they are going to have to vote on this bill and explain where they stand on this issue.

The other argument I want to address is the importance of passing this legislation this year. I think it was adequately dealt with in the legal and constitutional affairs committee report. It will be a lost opportunity for Australian society to make a new start in Aboriginal relations if this bill is not passed. We must, and we can, deal with the legislation and pass it this week. The argument has been put that we must get it right, and I agree, but there are mechanisms for dealing with any errors or unintended consequences. The legal and constitutional affairs committee, of which I am a member, supports the need to review and monitor the legislation. I think that is a sensible step to take.

I think we really have to ask ourselves whether those who are arguing for delay really are seeking improvement. Do they really think that a consensus is possible or do they have a vested interest in undermining the principles in the bill? Do they think that their vested interests are best served by delay? I think we have to look at those questions very seriously.

There is no doubt that the agreement that has been reached is fragile in the sense that the longer it remains unratified, the more likely it is to be undermined. People who went to the negotiating table and negotiated a settlement will come under increasing pressure from both sides of the argument to renegotiate their positions. The longer it is left unconsummated, the more chance it has of falling apart. The government is genuinely concerned, because it believes that this is our best chance to get a proper and balanced solution. We are pessimistic about the prospects of having another chance to bring those disparate forces in society together if the legislation is not passed this year.

I have to ask people who advocate delay or refuse to support the bill this week: what will happen if the legislation is not passed? What will the other states do in response? Will they go down the Western Australian track or will we find the Commonwealth under pressure to just pass legislation that validates titles for existing titleholders and abandons native title and protection of native title rights for Aboriginal people? I think that is the reality we are faced with.

I think we also have to ask: if we re-open the debate, who will win? Who will benefit from the extended public relations campaign? In Western Australia we are already seeing a campaign from the Liberal Party, funded by taxpayers, as the state government winds up a campaign in support of its position. We also have a campaign by the mining companies and quite a scurrilous use of surveys by both groups. It reminds me of the 1980s lands rights campaign experience. I think we ought to bear that experience carefully in mind when we debate this issue.

My major point is that there is genuine disagreement about the detail of the bill by those who have goodwill for Aboriginal people. We recognise that those disagreements, however, are on the margins of one side of a fundamental debate as to whether to recognise native title rights granted by the High Court or to extinguish them. Amendments should and must be debated, but we must do that in the context of the debate in Australian society about whether we recognise native title or whether we extinguish those rights. That is the hard political choice. That is where every senator will have to stand up and be counted on this issue. We must bear that in mind as we determine this bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Crowley) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In answer to Senator Chris Evans in question time today, I made reference to the Attorney-General of Western Australia. I am informed that some people have drawn imputations from my answer, which imputations I did not intend to make. PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crowley) proposed:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the comments that have been made by Senator Bolkus. I regret that it took him so long to get here, but that is not to deflect from the unqualified withdrawal he made. I observe that Senator Bolkus—perhaps given bad advice—read his answer. The question was premeditated; the answer was considered and deliberate. To that extent, I remind the chamber that Senator Bolkus said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . given the public interest in Western Australia about the relationship between the Attorney-General of WA and Dr Bradshaw, my advice is that no request for Dr Bradshaw's extradition has been received from the Western Australian Attorney-General, Mrs Cheryl Edwardes—

In the mind of a reasonable person, that implies that there was something unsavoury about the relationship and that as a result of that relationship there was a dereliction of duty by the Attorney-General. In a statement made today the Attorney-General said:
"In recent times questions have arisen over the possible extradition of Dr Wayne Bradshaw from the Maldives and what role I as Attorney General have to play in any such decision.
It should be pointed out that under Western Australian law, the State's Director of Public Prosecutions has full responsibility for extradition and has established policy guidelines.

Section 14 of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act states that `It is the function of the Director to take steps to secure the extradition to Western Australia of any person required to answer any charge of an offence or to serve a sentence imposed in Western Australia'.
The Office of the DPP was created to be independent of the Government of the day and I have not or will not instruct him on such a matter.
There have also been assertions that I could approach the Federal Government seeking assistance in the extradition of Dr Bradshaw under the `London Scheme'.
Whilst there is no bi-lateral extradition treaty with the Maldives, the Maldives is a `London Scheme' country to which the Extradition Act 1988 (Commonwealth) applies.

This enables requests of the Federal Attorney General to be made to the Maldives. Under the `London Scheme' the Maldives can be expected to co-operate with a request made by the Federal Attorney General.

However, the Solicitor General of Western Australia has advised me that in relation to the `London Scheme', Western Australia's DPP Act means that it is for the DPP to decide whether the Federal Attorney General should be asked to request extradition.

Therefore, the DPP will—as is proper—make any decision relating to the extradition of Dr Bradshaw, who will be treated in exactly the same manner as anyone else who faces charges in Western Australia.

However, I have conveyed to the DPP's Office an undertaking that the State Government will, in terms of resources, support any moves by the DPP to seek the return from overseas of any person facing police charges in Western Australia."

It is quite clear that persons making assertions that the West Australian Attorney General can make decisions regarding extradition are doing so in absolute ignorance—deliberate or otherwise—of Western Australia's laws.
In fact, the West Australian DPP made a statement today confirming that the WA Parliament placed responsibility for extradition to WA on the DPP.
So the WA Opposition and the Federal Government are wrong again and Western Australia's Attorney General is right again.
The nebulous assertions made by the WA Opposition are meanders through slime.
There are standard processes and procedures in place for the DPP, and the Police, and the Attorney General does not set the timetable.
Her integrity in not compromising the independence of the DPP is to be applauded and is something that members of the Federal Government could learn from.
A press statement put out today by the Director of Public Prosecutions states:
Wayne William Bradshaw
The office of the Director of Public Prosecutions is aware of outstanding matters against Wayne William Bradshaw.
By section 14 of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, Parliament has placed responsibility for extraditions to Western Australia on the DPP.
At this stage, no decision has been made on the question of extradition of Bradshaw. It will be made at the appropriate time.

As I recall, the position of the DPP was created by a previous state Labor government, and the DPP was also an appointee of a previous state Labor government. I will touch briefly on two other matters, the first of which is an unfortunate interview that Senator Jim McKiernan had today on the Western Australian ABC morning program, the compere of which was a Mr Gerry Gannon. Mr Gannon introduced Senator McKiernan in this way:
Well, joining me now is Senator Jim McKiernan, who is a senator for Western Australia and a resident in the Shire of Wanneroo.
Now what is the procedure for extradition, who directs whom to move for extradition?
Senator McKiernan answered:
The state Attorney, Mrs Edwardes, would have to contact the federal Attorney, Mr Lavarch, for him to initiate the extradition proceedings.
Mr Gannon then said:
So it's a government to government exercise, at Attorney-General level.
Senator McKiernan replied:

It would.. a request would have to be made to the Commonwealth. It could be done by the DPP, or the police, but it would be more proper, in this instance, because of the previous links between Mrs Edwardes and Mr Bradshaw, that she do it. I do believe that, you know, her reputation, and the reputation of the state Attorney-General is on the line on this matter.

I will err on the side of righteousness and assume that Senator McKiernan was appallingly ill-informed of the facts when he made that statement. The truth of the matter is that the statement made by Senator McKiernan had no basis in fact and no basis in truth. As I have just indicated by reading the DPP's press statement and a statement put out by the state Attorney-General, this matter is beyond an Attorney-General's reach of responsibility, and it would be most improper for her to seek to intervene in the affairs and the conduct of the office of the DPP.

PARA.TAB: As Senator McKiernan has, by a set of words, connected the Western Australian Attorney-General—the chief law enforcement officer of that state—with Mr Bradshaw, I hope that he will come in and apologise for his assertion that she has been negligent in her duty, and for the imputation that her reputation is on the line. The fact that she did not interfere enhances her reputation and tarnishes those who would seek to damage her.

As I said this afternoon when taking note of ministers' answers given during question time, to make an assertion about the integrity of the conduct of the duties of the chief law enforcement officer of any state of Australia or of the Commonwealth is the gravest of allegations. It goes to the very fabric of our society. I noted that, once the assertion had been made, it attracted the mirth and giggles of a senior Labor senator. I wonder whether those opposite, when they stumble into this area, understand the damage that they are doing to the Senate and to the office that they hold by conducting themselves that way.

I would hope that when Senator McKiernan made the statements he made on the Gerry Gannon show, and another program, that he was not doing so for partisan political purposes. I hope that he was not doing so because Cheryl Edwardes, who is the member for Kingsley and who had campaigned vigorously in the seat of Wanneroo—previously held by Senator McKiernan's wife—and who was successful in many respects—

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot take the high moral ground and start throwing that sort of stuff.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure we both know that if Senator Evans has something to say, there is time available to allow him to do so when I sit down. I should hope that Senator McKiernan was not in some way reacting to the contribution that the Attorney-General had made to the Liberal Party's winning the seat of Wanneroo, a seat previously held by Senator McKiernan's wife. I do hope that those who have made assertions in this chamber, I trust in good faith, will come into this chamber and apologise for the assertions that they have made.

PARA.TAB: I did not hear what Senator Evans said in his interjection, but Senator Evans, by the deliberate words of his question, was seeking to implicate the Western Australian Attorney-General in an environment of impropriety. The truth of the matter is that the question fell on its face. As a result of that the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) came into the chamber tonight and withdrew the implications of his answer and the clear assertion that his answer was intended to give. TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks the structure of the Australian stock market came close to undergoing one of the most profound policy changes in its history. The near decision of the Australian Stock Exchange Board of Directors to allow the introduction of differential voting shares—or super shares as they are known—would have transformed the investment culture in this country and would have altered the terms on which ordinary shareholders buy shares. It had the potential to change the relationship of power and accountability which operates across the stock market.

PARA.TAB: The issue of the introduction of super shares onto the Australian Stock Exchange needed to be treated most cautiously. It needed to be pursued in an open and orderly manner so that the Australian shareholders, large and small, could make an informed judgment as to its merits or otherwise. But the manner in which the Australian Stock Exchange pursued the super shares issue should be of great concern to the investment and business community.

If nothing else, it caused the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities—of which I am a member—to intervene and, by doing so, encouraged the federal Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to intercede in the issue as well. This dramatic parliamentary intervention occurred simply because, in mid-November this year, it looked as if the Australian Stock Exchange was about to introduce super shares of its own volition.

Indeed, the Australian Stock Exchange issues paper on differential shares was only widely distributed on November 10. The Australian Stock Exchange issues paper raised some 25 specific issues which needed to be responded to. These had to be lodged by November 29—only 19 days after it was first released. Further, the Australian Stock Exchange informed the public that it would make a decision on the share plan as early as December.

I understand the Australian Stock Exchange's concerns over the threat of losing News Group's contribution to the market's profitability. I believe News's contribution to daily turnover is something like 10 per cent, and I understand trading in News shares earns brokers about $60 million a year. I appreciate that the exchange operates in an international market and cannot long survive structural distortions in its own listings which are not apparent in others.

Despite this, however, there were bigger community issues involved about which the ASX needed to be well aware. The decision to rush through the superannuation shares initiative did nothing for the confidence of the ordinary shareholders—those mums and dads—who have been courted by the stockbrokers in the last two years.

Principally, with the Woolworths and the Commonwealth Bank floats, the share market has won a good deal of renewed favour and interest from small shareholders. The mums and dads have been encouraged to return to the Stock Exchange and to invest their private earnings—their wages and salaries—into stocks and issues. They have done this on the basis that the wheeling and dealing which characterised the market in the 1980s has been buried. They have returned because they believe that the Gordon Gekko mentality has been burnt out of the boardrooms and that an Australian family can invest confidently in a new, responsible, sober-minded investment industry which looks to the long term, not to the quick return at their expense.

But no sooner does the family investor return to the market than the managers of the stock market are seen to be back to their old tricks. What sparks the public suspicion even more so in these matters is the coincidental timing of the superannuation share development. No sooner does the stock market become a bit bearish and no sooner does its capitalisation increase, investment rates recover and the brokers become a bit flush with funds again, than we get the smell of the deals being done all over again.

The Stock Exchange's unseemly rush to embrace superannuation share plans shows that the board of the ASX is not sufficiently distant and dispassionate from the market forces operating in brokerage houses and other across-market influences. It seems to me that the ASX board has an ongoing potential conflict of interest between its perceived loyalties to the brokerage houses on the one hand and the investing public on the other. This problem is set to become the source of continuing difficulties in the future.

As long as the Australian Stock Exchange board of directors continues to be simply chosen from amongst the ranks of the brokerage houses we cannot expect it to act effectively as a watchdog of its own conduct. Look at the composition of the ASX board of directors. Its 15 members all come from the narrow stock brokerage and banking areas. Ten are elected members of the ASX and four were appointed directors by the other 10. The other is the managing director of the Stock Exchange. So, at a minimum, 11 of the 15 are straight out of the Stock Exchange itself.

I do not see on the current membership list too many ordinary shareholders or dispassionate observers, obviously dedicated by virtue of their backgrounds to oversee the interests of the investment public. They are part of the broker-stock market culture and cannot be rightly expected to carry out an increasingly formal regulatory role. But here they are making judgments which have massive ramifications for the community and for the legion of small, ordinary shareholders. This serves as a warning for the future.

The ASX board, as currently constituted, may not be suitably representative or appropriately far enough removed from the stock market to make the professional judgments that the community and the parliament expect of it. In view of this, it is important that the parliament reassess the structure of the ASX board to ensure that it is effectively pursuing the interests of the investing public and executing its regulatory responsibilities in an arm's length way.

Regulatory agencies are expected to be aloof from the activity that they are designed to regulate. But, for some reason, the ASX has escaped the issue and the responsibility. I remind the Senate that when similar issues arose in the UK the board of the London Stock Exchange was restructured to widen its representation to provide it with the basis for the effective execution of its regulatory and monitoring functions.

I propose the restructuring of the ASX board, either by statute or through its own articles of association, to ensure a wider body of representation of interests and viewpoints. The current ASX articles allow for four appointed representatives from the business community. I believe that this practice needs to be widened. Representation on the ASX board should embrace shareholder representative bodies and associations and other public and private figures with a professional and academic interest or a long experience in company law, the activities of the stock market or consumer affairs.

The appointment of outsiders to the ASX board could be given effect through amendments to the Securities Industry Act 1980—the principle act under which the ASX was incorporated. This would give statutory effect to the representative remodelling of the ASX board, and it would serve to override any inconsistencies which might arise in the ASX's own articles.

Generally, I would envisage that outside appointees to the ASX board would be similar in status and standing to nominee directors in other companies. I also consider it important that there be a mandatory reporting requirement on the part of the ASX to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities of all major decisions affecting the operation of the share market and the interests of ordinary shareholders. This will ensure that no key decisions are pushed through the ASX without careful consideration. This reporting requirement could take a legislative form, though I envisage the ASX accommodating a requirement from within its own resources and on a cooperative basis for a trial period at the very least.

I make this recommendation in view of the simple fact that neither the joint committee nor the Attorney-General received any prior warning concerning the decision making process that the ASX had embarked upon in respect of super shares. This is a set of circumstances which the investing public and the parliament should not have to tolerate. I cannot see any reason for having any confidence that these circumstances will not re-emerge unless the parliament pushes for change in the ASX board structure. I intend to refer the matter to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, with the aim of establishing an inquiry into the representative nature of the ASX board.

Having lost the confidence of the public in the 1980s, we surely cannot afford to lose it again in the 1990s. While accusations of interference in stock exchange activities may be levelled and its greater freedoms damaged, I believe greater damage would be done to the competitiveness of the exchange by loss of confidence in the ability of the ASX to monitor exchange activities than any small scale regulatory intervention into the ASX's affairs could ever cause.

My spouse has not made any public comment on this matter.

I have certainly never felt the need to stand up in this place or in the city boundaries of Wanneroo to defend my spouse or her political position. She is a very strong individual who is more than capable of defending herself or advancing her own arguments on matters that are of interest to her. She has done that in the past.

My comments this morning on Perth radio were of interest to the electorate that I represent within Western Australia. As Senator Crichton-Browne indicated in the quote from Gerry Gannon, I live within the city of Wanneroo, and I am aware of the scandals that have gone on for a number of years within the council of Wanneroo. Again, a check of the record will indicate that I have never utilised the forums of this parliament to raise those matters, and it has not been my intention to do so; but I do not run away from a brawl either. If that is the way honourable senators want to play it, I am more than happy to muck in with the best of them.

I have been told that Mrs Cheryl Edwardes, the state Attorney-General, followed me on the Gerry Gannon morning program. She has had adequate time to address any of the matters that I raised on the program. Those matters were not confined to the ones referred to by Senator Crichton-Browne—I did make other stronger comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under Standing Orders 190 and 191, I seek leave to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented, misunderstood or not heard properly.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the hour, I will not take more time than is absolutely necessary. I read out in a very honest fashion the comments made by Senator McKiernan about Mrs Edwardes and the question of the extradition. I did not seek to widen the comments past those germane to the matters I wanted to raise. I hope Senator McKiernan does not think that I misrepresented or misquoted him.
—No, I said to the best of my recollection you were accurate.

—I thank Senator McKiernan. When Senator McKiernan reads Hansard, he will see that I cast no reflection upon his wife in any way. I said I hoped that his comments were not inspired as a result of the contribution that Mrs Edwardes made toward the defeat of his wife in the seat of Wanneroo.

PARA.TAB: I endorse Senator McKiernan's comments—and I was not close to it for more than a couple of days—that it was a perfectly respectable and decent campaign. I have never known Senator McKiernan's wife to act in any other way and I would not expect her to. Senator McKiernan should be assured that I was not reflecting on her. Senator Crowley was here and she would have heard what I said. It will all be in the Hansard tomorrow.

I should say, by way of an excursion, that my wife had to sit in the President's gallery in the old Parliament House one evening and be insulted and attacked by Senator Walsh in a most obscene and dishonest way. There was not a shred of truth, integrity or fact in anything he said. He was able to do it because he did it under parliamentary privilege. He would not dare say it outside. That is the way Senator Walsh did business. It is not the way I do business and it is not the way Senator McKiernan does business. But I have to say that we are all very human when it comes our children, our wife or our relations being attacked. That is why I am supersensitive about those things.

Senator Chris Evans has not had enough experience to know that, when one responds in the chamber, it is good manners to stay and listen to the duration of the debate. Senator Evans said in his last sentence that I protest too much. That is an imputation on me and I could have asked for it to be withdrawn. The connotation is that there is something improper about me and the way I put it. But Senator Evans perhaps is not sufficiently sophisticated to know how to use the phrase and the right expression. So I say that it was more stupidity than malice.

I find it absurd that Senator Evans put to me and this chamber that it is `a bit rich' that I should be offended that a Western Australian state minister is being attacked. I forgive Senator Chris Evans because he gets everything wrong. He could not even get a ballot paper right, which cost one of his colleagues a seat in the upper house. So I will forgive him for any mistake after that. We are going to the Supreme Court tomorrow morning to get costs awarded against the Labor Party, which no doubt will cause him to blush when they are costed. A perusal of the Hansard will show that on not one occasion, to my memory, did I reflect in this chamber on any member of the previous state Labor government. To suggest that I did—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you winding up?
—Yes, but he reflected on me.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I suggest that you remind Senator Crichton-Browne not just of the hour but that, if he is seeking to make a statement about how he claims to have been misrepresented, then he should confine his remarks to that claimed misrepresentation.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Crowley's point is valid. As this is a personal explanation because you claim to have been misrepresented, I encourage you to keep your remarks to that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would not dare to presume to canvass your ruling, but I did also claim under standing order 191 that I had been misunderstood. Having said that, I raised the matter because of the clear and unqualified implication in what Senator Chris Evans said, that I had no right to defend a state minister because of the way that I and others had attacked the state Labor Party. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice no 232 (Senate Hansard, 1 September 1993, page 841) concerning the integration of the health staffs of the Headquarters of the Australian Defence Force and the Service Offices, and particularly on the issue of not allowing health professionals, other than doctors, to compete for three of the four most senior positions in the new organisations:
(1) Did the Chiefs of Staff Committee agree that positions in the new organisation were to be available to all health professionals on a best candidate for the job basis.

(2) If the responsibilities of the positions involved require broad military and health service experience, why is it that dentists, nurses and other health professionals who have this experience and who have excelled in their military careers, are unable to compete for three of the four most senior positions.

(3) Is the practice of not allowing health professionals other than doctors to compete for these positions consistent with the practice in other Commonwealth and State health authorities in filling SES band one and two positions with responsibility for health policy formulation and health service management.
(4) Does the Minister agree with the advice he has received on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Chiefs of Staff Committee agreed that all positions not clearly requiring medical, dental or nursing qualifications were to be available to all health service professionals or general list officers.

(2) The responsibilities of the Surgeon General and two of his Directors General are predominantly medical in nature necessitating medical qualifications as a prerequisite in addition to broad military and health service experience. The responsibilities of the third Director General are such that the position is available to both medical and other health professionals. All three Directors General have Service-specific responsibilities and are selected by their respective Service in accordance with Service prerequisites.

(3) As indicated in my answer to question on notice no 232, this arrangement is entirely in keeping with modern military medical practice. The health services in the Australian Defence Force provide a service not available from the civilian sector: a field service in support of military operations. At the most senior levels of health management, the task is to situate the provision of health services in the military context. This involves the provision of health advice and the development of health policy with an appreciation of the impact that such advice and policy will have on the provision of military health services to meet military operational needs. Considerable military experience is necessary and, as the advice requested and the policies generated are predominantly of a medical nature, the Service medical officer stream is the best placed to provide candidates for these positions. Under the circumstances it is not valid to compare the unique military requirement with the practice in other Commonwealth and State health authorities when filling SES band one and two positions. The incumbents of these positions generally have the responsibility for health policy formulation and health service management only; they do not have any equivalent to the Service responsibility to provide medical advice to a Chief of Staff, to enable him to discharge his command responsibilities.
(4) Yes.
